IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to harness the synaptogenic potential of Sema4D/Plexin B1 signaling to enhance inhibition in neural circuits by increasing GABAergic synapse number. This approach would be beneficial to preventing the establishment of epilepsy, halting its progression, or suppressing hyperexcitability during a seizure event. The proposed studies provide a unique opportunity to determine whether Sema4D, or ideally in the future, small molecules that activate Plexin B1, could be a novel therapeutic strategy for preventing or curing epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH In both health and disease, all cells in the body respond to engagement with specific proteins in their environment, but the molecular basis of many such interactions is poorly understood. Through the development of new tools that can parse the molecular determinants of protein-protein interactions and the signals that these complexes transmit into the cell, novel insights will be gained that will then be further leveraged to precisely tailor new protein drugs and cellular therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying previously unappreciated molecular/cellular mechanisms promoting synapse resilience to the detrimental impact of toxic tau oligomers in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This is ultimately expected to drive the development of a novel, effective preventive/curative therapy for AD, thus improving these patients’ health while driving down the societal cost for their care, which is expected to increase to unbearable proportions by the year 2050. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission concerned with fostering creative discoveries and their application to advance the Nation’s capacity to protect and improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wound healing is a fundamental biological process that is critical to the survival of all living organisms and cells of the monocyte/macrophage lineage play essential roles in this process. Macrophages are capable of performing a diverse array of tasks during wound healing, ranging from destructive killing functions to pro-healing and homeostatic duties, through their ability to adopt a wide spectrum of phenotypes. However, assessments of these phenotypes have so far been biased and incomplete. A goal of my laboratory over the next 5 years is to take advantage of newly developed single cell analysis techniques to determine, using unbiased methods, the actual phenotypes that macrophages adopt during normal and impaired wound healing and how these phenotypes are regulated. The overall vision guiding our approach is that by identifying novel regulators of macrophage function during wound healing, we can develop new approaches to manipulate inflammation and improve healing of poorly healing wounds, and in the process, generate a pipeline of candidate therapies to translate into clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The hippocampus is one of the few areas of the brain that integrate new neurons through adulthood. Adult- born neurons are known to improve spatial memory through processes that are not entirely understood. Here, we will test whether these neurons regulate the precision of brain circuits that encode spatial location. We expect to gain a better understanding of how adult neurogenesis improves cognition, which could open the door to potential new therapeutic targets for dementia and memory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The rate of drug overdose deaths in the United States has doubled over the last decade, reaching a staggering loss of more than 70,000 individuals per year. The proposed work characterizes a neural circuit that underlies the increased drug consumption that takes place by some individuals following chronic drug use. The information gleaned from this work will inform potential treatment targets for reducing intake in substance abusers, lowering the risk of overdose death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) participates in so many cellular tasks that trouble can ensue when it stops working properly, including β cell death in type 1 and type 2 diabetes. Despite the underlying importance of ER dysfunction, there is no effective diabetes treatment targeting the ER due to the complex etiologies of type 1 and type 2 diabetes. Our strategy for overcoming this challenge is to focus on monogenic forms of diabetes in which mutations in single genes are involved in ER dysfunction and disease manifestations. We will carry out molecular genetic studies of five types of ER diabetes to characterize variants using functional assays and bioinformatics and then develop novel treatments targeting the common molecular pathways altered in hereditary ER diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Tissue repair places many metabolic requirements on the wounded tissue for adequate healing and suffers from the detrimental effects of many pathological conditions. Obesity and diabetes are critical conditions that impair the metabolic regulation of many tissues. This proposal will optimize NAD functions in the metabolism of fracture tissues for the enhancement of bone fracture repair in an obesity/Type-2 diabetic condition. Obesity and the associated condition of Type-2 diabetes have become more frequent in the general population and are even more serious among aging veterans. It is well established that Type-2 diabetics generally suffer from impaired tissue and bone healing caused by an insufficient metabolic response to the requirements of tissue repair. Among the many documented effects of Type-2 diabetes on bone, the critical processes of osteogenesis and vascularity are reduced. Wound healing in challenging physiological conditions such as diabetes and obesity is therefore particularly problematic in bone repair and requires novel approaches that optimize tissue metabolism for healing.  This study will develop novel local therapeutic approaches to improve the tissue redox potential and promote bone repair in an obesity/Type-2 diabetes condition. This intervention will increase NAD production and fracture tissue metabolism through the local application of NAMPT agonists and augment NAMPT functions in the NAD salvage pathway. To achieve these objectives, selected agonists of NAMPT functions will be screened for their action on periosteal cells and identified as therapeutic candidates for the enhancement of NAD biosynthesis. These NAMPT agonists will subsequently be applied locally to the fracture tissues of mice induced to an obesity/Type-2 diabetic through a high-fat diet and bone repair then evaluated.  We have acquired exciting preliminary data demonstrating that local applications of an antagonist of NAMPT inhibits the functions of bone cells in vitro and impairs bone formation in vivo in the fractures of normal mice. It therefore stands to reason that the local application of an agonist of NAMPT functions would produce the opposite effect, enhancing NAD production and tissue metabolism, promoting bone formation in mice with physiologic conditions of reduced tissue metabolism and ultimately enhancing otherwise impaired bone fracture healing. We have chosen the obesity/Type-2 diabetic condition to test our hypothesis that augmenting NAMPT functions through the local application of an NAMPT agonist improves bone formation and fracture repair in an obesity/Type-2 diabetic condition, we hypothesize that NAD production is insufficient to maintain the tissue metabolism necessary for sufficient bone formation and fracture repair.  Two specific aims are proposed to develop this approach. 1) Agonists of NAMPT function will be screened in those bone cells established as mediators of endochondral bone formation, specifically periosteal cells. The effects of these NAMPT agonists on bone cell proliferation, motility and redox potential will be characterized. 2) Candidate NAMPT agonists that are especially potent or multifunctional in the enhancement of these functions in periosteal cells will subsequently be injected directly to the tibial fractures of mice that have been induced to the obesity/Type-2 diabetes condition through a high-fat diet. The effects of these agonists on bone repair in this condition will be characterized by various radiologic and histologic approaches for their promotion of healing. The results will help to develop local therapeutic interventions that improve impaired bone fracture repair.  The completion of the proposed studies should facilitate the development of novel therapeutic interventions that improve tissue responses to the metabolic requirements of wound repair and promote the healing of skeletal and non-skeletal tissues in challenging conditions such as age, obesity and diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Nerve cells (neurons) project elongated processes (axons) from the brain into the spinal cord to make connections (synapses) with motor neurons that drive movement. To identify genes that control the specificity of these connections, we are using the nematode C. elegans, a model organism with a simple, well-defined nervous system. The results of this work should reveal similar human genes with crucial roles in the creation spinal cord circuits and therefore potentially contribute to the development of treatments for spinal cord injury and dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Recent studies have suggested that living donors (LDs) have increased risks of kidney failure and death; but follow-up has been limited and there are serious problems with the scientific design of these studies, particularly with the characteristics of people compared to the LDs. We will compare LDs with true long-term follow-up to an optimally matched control group (same time period, same geographic area, healthy on date of donation, no abnormal kidney function); and in addition to kidney failure and death, study intermediate events (e.g., kidney function, cardiovascular disease), pregnancy and outcomes after new-onset disease (e.g., hypertension).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The efficacy of psychological interventions for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is likely limited by the difficulty patients have learning and remembering important therapy content. The proposed research will examine whether integrating a Memory Support intervention into Cognitive Processing Therapy for PTSD improves memory and learning of therapy content as well as corresponding reductions in PTSD symptoms. This work has the potential to advance knowledge about how to optimally deliver treatment for PTSD and help us better understand the factors influencing therapeutic learning.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Critically ill pediatric patients are at risk for poor outcomes if they do not receive high-quality care by prehospital emergency services, and there is significant concern that the quality and safety of pediatric prehospital care is lacking. In this project, we will develop a method to measure how ready an Emergency Medical Services agency is to care for critically ill pediatric patients. We will then evaluate how the readiness factors are associated with patient outcomes in a large cohort of children from both urban and rural areas across the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Human cells are challenged constantly by genotoxic stress of both environmental and intracellular origins. The ability to maintain the structure and function of the DNA replication machinery in the face of genotoxic stress is key to the prevention of cancer and other diseases. This proposal seeks to decipher a novel calcium-dependent signaling pathway that is essential for the protection of the replication machinery, with the ultimate goal of developing more effective cancer treatment strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal seeks to understand the impact that recently announced changes to the Medicare Shared Savings Program will have on an accountable care organization’s (ACO’s) decision to participate, as well as the potential effects of these changes on care delivery, health outcomes, and spending. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The skin surface is populated by diverse bacteria, and some of these commensal species help protect the skin against pathogens such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Our proposed studies will determine how cell to cell signaling mechanisms are employed by commensal bacteria to enable them to outcompete pathogens and thus benefit skin immunity. This research is relevant to public health because it is expected to provide the basis for the development of new strategies to treat and/or prevent bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This project is proposed to study a novel mechanism regulating transmembrane proteins by inverting the direction through which they are inserted into membranes. Achieving the project will have significant impacts on basic science regarding structure and function of transmembrane proteins, as it will fundamentally change our views on these proteins. Since transmembrane proteins are often the receptors for various drugs and pathogens, completion of the project may provide novel insights to combat human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In less developed parts of the world, there is an urgent need for accurate and more informative diagnosis of breast cancer as trained pathologists are scarce‚ and pathology infrastructure is often very limited. The proposed research will complete the currently ongoing development of a cell-phone based device that: (1) images cells from breast tumors and analyzes them by software to identify whether a person has breast cancer, and (2) measures levels of clinically-relevant protein biomarkers to help guide treatment. If successful, this technology can be widely by health care workers to provide the same level of care in low-resource settings as is currently available in the US and will thereby save many lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: I have spent my career as an NINDS-funded neuroscientist developing expertise in neuronal ion homeostasis and translating my findings to clinical care. Although I have focused on seizure therapies, many of the discoveries I have made are equally applicable to the volume shifts that occur in neurons after brain injury. These volume shifts are among the most incalcitrant and problematic barriers to improved outcomes after brain injury. In the enclosed R35 application, I propose to leverage NINDS’ investment in me and unravel these problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) has been shown to reside within the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) as an asymptomatic reservoir capable of seeding recurrent urinary tract infections (rUTI). This proposal seeks to elucidate how the previously unexplored interplay between the GIT and bladder (the gut-bladder axis) determines susceptibility to rUTI by determining: i) genetic mechanisms used by UPEC to invade, persist, and bloom in the GIT; ii) how the microbiota elicits host responses linked to susceptibility to rUTIs; and iii) how dysbiosis of the GIT microbiota affects colonization resistance. Knowledge gained by these studies will transform the development of antibiotic-sparing therapeutics needed to treat and prevent recurrent UTIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As the most common childhood-onset motor disability, cerebral palsy (CP) affects 764,000 individuals in the United States alone and accounts for lifetime healthcare expenses of $1.4 million per person. In approximately 20% of cases (or 150,000 individuals), the cause is unknown, raising concern for a genetic disorder, including treatable conditions where a molecular diagnosis may positively alter the trajectory of a child's development. This study will determine the genetic landscape of CP, including potentially treatable conditions; develop rules to predict which individuals with CP are likely to have a genetic disorder; and contribute to an emerging scientific understanding of the pathophysiology of CP that will impact a large patient population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary objective of the proposed alcohol research training program is to increase the availability of skilled clinical scientists from diverse backgrounds. We will achieve this goal by providing individual and group didactics and mentorship during the critical transition from clinical psychology doctoral training through clinical internship and NIAAA-supported postdoctoral fellowships. Implementing the proposed training program will help ensure that NIAAA remains a global leader in the development and dissemination of effective alcohol-related prevention and treatment efforts, and that it is equipped to fulfill its mission to meet the continuously evolving healthcare needs of the U.S. population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a debilitating incurable disease and presents a major public health problem leading to great economic and societal burden. The proposed studies will determine the capabilities of neural stem cells derived from primitive mesenchymal stem cells to provide anti-inflammatory response and neuroprotection as well as neuroregeneration in an animal model of MS. The results of this investigation will help devise strategies to treat not only MS but also other neurodegenerative disorders using cell therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following intercourse, the best sperm is naturally selected as the one that first successfully traverses the distinct biochemical microenvironments within the female reproductive tract. By mimicking these diverse biochemical microenvironments within the female reproductive tract and understanding how sperm motility should be accordingly modified, we can help clinicians identify the best sperm for IVF. This will increase production of healthy embryos and thus reduce the number of costly IVF cycles, easing the financial burden and making these procedures more accessible to low-income couples.

PHR: Project Narrative Research using the amphibian Xenopus, because of unique advantages as an experimental system, has revealed key insights in many domains of biomedical research, including cell biology, development, neurobiology, physiology and signal transduction, achievements that are supported by having a centralized National Xenopus Resource for raising and distributing animals and disseminating the most current technology to the research community. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This proposal describes the development and optimization of CD46 targeted radioimmunotherapy, and the systematic testing and evaluation of the method in preclinical models of prostate cancer. Novel chemical methodology is utilized to optimize the delivery of therapeutic radiation to tumor while minimizing healthy tissue delivery. A major focus of the proposal is the utilization of novel, clinically relevant metastatic PCa models, and the evaluation of the therapeutic efficacy and toxicity using a combination of histologic, microscale dosimetry, and metabolomic analysis.

PHR: Project Narrative Over the past 45 years, the NIDDK-supported training program in the Division of Nutritional Sciences has been instrumental in the development of nutrition professionals who hold research positions in academia, government, and industry, and key policy positions in government, international agencies, and nonprofit foundations. The training program is built on the graduate program in nutrition at Cornell University that emphasizes multidisciplinary and integrative scholarship across the biological, physical, behavioral,and social sciences, as appropriate for individual trainees. The NIDDK-supported training program emphasizes translational and collaborative approaches to meet national needs in translational research and includes a combined PhD-RD training program.

PROJECT_TITLE: NUTRITION TRAINING

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation-induced endothelial dysfunction can cause immune diseases, such as chronic inflammation and autoimmune disease. We will establish a nanopatterned inter-digitated electrode arrays-based assay for high- throughput phenotype screening of endothelial cell junction and immune cell interactions in a coculture of endothelial cells and pericytes. With the platform, we will evaluate endothelial dysfunction in inflammation and identify drug candidates to reverse the dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance to Public Health: Patients in the early stages of Alzheimer’s disease each display a unique pattern of altered brain structure, function, and thinking and memory skills. Knowing that their diagnosis of amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI) places them at risk for developing Alzheimer’s disease, patients often seek out intervention to delay the progression of the disease without knowing whether it will truly provide benefit. This project will use advanced machine learning tools to provide detailed predictions of aMCI patients’ likelihood of improving from a widely supported cognitive training intervention, and clarify how an individual patient’s brain and cognitive features contribute to their response-to- intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Heavy drinking in young adults is associated with serious negative consequences and is a major public health concern; however, interventions have shown limited efficacy. The goal of this project is to evaluate cognitive- based and mindfulness-based Regulation of Craving Training (ROC-T), which are novel, brief, web-based interventions that directly target core mechanisms implicated in drinking: craving and the regulation of craving. We specifically propose a randomized-controlled trial comparing these interventions to a control condition, and to test the effects on drinking as well as on cognitive, affective, and neural mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: As obesity increases in adolescents type 2 diabetes is also increasing. We do not know why T2D happens in some adolescents but not others or how to identify which adolescents will develop diabetes. This multicenter clinical study is designed to follow a large group of youth at-risk for T2D over 30 months and to identify differences in a variety of factors between those who do and do not develop diabetes.

PHR: Obesity is a major health problem associated with metabolic syndrome and type II diabetes and the control of adiposity is a top priority in managing these diseases. Promoting thermogenesis may not only help in combating obesity but also in improving glucose/insulin homeostasis. This research is to understand how thermogenesis is regulated upon norepinephrine/cold stimulation by increasing PKA activity and may provide new therapeutic targets for obesity/diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this U24 application is to establish an inclusive research network to identify mechanisms through which soft tissue manipulations exert biological effects on the nervous system, as well as on non-neural cells and tissues. The Neuronal & Systems Mechanisms of Affective Touch & Therapeutic Tissue Manipulation Research (NeuronS_MATTR) Network will nucleate an emerging field focused on the neurobiology of soft tissue mechanotherapies. Through combinations of multidisciplinary conferences, summer schools, pilot projects and dissemination programs, NeuronS_MATTR will address high-priority areas to elucidate the neural mechanisms of forced-based manipulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue structural cells can harbor ‘inflammatory memory’ of prior inflammatory responses in the form of stable epigenetic modifications that alter their transcriptional potential and behavior following subsequent tissue damage but how T cells influence inflammatory memory in the skin is unknown. In this proposal, we will examine the cross-talk between T cell derived cytokines and structural cells in vitro culture systems, in a murine model of T cell-dependent skin inflammation, and in samples from patients with inflammatory skin diseases to mechanistically dissect reprogramming of structural cells by T cells, and determine if this process can be targeted therapeutically to block cutaneous inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT A key challenge for psychiatry and clinical psychology is to discover, understand, and ultimately to treat the root causes of the most serious and debilitating mental illness, including schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. This project will harness an innovative combination of state-of-the-art technologies — including brain imaging and smartphone-based mobile surveys— to objectively identify and prioritize the pathways that promote paranoia, a common, debilitating, and treatment-resistant symptom of psychosis. This project will provide a potentially transformative opportunity to identify new treatment targets and to accelerate the development of digital interventions that are scalable, customizable, and inexpensive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is a highly aggressive and deadly brain tumor, with current treatment strategies ineffective and highly debilitating. The proposed research aims to investigate the role of targeting multiple phagocytosis checkpoints expressed in GBM as a novel therapeutic approach using a newly developed bispecific CD47-B2m antibody. The results generated from the proposal will enhance our understanding of tumor immune escape and provide a novel therapeutic strategy for treating GBM as well as other malignant tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Poly-substituted arenes and heteroarenes are ubiquitous in pharmaceuticals and approved drugs; however, the efficiency of using conventional approaches to access these structural motifs remains to be improved. The outlined proposal aims to enable new efficient catalytic methods for direct preparation of poly-substituted arenes and heteroarenes from readily available feedstocks. Success of the proposed research would significantly expedite the synthesis of complex aromatic molecules, which, in turn, would ultimately accelerate drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Retinal degeneration is the most common cause of untreatable blindness world- wide. The research proposed here will test hypotheses about how dying photoreceptors interact with resident immune cells, which help to remove debris and dying cells and can also secrete neurotrophic factors to support tissue repair and recovery. The ultimate goal of the work is to be able to delay or prevent photoreceptor degeneration through manipulation of the early immune response.

PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance to Public Health Many mental diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease and Huntington’s disease, are thought to be caused by failures in neuronal intracellular signaling related to learning and memory. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inequity in addictions and their treatment are ubiquitous threats to health and society; a global pandemic and large social movements (e.g., #BlackLivesMatter) have highlighted negative impacts of racism and discrimination for addictions and centered “structures” (e.g., policies and systems like education, housing, criminal justice, and healthcare which reinforce inequality) as the root cause of inequities, though these are grossly understudied. A new generation of addictions health services scholars trained in traditional health services and addictions content/methodology, as well as anti-racism and fields that can alter structures that reinforce inequity (e.g., policy and implementation science), is needed to address equity challenges rooted in structures. The University of Washington (UW) is a leader in addictions research, anti-racist pedagogy and research methods, policy, and implementation science and well-positioned to address the training needs of next- generation addictions scholars; thus, the UW’s Department of Health Systems and Population and Division of General Internal Medicine seek NIDA funding to found the Training in Equity and Structural Solutions in Addictions (TESSA) to prepare 11 pre- and post-doctoral scholars to be future leaders in structural solutions to inequity in addictions and their treatment via a specialized curriculum, mentored research opportunities, experience developing research career training plans, and iterative evaluation with support from both internal and external expert advisory committees.
PROJECT_TERMS: addiction;Equity;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Equity and Structural Solutions in Addictions (TESSA)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Career Development Education and Training Study Section[NIDA-S-K]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The NU-THRIVE T32 program will train postdoctoral fellows in research methods in HIV, mental health, and SGM health across the Translational Science Spectrum. Fellows will engage in a rigorous training program in which they will: 1) specialize and gain depth of knowledge in two Translational Science Skill Domains (i.e., Quantitative Methods, Qualitative Methods, Interventions & Trials, Implementation Science) through mentored research with a primary and secondary mentor; and 2) gain breadth of knowledge in all four domains through a formal training curriculum. NU-THRIVE will place fellows at the forefront of translational science in HIV and SGM health, with the ultimate goal of more rapidly moving basic science discoveries to efficacious interventions and onward toward implementation.
PROJECT_TERMS: gender minority health;HIV;Sexual and Gender Minorities;Training Programs;Translational Research
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Translational Science, HIV, and Sexual and Gender Minority Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 20 million Americans have evidence for advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD), and more than 570,000 patients have kidney failure (end-stage kidney disease [ESKD]), the latter accounting for 7% of Medicare expenditures, approximately $35 billion. African American CKD patients in the United States are four times more likely than white patients to progress to ESRD, and variants in a single gene (APOL1) explain much of this increased risk. We propose to use cell biology, live-cell imaging, and proteomic data analysis tools to determine how the variants change APOL1’s function to cause kidney diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT This mid-career investigator award in patient-oriented research will help establish the candidate’s mentorship and career development, allowing the candidate to investigate prodromal markers of neurodegeneration in age-related dementing disorders characterized by alpha-synuclein pathology. There is a need to identify prodromal states before patients have clinical symptoms of dementia and parkinsonism, ensuring greater likelihood that clinical interventions will modify disease progression. This research will provide important information in developing new quantitative measurements of degeneration in patients with prodromal, and clinically manifest, Lewy Body disorders, while allowing the candidate time to foster the development of mentees pursuing patient-oriented research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is the 6th leading cause of death in the United States and is expect to triple by 2050. Individuals with Alzheimer’s disease suffer from sleep disturbances and sleep disorders are associated with an increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease. Since sleep/wake cycles are a dynamic interplay between metabolism and neuronal activity, the goal of this project is to understand how changes in metabolism impact the relationship between sleep and Alzheimer’s disease and whether metabolic dysfunction is a novel therapeutic target for treating Alzheimer’s disease and sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Due to recent advances in imaging technologies, we can “see” brain in action. My dissertation project is aimed at understanding the signals generated by one of the most widely used brain imaging technologies – functional magnetic resonance imaging – in terms of the underlying microscopic activity of brain’s neurons and communication between neurons and cerebral blood vessels. This scientific knowledge will contribute to understanding of mechanisms regulating cerebral blood flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regeneration of kidney cells is an important part of recovery from many types of kidney injury but how regeneration is controlled is poorly understood. This project will study how Pax2 and Pax8, two similar proteins that are produced in kidney cells as they regenerate, control recovery after kidney injury. This project will generate a new understanding of Pax2 and Pax8 function that will help develop new therapies for kidney injury and chronic kidney disease and will provide the principle investigator with training and mentorship needed to establish an independent research career studying kidney regeneration.

PHR: This project will advance understanding how to breach antibiotic permeability barriers of Gram- negative pathogens during infections. Functional interactions between active efflux of antibiotics and their permeation across bacterial and host membranes will be analyzed using both empirical and computational approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative Violence alters the life course of far too many adolescents and disproportionately impacts minoritized youth in neighborhoods burdened by structural inequities and high rates of community violence. Through a community- partnered cluster-randomized trial, we propose to refine and evaluate Forging Hopeful Futures, a youth empowerment intervention that combines economic justice content from job readiness training, racial and gender justice content from gender-transformative programming, and leadership building as a novel multi-level violence prevention intervention. Results expected to emerge from this rigorous effectiveness and implementation evaluation will expand our repertoire of effective interventions to address racial, and gender, and economic inequities and reduce youth violence.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE-22-005 Forging Hopeful Futures: A Racial and Gender-Justice Program to Reduce Youth Violence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative This application is aimed at comparing a time-limited multicomponent linkage and treatment approach called “Maintaining Independence and Sobriety through Systems Integration, Outreach, and Networking (MISSION) to a linkage only Peer Support Intervention specifically for individuals with co-occurring substance use and mental health disorders given that they often have poor treatment engagement and other behavioral health outcomes. This study will include a 3-year, Hybrid Type 1 Randomized Controlled Trial among 208 patients that will also examine treatment mechanisms and sustainability.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Supporting Treatment Access and Recovery through Linkage and Support (STAR-LS)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: CD8+ T lymphocytes are essential players in mounting protective cellular immune responses against pathogenic antigens and malignantly transformed cells. The transcription factor Tcf1 has critical roles in regulating the recall response by memory CD8+ T cells and enhancing functional restoration of exhausted CD8+ T cells. The proposed studies will provide rationales for utilizing Tcf1 and its downstream pathways to promote recall response and rectify T cell exhaustion to improve viral and cancer immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative Rigorous evaluation of the KATR linkage strategy has the potential to inform and enhance public health policy, such as enhancing state ATR programs to address SUD health disparities experienced by individuals in underserved areas with incomes at or below the 200% poverty level, individuals with prior criminal-justice involvement, veterans, and pregnant and parenting populations, with illicit SUD, which are all the unique characteristics of the KATR study population. As individuals with illicit SUD and these specific demographic characteristics are not unique to the geographic region of Kentucky, we believe that, if results are significant, they may be generalizable to populations with those characteristics in other states. One aspect of the KATR linkage strategy evaluation that will be crucial is determining RSS utilization and RSS combinations that are associated with long-term recovery capital and recovery maintenance success.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-22-010 Evaluation of Kentucky Access to Recovery Linkage Strategy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: This study will examine, via a cluster-randomized controlled trial in 20 neighborhoods with concentrated disadvantage in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, the effectiveness of a community resiliency collective efficacy intervention. Using a community-partnered participatory approach, this study will assess an innovative approach to address community violence by engaging community members in dialogue on child and youth thriving and consensus organizing to build collective efficacy. This will be the first rigorous evaluation of a community-designed, community-centered collective efficacy intervention intended to increase individual and neighborhood levels of collective efficacy, protective factors that are expected to reduce multiple forms of violence.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE22-013 A community-centered collective efficacy intervention for prevention of community violence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Pharmacological and genetic evidence in three Alzheimer's disease (AD) mouse models suggests that the enzyme neutral sphingomyelinase 2 (nSMase2) plays a significant role in the etiology of the disease, however there are no inhibitors to test this hypothesis in clinical trials. Utilizing a high- throughput screening campaign we identified DPTIP, the first nM human nSMase inhibitor; however DPTIP has a short half- life (t1/2< 0.5h) and poor oral availability (F<5%) hampering its clinical use, and chemical modifications (~200 analogs synthesized by our group) have not led to substantial improvements. Given its significant clinical potential, we propose to synthesize and evaluate dendrimer nanoparticle conjugated-DPTIP for their ability to deliver DPTIP to brain and provide efficacy and safety in two established mouse models of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Multifaceted strategies are needed to stem the tide of the drug overdose crisis, linking vulnerable individuals to recovery resources and helping them to build recovery capital. In this Hybrid Type 1 effectiveness-implementation trial implementing peer recovery coaches both in-person and via telemedicine at a large, urban level 1 trauma center, investigators will study the process of peer recovery coach implementation and patient- and community-oriented outcomes resulting from the program. Results will inform other EDs considering their own peer recovery coach program, including rapidly scalable telemedicine- based programs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE-22-010 Linking Individuals Needing Care for Substance Use Disorders in Urban Emergency Departments to Peer coaches (LINCS UP)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The elderly are more susceptible to an episode of acute kidney injury and subsequent development of chronic kidney disease. The purpose of this study is to explore the mechanisms underlying the decreased repair response in aging kidney after injury with a specific focus on the role of tubular senescence and decreased proliferative capacity as a possible driver of failed repair. Gaining insight into the cause for lack of reparative capacity in the aging kidney will point the way towards new therapeutic targets and interventions for this critically important clinical problem. !

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Artemisinin-based combination therapies are the primary treatment for malaria, but rapidly evolving resistance and poor drug exposure in children with and without HIV threatens treatment efficacy. A deeper understanding of parasite and drug dynamics is needed to truly optimize treatment regimens. This proposal will leverage clinical samples from a randomized PK/PD study in HIV-uninfected and HIV-infected children to study parasite dynamics after treatment, the relationship between drug exposure and drug resistance, and the impact of HIV infection on these parameters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVENCE) Conjunctivitis results in significant economic burden worldwide and can result in long-term vision impairment and severe systemic complications in children. This project takes advantage of international collaborations and recent advances in genomic technologies to enhance our understanding of conjunctivitis epidemics globally by identifying the pathogens involved, characterizing the evolution of pathogen genomes across time and space, and defining the immune responses to these infections. The results of this study will improve prevention methods and help to curtail spread, thus reducing the burden on cost and human ocular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Craniofacial bone defects occur due to trauma, congenital abnormalities, and during the course of surgical treatments for stroke and cancer. Clinically-available technologies for craniofacial reconstruction are non- regenerative while current tissue engineering efforts rely on biomaterials with poor mechanical strength and in vitro expansion of stem cells that limit surgical practicality. The proposed research will develop an innovative composite biomaterial that can be used off-the-shelf, that passively promote implant integration and structural stability, and that actively accelerates biological processes that improve bone regeneration.

Thoughtful approaches that combine the best of research training alongside close understanding of clinical issues can produce a cadre of investigators who are well-equipped to advance research in this critical area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: We will leverage our institution’s multi-disciplinary and experienced investigator base, our prior success in leading collaborative and single-site randomized clinical trials (RCTs) and mechanistic studies, and our access to a large population of urban, disadvantaged, and largely minority youth with asthma to create the District of Columbia’s Childhood Asthma in Urban Settings Clinical Research Center (DC CAUSE-CRC). It will implement network-wide research studies and conduct a highly innovative, pilot, mechanistic, non-therapeutic RCT of single-dose anti-IgE therapy (omalizumab) in the fall season in highly exacerbation-prone urban children (Omalizumab Before Onset of Exacerbations - OBOE). Over three fall seasons, OBOE will randomize at least 100 youth aged 6-17 years with persistent asthma, high levels of allergy, and a recent asthma exacerbation to omalizumab or placebo during a fall upper respiratory infection and will collect nasal secretions and blood during those infections to characterize the interaction between the host’s and microbiome’s response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is aimed to determine if a systems geroscience approach can be leveraged to identify potential synergy among age-delaying strategies, which when given alone, can delay pathology and symptoms in mouse models of AD. As such, we will use several approaches to characterize established and emerging strategies on major aging pillars, including proteostasis, inflammation, metabolism, and macromolecular damage in relevant brain regions, along with omics datasets to build a systems view of aging pillars and AD. Based upon these data, we will use our systems approach to predict possible synergistic effects in silico among these strategies and this model will then be validated in vivo as compared to controls and each intervention alone, thereby demonstrating the potential utility of systems geroscience to identify novel treatment strategies for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Public Health Relevancy Statement/Project Narrative Lifestyle and career changes in the Western world have lead to couples putting off childbearing until later in life. Not only is time to conception delayed in older men, but it is increasingly clear that children of older men are at increased risk for certain neurodevelopmental diseases. Here, we propose to thorouhgly investigate the effects of advanced age on the male reproductive tract, focusing not only on the testis but also on understudied male reproductive tissues of relevance to fertility including the epididymis and seminal vesicle. We will also investigate changes in behavior and metabolism in offspring of older males, and will characterize the changes in the sperm epigenome that might explain these changes. These studies will be of great importance for understanding how male reproductive function changes with age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Antibodies are invaluable biotechnology tools for diagnosing and treating human diseases; they have been used to detect drugs, toxins, hormones, or pathogens; perform tissue typing; suppress organ transplant rejection; and therapeutically treat viral infections, cancer, and autoimmune diseases. In this project, we will develop a pipeline to replace a large portion of costly, time-consuming experimental work required today in antibody drug discovery with a software pipeline based on improvement in and integration of protein structure prediction, protein-protein docking and protein engineering tools we currently provide to the market. Our proposed pipeline will be poised to accelerate antibody drug development and reduce costs of antibody drug discovery by 80 – 90%, literally revolutionizing the way antibody discovery and development is performed by biotech and pharmaceutical companies and third-party contract research organizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We anticipate that our novel phage-based preparation (ShigActive™) will reduce the risk of diseases due to consuming foods or water contaminated with Shigella spp. This approach is expected to have a significant positive public health impact in reducing worldwide morbidity and mortality due to Shigella infections of which there are ~125 million worldwide cases of shigellosis and ~14,000 deaths annually, the majority in children under the age of 5. Moreover, success of our studies is likely to lead to the development of other phage-based products for many other gastrointestinal diseases of bacterial etiology, including those having epidemic potential (e.g., cholera).

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Failure of Treg cell function in suppressing TH2 responses correlates with the onset and progression of allergic airway disease. In this application, we aim to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms by which Treg cells integrate immune signaling and cellular metabolism to ensure Treg cell function in preventing allergic airway inflammation. Insights gained from this application may manifest therapeutic opportunities for the treatment of allergic airway disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human microbiome is known to regulate host immune system function, but the mechanisms underlying this relationship are incompletely understood. This proposal will identify causal associations between microbial derived metabolites and human immune system function in health, autoimmunity, allergy, and infectious disease. Uncovering these host-microbiome circuits may inform the development of therapeutics to treat immune-mediated disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is ample evidence that parental substance use is a significant risk factor for adolescent substance use and there are a number of potential parenting-related mediators which explain this relationship. This study will advance our understanding of the intergenerational transmission of substance use through novel methodological developments which support the use of multiple informant data in statistical mediation analyses. Findings have the potential to contribute to developmental theory as well as family-based preventive interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Crisis stabilization centers (CSCs) provide a less costly and more comfortable alternative to Emergency Department care for individuals with acute suicidal crises. With demand for crisis alternatives growing, effective interventions designed and tested for CSCs are urgently needed to realize their life-saving potential. This study adapts and tests the effectiveness of a crisis recovery and follow-up intervention that seeks to reduce suicide risk by strengthening interpersonal connections.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular surgery is expected to see a workforce shortfall in the future. This T35 program will expose medical students to vascular surgery and the research that informs it. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of patients with neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) ultimately die from metastatic disease due to the lack of effective therapies, necessitating a better understanding of mechanisms promoting NET progression and metastasis to guide the development of improved targeted treatments. Proposed studies test our hypothesis that the RABL6A-PP2A pathway is a critical driver of NET progression (including metastasis) and response to targeted therapies. This work addresses a major gap in NET research, builds upon an emerging anticancer strategy of pharmacological reactivation of PP2A, and may have broad cancer relevance beyond NETs given the importance of RABL6A and PP2A in other tumor types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Nonmelanoma skin cancer, which includes squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), is the most common cancer diagnosed in the United States. SCC usually develop from premalignant precursors, providing an opportunity for intervention to prevent malignant disease and metastatic progression. This research will delineate aberrant prosurvival signaling pathways in skin cancer cells in order to develop candidate agents to disrupt this signaling. Successful completion of this work is anticipated to lead to novel approaches for the prevention and treatment of skin cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative The high prevalence of alcohol use disorders (AUD) and other mental disorders causes severe socioeconomic stress for patients, families, and society. Despite identifying many genetic risk factors from human studies, effective therapeutics are limited due to a lack of understanding of the AUD pathophysiology. This proposal aims to understand neuroimmune interactions in a human neural model and examine how ethanol and individual (poly)genetic background affects these interactions; therefore, results derived from this study will guide the development of novel therapeutics for AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal cord injury is a leading cause of paralysis in the United States with limited treatment options. Astrocytes influence injury outcome after spinal cord injury and therefore present an attractive cellular target for repair strategies. This proposed research will determine location specific functions of reactive astrocytes in the injured spinal cord to provide the basis for an astrocyte-targeted approach to promote neural recovery and reduce human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE USC’s “Training for the Multiscale and Multimodal Analysis of Biomarkers in Alzheimer’s Disease” (AD) will focus on preparing postdoctoral investigators for independent research careers by integrating four areas of methodologies to illuminate various aspects of biomarkers in AD at differing scales: molecular and cellular methods, imaging tools and informatics, quantitative methods for clinical trials research, and large-scale population analyses. Trainees will complete coursework and career development activities such as lab rotations, seminars, instruction for problem solving, communication, time management, and leadership skills, as well as career guidance, including instruction and training in grant writing, in order to apply successfully for future fellowships and career development and independent research support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Repeated binge drinking is associated with elevated systolic blood pressure, which confronts more than half of mid-life adults in the United States. This K99/R00 application proposes training and research to develop a research strategy that integrates vascular physiology, physical therapies, and alcohol-related health. This will address the gaps in knowledge of mechanisms underlying alcohol-attributable contribution to elevated blood pressure and help identify/develop therapeutic approaches to decrease the burden of hypertension in mid-life adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a heterogeneous group of similar clinical syndromes often presenting with impairments in social cognition, executive function, or language that is caused by either tauopathies or TDP-43 proteinopathies part of the frontotemporal lobar degeneration spectrum. To determine whether tau and TDP-43 pathology cause distinct patterns of neurodegeneration currently elusive to studies of clinically similar FTD patients, this project proposes to use new quantitative techniques to determine the relative loss of neural microcircuits within a comparative cortical layer framework of FTD patients. The innovative study of laminar microcircuits will not only advance our understanding of disease-specific patterns of selective vulnerability, mechanisms of progression, and the neural substrates of cognitive impairment in FTD, the cellular changes to laminar architecture will aid the discovery of anatomically-grounded diagnostic markers and therapeutic targets urgently needed in the FTD spectrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Therapeutic use of CRISPR/Cas is currently limited by the lack of safe and effective delivery carriers that can mediate gene editing in vivo to targeted tissues and cells. In this grant, we study recently developed Selective ORgan Targeting (SORT) lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) that can mediate tissue-specific gene editing in the liver, lung, and spleen. Outcomes of this work will include elucidating the fundamental mechanisms how and why SORT LNPs target extrahepatic tissues, determining how SORT molecules control efficacy and tolerability for improved gene editing, quantifying cell-type gene editing specificity to expand targeted gene editing, and ultimately opening new avenues for CRISPR/Cas-based correction of genetic diseases by developing efficacious, safe, and translatable nanoparticle carriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with hearing impairment and central neurological disorders have difficulty understanding speech and processing other complex sounds in dynamic, noisy environments. This study seeks to understand how the auditory cortex represents important sensory information as individuals move through the world, changing the location and overlap of sounds arriving at their ears. These experiments will provide insight into basic function of the healthy brain that can inform treatment of hearing disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will provide definitive evidence about whether treating prenatal insomnia with digital cognitive behavior therapy for insomnia prevents depression during the perinatal period (i.e., pregnancy and the postpartum period). Currently, there are few intervention options for preventing perinatal depression, none focus on women with prenatal insomnia, and the accessibility of existing interventions is limited. Several attributes of our approach will facilitate its broad dissemination, including focusing on the low stigma target of insomnia and using a scalable intervention, with significant public health impact for reducing the burden of perinatal depression for mothers, children, families, and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The complex biology of aging, characterized by a progressive loss of cellular and physiological function, is particularly evident in hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) where aging results in a reduced capacity to self-renew and differentiate into lymphoid lineages. We propose a two-pronged approach for reversing HSC aging via cellular reprogramming, involving 1) profiling molecular signatures of aging in HSCs at single cell resolution to both develop metrics for aging and nominate transcription factors (TFs) involved in aging and self-renewal and 2) screening of TFs nominated by single-cell RNA-sequencing for restoration of HSC quiescence, self-renewal, lymphoid/myeloid balance, and systemic effects in an in vivo mouse aging model. Novel TFs will be characterized for their mechanism in renewing HSCs and restoring other downstream lineages in the bone marrow, and the framework presented will provide a generalizable approach for understanding stem cell aging and discovering new therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative We have identified a novel regulator of brain aging, neural network and microglial function that may protect against memory loss and the pathology of Alzheimer's disease. This proposal explores the role of REST in the dysfunction of neurons and microglia in Alzheimer's disease using precisely targeted gene knockout mice and new REST-activating drugs. Using these approaches, we will attempt to define basic mechanisms that underlie memory loss in Alzheimer's disease with potentially important therapeutic implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Aging is a complex process involving many physiological, anatomic, metabolic, cellular, and molecular changes. We have identified a molecular change that appears to track the number of times that a cell lineage has divided. We propose to explore the mechanistic underpinnings of this process, and to develop this finding into a molecular clock.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE With the decline in pharmaceutical company interest in common and morbid women’s health indications, our current proposal to identify drugs that block the functions of kinases (a druggable class of proteins in our genomes), as novel treatments for endometriosis will address an NICHD mandate of the Gynecologic Health and Disease Branch to identify and develop novel non-hormonal therapeutic agents for treatment of gynecologic pain syndromes. Our collective genetic validation, cell biology, and drug discovery experiences will bring novel drug-like inhibitors to targeted patient populations of women seeking new alternatives to control endometriosis as stand-alone therapies or as sequential treatment during the required hiatus following hormone antagonists. Our multidisciplinary team of reproductive biologists, medicinal chemists, pharmacologists, immunologists, entrepreneurs, and clinicians will work together to identify new classes of therapeutics to target unique endometriosis-relevant kinase pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite great advancement in immunotherapy for melanoma, such as adoptive cell transfer therapy and checkpoint blockade, the clinical outcomes remain less satisfactory due to a variety of factors that lessen antitumor efficacy. By investigating the role and mechanism of a safe attenuated Brucella melitensis mutant producing a tryptophan metabolite in modulating the suppressive tumor microenvironment and immunotherapy resistance, the proposed research will define and establish this microbe as a novel immunomodulatory agent that can be exploited to significantly improve current melanoma immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defining the lifetime risk of Chlamydia trachomatis in men and characteristics associated with infection in the US population will provide critical information to either support or change current chlamydia screening guidelines. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative To lessen the negative impact of medically refractory epilepsy in children, a new pre-surgical noninvasive biomarker that identifies reliably the area of the brain that generates the epileptic seizures is essential. The proposed experiments are relevant to public health because they may lead to a significant improvement of the presurgical evaluation procedure and postsurgical outcome of pediatric patients with refractory epilepsy. The project is relevant to NINDS’s mission because the resulting findings could significantly improve the quality of life in children with epilepsy, one of the most common pediatric neurological disorders, which has a major impact on children’s development and may significantly affect their adult life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed predoctoral training program is to prepare the next generation of HIV researchers to improve health equity and HIV prevention, treatment and care outcomes by: (1) developing theoretical competency in social-structural, intersectional and critical health equity approaches to HIV; (2) using these theoretical approaches to design and conduct rigorous research; (3) formulating strategic interventions grounded in social-structural and intersectional approaches; and (4) engaging equitably with the intersectionally diverse communities disproportionately affected by HIV, throughout all stages of research and intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research to develop the Functional and Fine-Mapping Approach to Improve Responsible Risk-modeling of Polygenic Risk Scores (‘FFAIRR-PRS’) approach will address key gaps in the current ability to deliver polygenic scores – new tools for genetic risk assessment – accurately to diverse populations, and reflects deep commitment to the overall goals of the NHGRI consortium. First, we propose to harmonize and aggregate individual-level data from >50,000 individuals of South Asian ancestry – prioritized on the basis of marked under-representation in studies to date – within the ANVIL data ecosystem, developing and sharing analytic workflows and new statistical genetics approaches. Second, using a ‘diversity-first’ approach, we propose to validate the FFAIR-PRS approach for enhanced polygenic score development, and build integrated and calibrated absolute risk estimators to facilitate ultimate clinical adoption via other ongoing research efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research takes novel approaches to elucidating the fundamental behaviors and roles of chromosomes, which are the repositories of our genetic material. We study meiosis, aberrancies of which confer infertility and birth defects; we study mammalian chromosome organization and segregation, defects in which underlie cancer; and we study E.coli, including L-forms, a lifestyle that bacteria use to evade antibiotics. Our research will therefore have a broad impact on many fundamental issues that directly impact human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Opioids are a class of drugs that act on neuromodulatory receptors throughout the brain and the highly addictive nature of opioids has continued to drive the ongoing opioid epidemic in the U.S. Using computational modeling and biological models, we test the concept that the order of neuromodulation impacts the net effect of opposing neuromodulators. Our findings may be relevant when considering the neurobiological basis of several behavioral phenomena related to opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Caloric restriction – a behavioral intervention that prolongs lifespan in model organisms – has beneficial metabolic effects in humans including weight loss and improvement in blood pressure and lipid levels. Intermittent fasting has emerged as a popular alternative to caloric restriction as it does not require daily adherence to a dietary protocol, but whether the benefits of fasting protocols are dependent on weight loss is not known. In this study we will investigate the metabolic effects of fasting and evaluate whether these effects, including negative effects on bone metabolism, are independent of weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: A delayed first childbirth, which is common in American women, is associated with increased breast cancer risk, but it is unclear whether this increased risk is caused by pregnancy or lactation or both. We hypothesize that lactation in women with a delayed childbirth instigates cancer formation from preexistent precancerous lesions, more common in older women than in younger women. This hypothesis, if proven, has important implications for women with a delayed childbirth and may help them make an informed decision regarding whether they choose to breastfeed or not, or just for a short amount of time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal aims to understand how the properties of microtubules are locally regulated in neurons, and how this regulation influences the transport and delivery of cargo to synapses. It does so by investigating the function of an immobile kinesin, VAB-8/KIF26, which we recently identified as a local cytoskeletal regulator in C.elegans. The results are expected to increase our fundamental understanding of neuronal microtubules and axonal transport, which is important given their critical roles in neuronal health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the past several decades, dialysis has been the prevailing treatment paradigm among advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients who are ineligible for or unlikely to receive kidney transplantation. As dialysis may not offer survival benefit nor improved quality of life among certain dialysis subgroups including elderly and multi-morbid patients, there has been growing interest in conservative dialysis-free management as an alternative patient-centered treatment strategy. In this proposal, we will compare hard outcomes and patient- centered endpoints among patients receiving conservative management vs. dialysis transition, and we will develop clinical prediction models that will identify which patients will most benefit from conservative dialysis- free treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Integrins, the principal extracellular matrix (ECM) receptor of the cell, have been implicated in every step of tumor development including tumor initiation, progression, and metastasis. Integrin-targeted drugs have classically focused on antagonizing the integrin extracellular domain, thus preventing ECM:integrin binding. Based on our preliminary data, our central hypothesis posits that these ectodomain-targeted drugs neglect constitutive signaling from the integrin cytoplasmic tail and thus future drug development strategies should focus on this ligand-independent signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Normal aging is associated with deficits in cognition that correlate with myelin damage and inflammation and ADRD-like pathology, such as accumulation of pathological Tau and A-Beta. Our recent work with our monkey models of aging and cortical injury demonstrated the mesenchymal stem cell (MSC)-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) are highly efficacious in facilitating recovery and reducing inflammation, myelin damage and tau and A-Beta. In the current study, we will test whether administration of MSC-EVs in aged monkeys will enhance cognitive performance and reduce age-related markers of inflammation, myelin damage and ADRD-like pathology in blood and CSF and post-mortem brain tissue. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma multiforme (GB) is the most common and deadly form of adult primary brain cancer with a current median survival of just over one year. This research focuses on the study and evaluation of the potential pathologic role of circulating glioma cells (CGCs) and the characteristics and signaling mechanism(s) which generate and sustain this subpopulation. Results of these studies will ultimately benefit public health by potentially improving our understanding of glioma tumor biology, mechanisms of recurrence, and evaluating novel therapeutic approaches against these brain tumors and cancers in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Experience-dependent refinement and efficient memory storage in CNS circuits is thought to require homeostatic forms of plasticity, such as synaptic scaling and intrinsic plasticity, that stabilize overall neuronal activity by endowing individual neurons with a 'firing rate set point'. Here we will investigate the mechanisms and function of these set points, and ask how their loss impacts critical features of circuit function including memory stability. These studies will enhance our understanding of neurological disorders that arise from aberrant circuit excitability, and will provide a new avenue of investigation into disorders (such as PTSD) that arise from excessive generalization during aversive learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Inherited retinal degenerative diseases and age-related macular degeneration are debilitating visual disorders for which there are currently no curative treatments. Thyroid hormone signaling regulates cell proliferation, differentiation, and metabolism, and has been associated with cone photoreceptor viability. This study will investigate thyroid hormone signaling activity in degenerating cones/retinas as well as the mechanism(s) underlying thyroid hormone signaling-induced cone death, and determine whether suppressing thyroid hormone signaling locally in the retina represents a strategy for cone protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with a rare premature aging disease accumulate a protein called prelamin A that is only transiently expressed in non-affected people. In this project, we will use a unique mouse model that accumulates prelamin A to determine how it contributes to osteoporosis and blood vessel defects, conditions that frequently occur in older individuals. We will determine the molecular mechanisms by which prelamin A alters cells and if it actually accumulates in tissues during normal aging, which would provide a new insight into the aging process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Numerous recent studies have consistently shown that likely no two cells in the human body have the exact same genomes, a phenomenon called somatic mosaicism. Mosaicism can be studied using various approaches, but the study of mutations directly in the cell promises a comprehensive characterization of mosaicism in any tissue. However, all existing methods have significant limitations for studying the genome in a cell. Here we propose to benchmark and test new approaches for comprehensive, accurate, and high-throughput analyses of the genomes of single cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is one of the major health problems facing today’s society and projected to afflict nearly 1 in 3 people by year 2050. It is therefore critical to improve our understanding of the molecular mechanisms driving the increasing prevalence of T2DM which can lead to the development of novel therapeutic and preventative approaches. Thus the underlying goals of this proposal are to uncover novel molecular mechanisms responsible for the regulation of pancreatic β-cell function in people exposed to enviromental stressors associated with increased risk of T2DM such as circadian rhythms disruptions and diet induced obesity.

ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to mechanistically develop and characterize age-appropriate dose-flexible pediatric co- delivery (combination) system of lamivudine and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate by selective laser sintering 3D printing method. It is expected that the quality, stability, palatability (human), pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic (safety and efficacy) profiles of dose-flexible pediatric co-delivery systems would be similar to commercial tablet formulations (Epivir, Viread® or CimduoTM), which are non-flexible. The pediatric delivery systems will meet FDA and USP requirements for eventual deployment in hospitals for pediatric use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to cues associated with methamphetamine use can trigger relapse in recovering methamphetamine users, even after long periods of abstinence. To understand this persistent vulnerability, we study the nucleus accumbens, a key brain region for motivation and addiction, in a rat model of craving and relapse. Our studies will be the first to test the role of specific cell types in the nucleus accumbens and specific glutamate inputs to these cells in the synaptic plasticity that maintains high levels of methamphetamine craving during protracted withdrawal from methamphetamine self-administration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Depression is a major public health problem; however, our understanding of and treatment for this  prevalent disorder remain lacking. Using an integration of state-of-the-art molecular and  functional imaging techniques in conjunction with a longitudinal design, the main goals of this  research are to (1) attain a better mechanistic understanding of MDD and anhedonia by focusing on a  novel target (Nociceptin/ Orphanin FQ receptors) expected to yield molecular abnormalities  associated with anhedonic phenotypes and stress- induced inflammatory abnormalities and (2)  identify abnormalities that map disease course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sustained viral infections, including infections with either prolonged or life-long viral replication, represent a major health problem worldwide. Importantly, the capacity of a virus to persist and cause disease is tightly related to the power and quality of the host immune response. We have identified two new ways in which CD8 T cells are regulated by adipose tissue after a viral infection and propose to characterize these novel immune- regulatory pathways and the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Immunotherapy (promoting an anti-tumor immune response) has demonstrated successful and exciting results in certain cancers, but not in patients with glioblastoma, a malignant brain tumor. Additionally, the composition of the gut microbiome has been shown to influence the efficacy of immunotherapy. Therefore, this proposal seeks to identify optimal microbial gut compositions to rescue resistance to immunotherapy for patients with glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Ng) is an urgent public health threat, with both infection rates and antibiotic-resistance rising globally. An approved vaccine specifically for Ng does not yet exist, and treatment with extended-spectrum cephalosporins is the only reliable treatment remaining. Successful completion of this application will generate a new SL vaccine to prevent Ng infection, designed for robust Th1 immune responses and mucosal immunity, administered easily, and thermostable for rapid, global distribution.
