IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The research proposed here will contribute to an understanding of the causes major depressive disorder, the commonest psychiatric disorder and a leading cause of disability throughout the world. The proposal will improve our ability to diagnose depression from electronic health records, generate insights into the genetic architecture of depression, separating out specific from non-specific genetic risk factors, and will identify, from the analysis of sequencing data, genes that are involved in the etiology of the disorder. The research will provide new insights into disease, and well enable the development of more effective therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Mutations in the gene encoding the protein tau cause frontotemporal dementia and/or increase the risk of developing Alzheimer’s dementia. Tau plays important roles in brain cells (neurons) regulating the cytoskeleton, which is essential for formation and maintenance of the communication network that underlies neuronal function. We have discovered a novel neuroprotective pathway involving two proteins whose gene mutations contribute to frontotemporal dementia and Parkinson’s-related dementia. This proposal focuses upon understanding the mechanism(s) and neuroprotective potential of this pathway in patient-derived neuronal cells and a mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE This multidisciplinary project combines novel brain-penetrant and translatable PPAR agonists (KD3010, T3D- 959) and conditional cre/lox tools to manipulate PPAR function to test the role of brain PPARδ receptors in compulsive-like AUD phenotypes. Whole-body and brain-restricted transgenic approaches will specifically test the role of brain PPAR receptors in voluntary and aversion-resistant alcohol use as well as withdrawal- associated negative emotional behaviors; the effects of agonists and conditional knockouts on PPAR target gene expression will be studied with regional specificity. Collectively, the resulting data and novel tools for this understudied PPARδ isotype will lay the groundwork for cell type- and anatomically-specific mechanistic studies and may translate to interventions for people affected by AUD and potentially other forms of addiction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: TITLE: The eXtraordinarY Babies Study - Natural History of Health and Neurodevelopment in Children with Sex Chromosome Trisomy NARRATIVE: Sex Chromosome Trisomies (SCT), including Klinefelter (XXY), Trisomy X (XXX), and XYY syndromes, are the most common chromosomal abnormalities, occurring in 1 out of every 400 births or over 10,000 births per year in the US. The prenatal diag- nosis rate of SCT has been increasing, and children born with SCT have a significantly increased risk for: (1) neurodevelopmen- tal problems including developmental delays, speech-language disorders, learning disabilities, ADHD, autism spectrum disor- ders (ASD), and (2) medical comorbidities including testicular/ovarian failure, disorders of insulin resistance, seizures, congeni- tal malformations, and other medical problems. The eXtraordinarY Babies Study will prospectively describe the natural history of children with a prenatal diagnosis of SCT through 7-8 years of age, building on data collected from a group of 260 infants with SCT recruited during the first funding cycle who were comprehensively evaluated from infancy to 3-4 years of age with a focus on identifying developmental and hormonal predictors of neurodevelopmental and health outcomes. Results will lead to a comprehensive understanding of the natural history and variability in SCT conditions, will identify targets for interven- tions, and will inform clinical care and genetic counseling guidelines for the increasing number of prenatal and early childhood diagnoses of SCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Psychiatric disorders are among the most common illnesses across the lifespan and highlight the importance of cognitive and mental health in youth development. In this project, we will develop sophisticated analytical tools with high-density EEG to discover neural circuits associated with behavioral phenotypes spanning multiple psychiatric disorders for an improved understanding of psychopathology. Successful outcomes of the project will produce translatable biomarkers crossing current diagnostic boundaries and provide a new avenue for functional connectivity-based transdiagnostic study of psychopathology, thereby laying the foundation for the development of personalized therapeutics toward improved cognitive function and mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Prostate cancer develops in a microenvironment where growth and progression are governed by complex and reciprocal interactions between tumor cells and surrounding stromal elements. The proposed studies aim to define the functional and mechanistic roles of monoamine oxidase B, a novel therapeutic target in prostate cancer stromal fibroblasts, and its downstream effectors in reprogramming prostate cancer stroma and mediating epithelial-stromal crosstalk promoting prostate cancer. Our studies will provide new fundamental knowledge of the molecular basis of prostate cancer development and progression in the context of its microenvironment, laying the foundations for new single or combination therapies capable of rapid clinical translation to treat prostate cancer, especially lethal castration-resistant and neuroendocrine prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid-related overdose death is the single largest cause of accidental death in the United States, and individuals being released from incarceration are at particular risk, with some studies showing their risk of death in the weeks immediately after release is as much as 129 times that of the general population. In January 2020 the Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department began giving people being released from jail naloxone, a medication which can be used to ‘reverse’ overdose, in order to try and reduce overdose deaths among people being released and also in the communities they return to after release. This study will use a range of methods to examine whether the program is effective at getting naloxone to where it is most needed, and whether it reduces deaths among people being released and in the communities to which they return.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACT STATEMENT In this study, we will examine the efficacy of Safe South Africa, a behavioral intervention that is developmentally- and gender-tailored to prevent human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and intimate partner violence (IPV) among adolescent boys. South Africa faces some of the highest global rates of HIV and IPV with sustained high incidence of HIV and alarming rates of IPV among adolescents and thus, is an ideal site to advance prevention science to tackle these urgent public health priorities. Testing the efficacy of an integrated intervention to prevent HIV risk behavior and IPV for adolescent boys can support optimal health for young people, their future partners, and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major therapeutic gap exists in relapsed/refractory diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) – a disease against which immunotherapies have shown significant progress; however, the impact of the DLBCL immune environment on immunotherapy response is not known, and knowledge regarding the influence of lymphoma- intrinsic oncogenic pathways on shaping the DLBCL immune environment is lacking. To fill these gaps in knowledge, we have characterized immune landscapes associated with DLBCL using transcriptional profiling and have uncovered several recurrent mutations that appear to play key roles in sculpting the immune environment in this disease, which will be mechanistically characterized in this proposal. Furthermore, having established the existence of unique DLBCL immune environments, we will develop a DLBCL “immune score” that may predict responsiveness to immunotherapies including PD-1 blockade and CAR T cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Motor neuron diseases including Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) involve loss of axons, including the essential connections between the spinal cord and muscles. Lactate metabolism plays an important role in nervous system health. We will explore findings that implicate abnormalities in lactate pathways in motor axon function and in progression of ALS disease symptoms, with a goal of developing new treatments for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorders (AUDs) represent a leading health issue that causes an enormous number of deaths and disabilities globally, highlighting the critical medical need for the development of novel therapeutic strategies. We have designed, synthesized, and characterized a novel small molecule YA7068 that inhibits ALDH2 with excellent potency, while also acting as a substrate for the hepatocyte-specific organic anion transporting polypeptide 1B1 (OATP1B1). Our goal is to synthesize and test a series of YA7068 analogs using established assays, to identify, validate, and characterize potent liver specific ALDH2 inhibitors as a potential treatment for AUDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Our work aims to promote equitable access to lung transplant in a vulnerable population using up-to-date, cystic fibrosis-specific lung transplant education that supports self-efficacy and patient-empowerment in health care decisions. High-quality lung transplant discussions could improve clinical and psychological outcomes by changing attitudes, beliefs, and choices related to transplant. The Take on Transplant lung transplant decision support tool has the potential to expand the toolbox for engaging patients with cystic fibrosis in high-quality lung transplant discussions and aims to narrow the gap in access to transplant for individuals in disadvantaged groups, including those with lower socioeconomic status, non-White race, or Hispanic ethnicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eating disorders, including anorexia/bulimia nervosa and binge eating disorder, have their peak onset during adolescence but their etiological underpinnings are still largely unknown, leading to poor treatment outcomes and even mortality. This study will be the first to prospectively study the genetic, neuroimaging and behavioral factors that precede onset of an eating disorder in adolescence using data from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study, as well as integrating independently collected clinical data to examine how putative premorbid factors translate to clinical outcomes. Infusing a neurobiological perspective to an etiological model of eating disorders will offer valuable directions for future treatment plans and clinical assessments early in the course of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Medical toxicologists have increasing roles in the management of poisoned patients, adverse drug events, novel therapeutics and substance use disorder (SUD). Despite their critical role in the care of patients with SUD, few medical toxicologists achieve federal funding or receive formal instruction in hypothesis driven research. This proposal establishes the Advancing New Toxicology Investigators in Drug abuse and Original Translational research Efforts (ANTIDOTE) Institute in collaboration with the American College of Medical Toxicology to facilitate research methodology skills in medical toxicologists interested in substance use disorder research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Without access to an integrated approach to diagnosis, research, and care, many patients with rare conditions go from one institution to the next without finding answers or making progress with their care. This leads to poor outcomes for patients and families and poses a burden on our healthcare system. As part of this project, we will create sustainable, national infrastructure to address this unmet need for those who are undiagnosed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although Black Americans are twice as likely to have Alzheimer’s disease than White Americans, little is known about the impact of social and societal determinants of health on neurocognitive integrity of the medial temporal hippocampal memory and prefrontal-executive systems, the primary brain systems impacted in Alzheimer’s disease. The objective of this application is to investigate the impact of interpersonal and institutional/structural racism on neurocognitive integrity of these brain systems in Black adults aged 65 years and older and to examine cardiovascular disease risk as an underlying biological mechanism. Addressing this knowledge gap is critical for developing new health policies and biobehavioral and social interventions for healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Microfluidics (MF) are the test tubes of the digital age and play a vital role in drug discovery, biotechnology, lab- and organs-on-a-chip, personalized point-of-care diagnostics and treatment, disease research, and more. Phase, Inc. is developing a new 3D printing technology to create PDMS microfluidics that believe will fundamentally change the way PDMS microfluidics are fabricated and unlock the design freedom of additive manufacturing for the MF community, which will lead to significant advancements of in vitro MF models. This new 3D printing technology will allow researchers to quickly design and create microfluidic devices in a matter of hours – as opposed the weeks it now takes. This will enable researchers to more quickly test drugs to treat illness and decrease the time needed for new medicines to reach the market and, in turn, patients. Narrative

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research proposed in this application is relevant to public health because chronic pancreatitis is a progressive, incurable inflammation that leads to permanent organ damage and cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overall goal of this project is to understand the role of social connection OUD-related recovery outcomes, specifically during the postpartum period. The results of this study, regardless of outcome, will directly contribute to scientific knowledge on the role of social connectedness in postpartum OUD recovery. Moreover, this work will allow for the identification of new intervention targets, which will contribute to the development of novel, high- impact relapse prevention treatments tailored to the perinatal period, a unique inflection point with ample untapped opportunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Over 6 million adults in the U.S. are living with Alzheimer's Disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias (ADRD), a population estimated to double by 2050. We propose to examine the effects of enrollment in private Medicare Advantage plans versus traditional Medicare on health care use, management of comorbid conditions, potentially inappropriate medication use, and stays in nursing homes for beneficiaries with Alzheimer's Disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias. Given growing enrollment in the Medicare Advantage program, the findings from this project will provide important evidence of the program's effect on the health of individuals with Alzheimer's Disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The progressive intensification of drug craving/seeking across periods of drug abstinence poses a significant challenge for avoiding relapse to drug use. In the proposed experiments, we will use sleep electrophysiology, neurochemistry, biochemistry, and viral approaches to examine the extent to which sleep disruptions during cocaine abstinence contribute to dopamine terminal adaptations and persistent seeking and motivation for cocaine. Completion of the proposed experiments will reveal whether normalizing sleep or dopamine transporter expression and function is sufficient to prevent seeking and motivation for cocaine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This proposal is a competing renewal that will build upon the research completed during the last funding cycle to extend resource preserving, outcome dependent and outcome related sampling designs to generalized ordinal and longitudinal response data. For this funding cycle we will focus on robustness by way of new classes / applications of semiparametric models and estimation procedures. While efficient study designs are ubiquitous medical and public health research, we seek to expand this important methodology, and tools for implementation, to generalized ordinal and longitudinal ordinal data settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Obesity causes chronic inflammation without any obvious infection or autoimmune diseases. This chronic inflammation predisposes obese patients to various metabolic disorders, such as insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, and diabetic complications. However, the underlying causes of the sterile inflammation remains poorly understood. The proposed studies will determine the role of the ALCAT1 enzyme as a key regulator of inflammation and insulin resistance, thereby a novel drug target for obesity and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The clinical and financial burden of cancer care in the United States is high and rising, but little is known about the variation in radiation oncology spending and quality across the country and characteristics of high-performing radiation oncology practices. This research proposal will assess the variation in spending, utilization, and quality of radiation oncology practices across the U.S., determine whether disparities in care are seen for dually eligible Medicare and Medicaid patients, and identify unique strategies of high-performing practices based on insights from physicians and other healthcare workers. This study is relevant to public health and could have significant implications for clinicians and patients as the radiation oncology alternative payment model looms and as policymakers continue to seek ways to improve the value of cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Disparities in the health care system are substantial, leading to worse health outcomes and quality of care for marginalized groups. The proposed research builds a framework for reducing health disparities by creating fairer algorithms and removing societal bias from health care data for multiple marginalized groups with rigorous testing in a high-impact chronic kidney disease study. The broad applicability of the framework and creation of reusable computational tools will facilitate deployment in many practical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal health in the US is in crisis, where quality of care and health outcomes are particularly concerning for low-income pregnant and postpartum people (PPP) of color, the majority of whom are covered by Medicaid. Large scale, innovative Medicaid care delivery models like Accountable Care Organizations (ACOs) present an important opportunity for states to improve maternal health outcomes and equity at scale through better care integration, coordination, and quality improvement incentives, although very limited evidence is available to guide states and policymakers. This research will therefore fill this critical evidence gap by evaluating how Medicaid ACOs, and different Medicaid ACO model designs, can improve quality and equity of care for PPP by leveraging a novel natural experiment using both claims data and qualitative data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Dopamine is well-known for its importance in motivating, performing and reinforcing behavior, and its dysfunction is implicated in many neuropsychiatric diseases including depression, addiction and Parkinson’s Disease. How dopamine influences the activity of target neurons to modify behavior, however, remains unclear. Developing an understanding of dopamine’s actions on synapses, cells and circuits will help to clarify these actions and pave the way for novel targets for treatments that leverage these mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability of cells to define, change shape depends on their ability to mechanically tense their surroundings through actomyosin-based stress fibers (SFs). In this proposal we combine single-cell tools, traditional cell and molecular biological approaches, and tissue-mimetic culture platforms to investigate how individual SFs with a cell contribute to tension and motility relevant to brain cancer.

PHR: Project narrative There is a need for scientists who appreciate the clinical challenges of patients with digestive diseases and then seek to understand the mechanisms of disease. This research training program will provide a high-quality mentored training experience in basic, translational or clinical research. The fellows trained in this program will be prepared for meaningful careers in research that will ultimately lead to new diagnostic tests and therapies for patients with digestive diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Tissues in our bodies accumulate mutations over time. We do not yet understand what the effects of these mutations are on aging and disease. Currently, we do not have good tools to study these mutations in the native context of where cells live, tissues. Here, we will develop new tools to study mutations in tissues, and in particular, assay how and if somatic variants occur in spatial groupings across different types of tissues. After discovering these spatial groupings, we will explore how the variants change the state of the cells that harbor them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Discrimination between distinct salient locations among constellations of similar sensory cues is a crucial function of episodic memory in guiding behaviors such as goal-directed spatial navigation. This proposal investigates the neural circuits that support sensory cue representation, with a specific focus on the function of mature and adult generated granule cells and their inputs in the hippocampal dentate gyrus, a key brain region involved context encoding and spatial discrimination. This work will elucidate how multisensory cues are incorporated into episodic memories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE  In the last hour, over 100 patients have presented with suicide risk to emergency departments (EDs) and approximately 5 people have died by suicide in our country. The ED setting has strong potential to be an effective place to detect risk and intervene to reduce the chances of suicide, but current practices are insufficient, in large part because of poor access to behavioral health specialty care and tepid adoption of best- practices in suicide-related care. Our proposed study will address fundamental issues around leveraging telehealth service delivery models, both during the ED visit and afterwards, to help improve access to behavioral health specialty services, improve the quality of suicide-related care, and, ultimately, prevent suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Visual impairments are particularly disabling because they disrupt our ability to gather information critical for navigation. The retrosplenial cortex receives strong visual and hippocampal input, suggesting a central role in landmark processing. This proposal sets out to examine how the stability of landmark positions are learned and encoded by the retrosplenial cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The anterior insula is a component of the `anxiety network' and is heavily linked to anxiety-related symptoms. Nevertheless, the underlying role of insular circuits and their organization still remains unclear. We propose to use direct intracranial electrophysiological mapping with high density recordings to elucidate the functional organization of insular cortex in relation to dimensions of anxiety in patients with medication refractory epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The objective of this proposal is to develop a next-generation micro-CT system that offers low-dose, fast x-ray phase-contrast imaging (PCI) for soft tissue imaging. Our proposed system will use cutting-edge high resolution spectral detectors, allowing direct comparison of PCI micro-CT with attenuation-based spectral micro-CT. PCI may provide significant reductions in dose coupled with enhanced contrast and higher fine- structure visibility as advantages for cancer research in animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative mRNA treatments have the benefit of being quickly and precisely designed, and currently have been best suited for transient treatments with long lasting effects; RTI’s project concept that targets cellular uptake in progenitor cells advances the potential for mRNA therapeutic payload as these cells multiply in large numbers and differentiate into tissue-specific cells. As a result, with a single dose, RTI can achieve therapeutic results akin to repeated non-progenitor cell dosing, which has the potential to completely transform the global healthcare economy. Additionally, RTI’s platform allows for the testing of multiple different peptide-conjugated LNPs in a single subject and offers a novel, time efficient method for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Heath Relevance/Narrative Protein-protein interactions, proteases and kinases play critical roles in mediating cell signaling. Perturbation of their activities can lead to many human diseases including cancer and infectious diseases. The proposed engineering of new classes signaling reporters will expand our capability in imaging the compartmentalized signaling dynamics, laying foundation for understanding disease mechanisms and identifying therapeutics for the treatment of various diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The Wayne State University "Center for Urban Responses to Environmental Stressors (CURES)” strives to establish a cleaner and healthier living and working environment in the City of Detroit and other urban areas. A preponderance of our citizens disproportionately suffer the consequences of systemic racism, poverty, and environmental health disparities. CURES applies integrative teamwork, community-engaged research, and the latest technologies to understand how exposure to urban environmental chemical and non-chemical stressors affects human health. CURES seeks smart solutions that will reduce and ultimately eliminate the negative impact of these stressors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most common hemoglobin variants is homozygous sickle hemoglobin which leads to sickle cell disease (SCD), with an estimated 400,000 babies born annually with SCD and approximately 100,000 individuals living with SCD in the United States. Currently, there is no FDA-approved POC diagnostic device to detect Hb variants and quantify Hb-O2 affinity in hemoglobin disorders., and current laboratory and POC tests do not support treatment monitoring, especially for the new hemoglobin-oxygen affinity modifying therapies. This project aims to develop Gazelle Rapid Hemoglobin-Oxygen Dissociation Assay (RHODA) as the first POC diagnostic platform for screening and treatment monitoring for SCD by incorporating hemoglobin variant analysis and hemoglobin-oxygen affinity functional analysis in the same platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project aims to improve and validate a cutting-edge DNA analysis technique called Single Molecule Mutation Sequencing (SMM-Seq) to accurately detect various types of genetic mutations. This innovation will provide a valuable tool for assessing the potential health risks associated with exposure to harmful substances in our environment, ultimately contributing to better public health and disease prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Gulf Coast Center for Precision Environmental Health serves as a focal point and catalyst for environmental health sciences research across the Texas Medical Center. Its members from Baylor College of Medicine and the University of Texas work together with an active Community Engagement Core to drive precision environmental health research to prevent disease and improve human health, and promote career development of junior faculty. Research in the Center is accelerated by services provided by the PIPELINE and Translational Research Support Cores, and a Pilot Project Program that together advance our understanding of individual- and place-based environmental determinants of human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE UbiquiTx is pioneering a new class of computationally-designed mRNA therapeutics that encode peptide-guided protein degraders, known as ubiquibodies (uAbs), for potent and selective degradation of historically undruggable targets not addressable by conventional drugs. To further advance our platform, this Phase I STTR project seeks to design customized uAbs against β-catenin and CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein homologous protein (CHOP), two intracellular transcription factors that hold promise as drug targets for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD), and other liver diseases. By accelerating the removal of these two key intracellular disease drivers through LNP-mediated delivery of mRNA encoding peptide-guided uAbs, these studies will provide important proof-of-concept for our unconventional approach to drugging the proteome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Patients with inoperable locally advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) have a 5-year survival rate of just 31%. POP BIO seeks to advance its novel interstitial chemo-phototherapy (I-CPT) therapeutic that combines PhotoDox, POP BIO’s light-activated liposomal formulation of doxorubicin, with MRI treatment planning developed by PI to provide a potent therapeutic option for locally advanced HCC. This proposal seeks funds to generate IND-enabling pharmacokinetic data of doxorubicin; doxorubicinol, the major metabolite of doxorubicin; and PPa-lipid, the excipient responsible for phototherapy, in the plasma of rats and dogs as well as the assess the accelerated stability of PPa-lipid and PhotoDox.

PHR: Overall NARRATIVE The vision for the Texas A&M Center for Environmental Health Research (TiCER) is to nucleate environmental health research and translational activities of investigators around the overarching theme of “Innovative solutions for addressing exposure-stressor interactions with a focus on underserved populations in urban and urbanizing areas” in the state of Texas. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infects macrophages in the spinal cord, often leading to clinical symptoms even with antiretroviral treatment (ART). In the spinal cord, macrophages may serve as long-term cellular reservoirs of latent HIV; replication competent HIV can emerge from these latent reservoirs if ART is stopped. Our proposed studies to identify the cell types in the spinal cord harboring SIV combined with spinal cord gene expression profiling will advance our understanding of the role that spinal cord macrophages play in HIV latency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will collect data in a large treatment cohort [N=200 Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD), >40% female; enrollment at 2-5 weeks into treatment,; N=100 controls] using a multi-method approach (personality, neurocognition, clinical assessments, task/resting fMRI brain function) to assess function across three different domains (reward reactivity, aversive reactivity, executive control). We hypothesize that relapse in AUD is driven by different combinations of these three factors in each individual. We will test this hypothesis by using novel analytical approaches to parse out individual heterogeneity in the multivariate patterns of impairments underlying relapse in dependent alcohol users.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Most veterans will develop atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (CVD) during their lifetime. Research to date has largely focused on the role of traditional risk factors and the occurrence of CVD outcomes. Genes and the environment work in concert to foster the development of traditional risk factors and subsequently increase the risk for clinical vascular disease. This project provides the opportunity to investigate the role of genes and environment as causative in the development of the risk factors and the association of genes with CVD itself. It also expands the scope to include new CVD risk factors including blood cell indices, inflammatory conditions, valvular heart disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and atrial fibrillation. The project we describe creates the framework for the VA to participate in the process for CVD research concerning MVP assessment, risk factors and CVD outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related cognitive impairments co-occur with the disruption of molecular signaling within the brain, but the basic mechanisms of this relationship are unclear. In the proposed research project, we will investigate the mechanisms by which changes in the activity of the noradrenaline signaling molecule modulates the increased distractibility by task-irrelevant information seen in older adults and whether managing baseline levels can improve attentional control. The findings in both older and young adults will contribute critical knowledge on how the changes in molecular signaling activity in the brain modulates behavior, which will inform therapeutic approaches in how to control the activity of these signaling molecules to prevent cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: For the past 30 years, the VA has been a leader in measuring the quality of surgical care. However, most of the VA’s work has focused on quality outcomes that happen after surgery. There is a need to develop new reliable and more accurate measures of quality of care for the Veteran’s entire health care journey, both before and after surgery. The goals of the current study are to develop an approach for measuring the quality of Veterans’ full surgical experience (the “surgical episode”) for three common surgical procedures and to apply this approach to VA and Community Care settings in which Veterans receive care. This work will advance the science of quality measurement to more thoroughly assess quality before, during, and after surgery in order to identify opportunities for quality improvement. The proposed study will also compare VA and Community Care quality, providing recommendations to improve quality measurement for Community Care, and helping to inform Veterans about their choices for surgical care in VA and Community Care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We present an innovative pathophysiological concept: Dry Eye Disease (DED) is characterized by breach of self-tolerance towards citrullinated antigens with generation of autoantibodies. Neutrophil Extracellular Traps could represent a source of citrullinated antigens fueling the autoimmune response over the ocular surface, creating a self-perpetuating cycle of chronic inflammation. Because pooled human immune globulins contain anti-idiotypic antibodies that inhibit the pathogenic actions of autoantibodies, we propose to formulate them as eye drops for use as the first topical biologic immunotherapy for DED.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Over 1 million Black and 0.5 million Hispanic Veterans are enrolled in the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) and the percentage of race and ethnic minorities served by the VHA is expected to continue to increase over the next several decades. Hypertension is the most common chronic condition in Black and Hispanic adults and is a top risk factor for cardiovascular disease morbidity and mortality. Also, Black Veterans are more likely to die due to stroke compared to White Veterans in the VHA and controlling blood pressure is recognized a one of the most important ways to prevent stroke. Understanding the reasons for racial and ethnic differences in blood pressure treatment in Veterans is important for developing implementation plans that support high quality equitable care for all Veterans. This research is consistent with the VA Blueprint for Excellence Transformational Actions: “to understand and eliminate health inequalities.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The shortage of minority representation among scientists that conduct research and outreach in substance use disorders contributes to the lack of role models needed to train young students about the harmful impact of substance use, specifically in minority populations. With substance use disorders being prevalent among minority populations, it is of particular importance that we continue to foster the development of young minority students interested in pursuing careers in science. The UTEP (University of Texas El Paso) SMART MIND program is aimed at enhancing the education and research training of 12 undergraduate students, 3 high school teachers, and 6 high school students each summer (through Americans for Medical Progress), with a focus on neuroscience and public health issues related to substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric acute respiratory distress syndrome (PARDS) is a heterogeneous syndrome characterized by severe, refractory hypoxemia not explained by heart failure or fluid overload that affects 6% of children requiring invasive mechanical ventilation in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU). More than 40% of children who die PARDS-related deaths are previously healthy, very young children and there are currently no targeted therapies to treat PARDS apart from supportive care. The goal of this project is to identify molecular pathways that contribute to prolonged acute hypoxemic respiratory failure to guide the development of personalized therapies to alleviate the sequelae of lung injury and reduce long-term morbidity and mortality of critically ill children with acute lung injury.

PHR: Project Narrative (relevance to public health) ALS is a fatal neurodegenerative disease that causes progressive motor dysfunction, paralysis, and ultimately death. The mechanism of this disease is incompletely understood. This proposal will investigate the role of protein arginine deiminase 2 (PAD2) and protein citrullination in ALS pathogenesis. The results will uncover new mechanisms and may open a new avenue for ALS therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Patients widely vary in their beneficial and adverse effects to medications, with important clinical and public health consequences. This research focuses on how a person’s genetic makeup, drug-drug interactions and drug metabolizing enzymes located outside human liver influence variability in drug response. The results will help to identify patients at increased risk for drug adverse effects or for lack of clinical benefit, which is a key step towards personalized therapy by selecting the right dose or drug for each patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-associated (CA) MRSA is a major health concern worldwide that causes significant morbidly and mortality in humans. This work will fill a critical gap in knowledge pertaining to how the peptidome contributes to CA-MRSA disease etiologies. The information gained from this work has the potential to discover new mechanisms of host-pathogen interactions and can lead to the rational design of anti-virulence based therapies. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE For researchers to take full advantage of the large amount of clinical data that is captured in electronic health records and incorporate this information into machine learning and artificial intelligence applications, outcomes research, genotype-phenotype association studies, and other areas, it is critically important to be able to accurately identify diseases and outcomes of interest; the existing approach relies exclusively on administrative billing codes to identify these entities. In this study we will develop and test novel approaches to identifying and characterizing sight-threatening eye diseases and their outcomes in electronic health record data. By fulfilling the aims of this grant, we will make it easier for researchers throughout the country and the world to make use of electronic health record and clinical registry data to study patients with chronic diseases, which is essential to the mission of the National Institutes of Health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) represents one of the most significant healthcare problems in the aging population of the United States, but the contribution of the blood-brain barrier and meningeal lymphatics impairment in AD is yet to be fully elucidated. This is partly due to the lack of an effective and reliable model to capture the complex interactions between the various cellular components in the brain. Drawing upon our considerable experience in 3D modeling of AD in a dish, the BBB, and neurovascular units in vitro, we propose to create a comprehensive model of AD focusing on key interactions and the role of the BBB and meningeal lymphatics impairment in Aβ clearance to gain a deeper understanding of underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative My proposal aims to use cryo-electron tomography and correlative fluorescence microscopy to elucidate the high-resolution structural changes that lead to excitotoxic loss in dendritic spines (DS). I hypothesize following glutamate excitotoxicity dually innervated DS that contain both an inhibitory and excitatory synapse have a more stable DS structure than single innervated DS containing only an excitatory synapse. If successful, this project would determine the high-resolution actin network differences between dually and singly innervated DS and provide evidence for the protective effect of inhibitory synapses on DS structure ensuing excitotoxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improvements to mass spectrometry will better enable the study of aging, neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, and age-related cancers. This project addresses the missingness endemic to virtually every quantita- tive mass spectrometry proteomics experiment and offers a robust analytical solution that will signiﬁcantly improve the utility of mass spectrometry experiments. The computational methods developed by this project will enable additional discoveries within Alzheimer's disease proteomics data, leading to better understanding of Alzheimer's disease biology, identiﬁcation of brain region-speciﬁc biomarkers, and selection of potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is the greatest risk factor for many age-related diseases that impair quality of life and is a growing public health concern in the United States. One hallmark of aging is cellular senescence, which has been shown to promote age-related pathologies. This proposal will examine how dietary protein and branched-chain amino acids regulate healthy aging by affecting cellular senescence, with the goal of gaining mechanistic insight into cellular senescence and aging that will aid in developing geroprotective interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cerebellum improves behavior using implicit learning encoded by climbing-fiber-induced LTD, a type of plasticity subject to regulation because without gating, its induction would occur promiscuously potentially corrupting the capacity for accurate new learning. Because GABAA receptor-mediated inhibition opposes climbing-fiber-mediated plasticity and learning, we seek to test the hypothesis that in a mouse model of dystrophinopathy (Duchenne muscular dystrophy, DMD), loss of dystrophin-dependent GABAA receptor clustering in Purkinje cells explains plasticity deficits that affect implicit learning in these animals. Furthermore, we will test whether increasing inhibition in these cells provides symptomatic relief by increasing the threshold for plasticity induction; in this way, completion of this project will help determine pathology related to impaired plasticity gating, the etiology of brain deficits in DMD, and provide insight into therapeutic strategies to recover cerebellar function in this disorder.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA WESTERN NEW YORK HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death among Veterans and congestive heart failure, in particular, is among the most common conditions resulting in death, disability, and hospitalization. Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) has emerged as the most common form of heart failure, but our poor understanding of how it develops has made it difficult to devise effective treatments. The research proposed in this application will address this problem by examining how repetitive stretch-induced remodeling of the non- cellular components of heart muscle (i.e., the cardiac extracellular matrix) leads to persistent fibrotic collagen deposition and a sustained reduction in cardiac compliance that promotes the development of HFpEF in patients with chronic coronary artery disease (CAD). Improved understanding of this process is anticipated to reveal new targets for therapies designed to prevent or reverse heart muscle stiffening in CAD patients at-risk of developing HFpEF and significantly improve the quality of life and survival of Veterans with this common condition.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Service-related diseases including post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) are a major problem in Veterans. There is also an increased prevalence of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD; ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease) in VA patients. IBD and PTSD appear to be linked. It has been speculated that this is related to altered gut bacteria (microbiome), but this potential explanation, and the cellular/molecular features of IBD in Veterans have not been determined. We will utilize our long experience in IBD research, our robust clinical and research infrastructure, and the synergy of the Collaborative Merit Award to address knowledge gaps. Using powerful molecular techniques, we will study stool bacterial composition and function, as well as genes and proteins expressed, and metabolites in gut tissues from VA IBD and PTSD patients. We will use novel models involving intestinal cells from patients, and mice infected with patient microbiota and tested in experimental colitis, to uncover causes of these diseases and develop a Roadmap for new treatments in Veterans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preeclampsia affects millions of pregnancies worldwide, and there are limited therapeutics for patients. Senescent cells have been implicated in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia, and designing drugs targeting senescent cells holds great promise. The histone variant H2AJ has been shown to control the senescent- associated secretory phenotype, and we have knocked down this protein in a model of trophoblast development to uncover its function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria remains one of the biggest infectious disease problems in the world, and drugs are of critical importance to treat episodes of malaria, prevent disease in high risk groups, and limit transmission. In this context, antimalarial drug resistance is a major threat. We will study the pharmacology of key drugs in studies evaluating the treatment of malaria in Ugandan children, prevention of malaria in Ugandan pregnant women, and prevention of malaria in children in Burkina Faso. These studies will help us to optimize regimens for the treatment and prevention of malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis can cause jaw bone destruction, tooth loss. and increased risk of developing systemic conditions. This application is relevant to public health because it will provide us new knowledge about balancing host immune and inflammatory responses in periodontitis by promoting functions of immune regulatory cells. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that it will contribute to the future development of local therapeutic strategies that are effective in treating periodontitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  Parkinson’s disease (PD) is an incurable neurodegenerative disorder (ND) affecting over a million Americans but no effective treatment options are available to slow down the progression of the disease mainly due to the lack of an in-depth mechanistic understanding of the complex neurodegenerative processes underlying the disease. The research proposed here will identify a novel protective mitochondrial and nuclear subcellular signaling network mediated by protein kinase D1 activation, which is inherent in dopaminergic neurons during the early stages of neuronal oxidative stress (OS). The outcome of this research program will help devise a new treatment strategy that can intervene early in the progression of this debilitating disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to understand characteristics that relate to higher or lower electric vehicle adoption levels in a neighborhood, through talking with community members and examining large datasets for the state of California. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current treatment options for breast cancer brain metastases with human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2+) are limited, leading to a poor prognosis for these patients. The proposed study aims to demonstrate that (a) de novo lipid synthesis as a novel therapeutic target for HER2+ breast cancer brain metastases and (b) targeting lipid metabolism improves the treatment outcome. Our findings will directly inform the design and interpretation of future clinical trials using agents that target lipid metabolism to improve treatment of patients with HER2+ breast cancer brain metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE

PHR: Public health relevance statement: The disruption of numerous human genes and their isoforms driven by non-coding genetic variants is implicated in cancer and several neuropsychiatric disorders, including Parkinson's disease, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and autism. This project will contribute novel pre-trained deep-learning tools to decipher the language of non- coding DNA and facilitate integration of gene regulatory information from rapidly accumulating sequence data with NLM’s genetic databases (for example, dbSNP, dbGaP and ClinVar), which serve both scientists and the public health by helping identify the genetic components of disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research program is relevant to public health because it encompasses the development and characterization of the highly specific monoclonal antibody inhibitors for disease-related proteases. These proteases are pivotal in the pathogenesis of many disorders including cancer, neuropathic pain, obesity, stroke, and viral infections. Highly specific monoclonal antibody inhibitors will accelerate research directed to a better understanding of basic pathology of these diseases and lead to the development of therapeutic interventions targeting these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year, approximately 795,000 people suffer a stroke and more than 140,000 people die from stroke in the United States. However, there is only one FDA-approved drug for ischemic stroke, the tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), which is beneficial to patients only within 4.5 hours of having a stroke. Therefore, there is an urgent need to identify novel therapeutic targets for treatment of this devastating disease. This study aims to reveal the pathological role of the cell swelling-activated chloride channel and evaluate the effectiveness of targeting this membrane protein in ischemic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For last two decades, Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) research has been focusing on a neuron-centric biochemical process that leads to synaptic deficits and neuronal degeneration. However, recent failures in clinical trials call for studies that lead to unbiased and holistic understanding of disease pathways in different types of brain cells. This project aims to unbiasedly explore and validate neuron-glia and glia-glia interaction in the AD brain by combining a computational systems biology platform, novel 3D Alzheimer’s-in-a-dish models, and the enriched multiple-omics AD databases. The completion of this study will provide a validated integrated bioinformatics tool to unbiasedly identify altered neuron-glia and glia-glia crosstalk pathways in AD and will provide novel therapeutic targets and repositioned drug candidates for translating into clinical studies for AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Men’s reproductive health is a critically understudied area of research, and ambient exposures including air pollution and temperature may have important adverse impacts on male fertility. Together, findings from this study will provide a comprehensive understanding of the impact of exposure to ambient air pollution and both high and low ambient temperatures during developmentally-relevant windows of spermatogenesis on men’s reproductive health and infertility treatment outcomes. Findings will add to the evidence base identifying optimal timing of infertility treatment to male partner environmental risk factors and suggesting future research directions for potential benefits of behavioral or pharmacologic interventions in the weeks leading up to fertility treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Molecular mechanisms of BPH initiation and progression remain incompletely understood. The lack of understanding of these mechanisms is a barrier to improved treatment. Our study will reveal novel molecular mechanism regulating BPH initiation and progression and inspire novel therapeutic avenues for BPH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Kidney transplantation is the preferred treatment for end stage renal disease yet many transplant recipients still suffer from rejection and the side effects of immunosuppressive medications. Transplantation tolerance has the potential to eliminate the need for chronic immunosuppression and avoid their attendant side effects thereby improving the health and well-being of transplant recipients. Developing successful approaches to induce transplant tolerance has the potential to improve countless patients’ lives along with significantly decreasing the societal burden of end-stage organ disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Despite treatment advances in rheumatology, pain remains the most prominent, unaddressed patient complaint in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), a condition that disproportionately affects women and racial minorities. The proposed research uses electronic health records to characterize chronic pain and its biopsychosocial mechanisms in SLE. The information learned from the study is relevant to public health efforts to understand the burden and natural history of pain; and it is also relevant to NIAM’s mission of improving the understanding of biopsychosocial components of pain in rheumatology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative This project investigates the underlying biological mechanisms whereby environmental chemicals alter the expression of genes that control physiological processes that affect human health and liver-based disease. This research is centered on the effects of foreign chemicals on gene transcription events whose dysregulation leads to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, which affects an estimated 25% of all US adults and is a major cause of advanced disease and liver failure. Overall, the findings obtained are expected to increase our understanding of the effects of environmental chemical exposures on hepatic metabolism and the development of liver disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The objective of this study is to address the gap in knowledge of best practices for remote insulin pump management to mitigate adverse effects the ongoing pandemic has on high-risk Veterans on insulin pumps (VIPs). The long-term goal of this research is to establish an evidence-based telehealth program for safe and effective remote insulin pump management to improve access to remote care for VIPs and meet the growing demand for insulin pump therapy. An established telehealth program for VIPs will: (1) benefit vulnerable Veterans living in rural communities and other Veterans who face access challenges unrelated to distance from their closest VA, (2) expand care options for Veterans with diabetes who may be candidates for insulin pump therapy but are unable to access VA specialty care, and (3) enhance VIPs ability to connect with their care team for critical real-time troubleshooting of unexpected device failures. Expanding Veteran access to remote insulin pump management assures continued quality care and connection for VIPs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Pompe disease results from mutations in the gene for acid α-glucosidase (GAA). Current therapeutic strategies delay disease progression but many patients eventually suffer respiratory failure. Supported by preliminary data, this renewal application uses rat models of Pompe disease to test the hypothesis that adeno- associated virus (AAV) gene therapy is capable of restoring life-long GAA expression throughout the nervous system, skeletal and cardiac muscle, thereby preserving cardiorespiratory function and prolonging life.

PHR: PROJECT 2 NARRATIVE The objective of Project 2 is to develop a safe, effective, and clinically translatable protocol in nonhuman primates for inducing stable tolerance in living donor kidney transplants. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The objective of this application is to define cellular and molecular mechanism by which brain angiogenesis (formation of new blood vessels) is regulated under low energy conditions. Our project is relevant to and has implications for public health because, if successful, it will identify a novel drug target to regulate a novel innate mechanism for brain angiogenesis under pathological conditions such as traumatic brain injury, stroke, hypoxia, metabolic and nutritional disorders, and tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiological data link the history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) to increased likelihood of development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD) later in life. While recent analyses estimate the overall risk of dementia attributable to TBI at 5-15%, it is still poorly understood how history of brain trauma may contribute to neurodegeneration years or even decades later. Here we propose to determine whether TBI may speed up detrimental cellular changes occurring during normal brain ageing, thus leading to AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular pathogen that can cause serious disease in immunosuppressed people (such as AIDS patients) and fetuses and is also a major cause of blindness in otherwise healthy individuals. In this proposal, we will determine the mechanisms by which Toxoplasma uses the secreted effector protein TgWIP to modulate the host leukocyte migration machinery, thereby hijacking these cells as Trojan Horses to mediate its in vivo dissemination. By advancing our understanding of the molecular mechanisms by which Toxoplasma disseminates through co-opting host leukocytes, the proposed work can provide novel insights into cell motility, which is likely shared by various types of metastatic cancer cells and immune cells, and will also lay the foundation for the development of safe, non-transmissible vaccines or novel therapeutics to block Toxoplasma dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA deaminase enzymes can generate purposeful genomic mutations and play important immune defense roles, but are naturally constrained in various manners that make them suboptimal as biotechnological tools. This proposal aims to leverage knowledge of DNA deaminase structure and function to engineer CRISPR/Cas- coupled base editors that are capable of generating targeted genomic changes in an efficient and controllable manner. The outcome of this work will be an enhanced understanding of the base editing mechanism and a suite of editing tools with properties necessary to study, diagnose, or treat diseases involving precise genomic changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Kidney transplantation is the preferred treatment for end stage renal disease yet many transplant recipients still suffer from rejection and the side effects of immunosuppressive medications. Transplantation tolerance holds the promise of long-term transplant survival without immunosuppression. Developing successful approaches to induce transplant tolerance has the potential to improve countless patients’ lives along with significantly decreasing the societal burden of end-stage organ disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Genetic variations of NMDAR GRIN genes have been identified in children with profound neurodevelopmental problems, including intractable seizures, autism, and intellectual disability. We will compare the functional effects of disease-associated variants with the missense variants present in the general population in the GRIN2A gene to evaluate the idea that variation of intolerant genes can act as risk factors for neurological disorders. We will elucidate how the loss and gain of NMDAR activity promote network hyperexcitability and induce epileptic phenotypes in mice engineered to harbor the variant, which will allow us to suggest novel strategy of potential personalized therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ovarian cancer is a leading cause of cancer deaths among women with a five-year survival below 50% despite recent advances in therapy. These studies will determine the mechanisms by which a key signaling molecule (FAK) coordinately promotes tumor recurrence and acquired chemotherapy resistance. Knowledge gained from these studies will provide a blueprint for understanding FAK-driven disease, and will identify women whose disease will benefit from FAK-targeted drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most cancer patients do not respond to currently approved immune checkpoint inhibitors, motivating a need for new approaches to stimulate robust and durable immune responses against tumors. This proposal aims to develop and optimize a new class of immunotherapeutic nanotechnology that jump starts natural mechanisms of antitumor immunity. If successful, this approach has potential to increase the number of patients that benefit from cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study aims to uncover the plasticity of postmitotic cells in mammalian retina. We will focus on understanding how zinc finger transcription factor Myt1 promotes neuronal fates in newly born postmitotic cells during development and determining whether Myt1 can enhance neuronal reprogramming in mature retina. This work will improve our understanding of the retina and provide new candidate genes and possibilities for the regeneration of retinal neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Blockade of CD154 is a highly effective method of inducing transplantation tolerance (a state in which transplant recipients would no longer require toxic immunosuppression), however clinical translation of CD154 blockers has met with many challenges, and as an alternative reagents that block CD40 (the receptor for CD154) were tested in recent clinical trials. However, CD40 blockers have proved to be not as effective as CD154 blockers, and here we have identified a novel molecular interaction that explains this discrepancy. Here, we will test innovative strategies to block these residual interactions and thus optimize the use of CD40 blockers to promote transplant tolerance in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders (SUD) are heritable and facilitated by a host of brain-based mechanisms. These mechanisms, their neural correlates and genetic underpinnings, are increasingly being investigated in the context of large consortium efforts using novel technologies including genomics and neuroimaging. Leveraging such data at scale to address questions in addiction science is a challenge that this mixed predoctoral/postdoctoral training program will rise to meet through a central focus on neurobehavioral measures, genetically informative designs, and cutting edge quantitative methods to uncover and characterize neurobehavioral mechanisms in the development of addiction.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in genetic and neurobehavioral mechanisms of addiction

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because a detailed understanding of the role of autophagy in esophageal epithelial renewal and basal cell homeostasis will fundamentally advance the fields of epithelial biology and mucosal defense. These findings will provide a platform for new avenues of translational applications for therapy in eosinophilic esophagitis. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burden of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: African Americans have a higher incidence rate of colorectal cancer and colorectal cancer diagnosed before age 50 constitutes over 15% of all colorectal cancers diagnoses—a major cancer health disparity. We have discovered a subtype of colorectal cancers that lack mutation in the APC gene that is associated with earlier ages of diagnosis and a novel epigenetic signature that impacts cancer stem cell maintenance. We will characterize the DNA methylation and transcriptomic signatures and interrogate with genetic and chemical perturbations the pathway-specific vulnerabilities of this subtype, leading to the identification of gene targets and enabling development of precision-medicine approaches to earlier age of onset colorectal cancers in African Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD), for which no effective therapy exists, affect millions of people in the US, cost hundreds of billions of dollars in caregiving expenses, and are a source of important racial and ethnic disparities. Education and lifestyle contribute to these disparities, and this project will clarify how genetic factors may also be involved through the application of three novel tools to study mitochondrial genetic variation: 1) mitochondrial genome-wide association studies (MiWAS), 2) mitochondria-wide gene and environment (GxE) interaction scans (MiWIS), and 3) mito-transcriptomics. The proposed analyses will help explain ethnic differences in AD risk and guide immediate diagnostic insights, targeted lifestyle interventions, and novel therapeutic target identification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The advancement of biomedical research critically relies on training the next generation of scientists. The goal of the Northwestern University Postbaccalaureate Research Education Program is to recruit trainees from diverse, underrepresented groups and prepare them for a successful transition into graduate school in the biomedical sciences and to help guarantee their success in obtaining the PhD degree. The program features core research, communication skills instruction, and coursework, in addition to a broad range of opportunities within the life sciences PhD and affiliated institutional training (T32) programs, allowing for individualized experiences that will foster personal, scientific and professional growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Natural killer cells (also known as NK cells) are a type of white blood cell that can target and kill cancer cells and virally infected cells; however, their functions are dysregulated during HIV infection allowing HIV-infected cells to evade their surveillance. The functions of these NK cells are hindered when a carbohydrate-binding protein called Siglec-9, expressed on their surface, binds to specific carbohydrates expressed on the surface of their target (HIV-infected) cells. We developed a novel approach to prevent this binding and thereby enhance the NK cells' ability to target and kill HIV-infected cells; this approach can be used in conjugation with other approaches to cure HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Hypertension is a growing epidemic condition that afflicts a third of the US population. We have identified the E3 ubiquitin ligase adaptor FBXL13 that interacts with the Na/K/2Cl co-transporter (NKCC2) which is associated to hypertension, but the function of this E3-ubiquitin ligase remains unclear. This proposal will elucidate the effect of high salt diet on the mechanism by which the E3 ubiquitin ligase adaptor FBXL13 regulates NKCC2- dependent NaCl reabsorption which, may lead to new strategies for the treatment of hypertension and promote the development of specific loop diuretics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute lung injury (ALI), known clinically as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is a severe and potentially fatal condition with distinct sub-phenotypes associated with different clinical outcomes. Molecular imaging of the recently discovered chemokine receptor/chemokine ChemR23/chemerin axis is a promising approach to non-invasively determine and characterize ALI endotypes. This proposal will focus on the development ChemR23/chemerin targeting positron emission tomography tracers and validation of their potential to non-invasively track the ongoing lung inflammation in a mouse model of ALI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of this project is to test a virtual reality experience designed to reduce drug use and increase abstinence, and increase identification with the future self, future time perspective, and delayed reward choice in persons recovering from stimulant use disorder. Through increasing future orientation and delay-of-reward behavior with a precision medicine personalized experience, the intervention is designed to increase beneficial decision-making and positive future outcomes. The results of this study will provide vital information on the effectiveness and behavioral mechanisms of this adjunctive intervention intended to facilitate recovery outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Disruption of circadian rhythms is common in modern life and has been causatively associated with most major human diseases including coronary artery disease, diabetes, obesity, aging, and neuropsychiatric disorders. We propose to investigate the underlying biochemical and cell biological mechanisms by which the circadian timekeeping system adapts to stress to promote cellular resilience. Unveiling the links between the circadian system and cellular stress pathways will define crucial regulatory steps that might herald the identification of novel disease pathways and how the circadian clock modulates vulnerability to them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are significant sex differences in COPD epidemiology and clinical manifestations, however sex-based analyses of genomic data have been limited, neglecting an essential biological variable for advancing precision medicine for lung diseases. We propose integrating X chromosome multi-omic data, X chromosome inactivation patterns, and network analysis to better understand sex-biased regulation of X chromosome genes in COPD susceptibility and heterogeneity. Understanding the X chromosome genetic, epigenetic, and regulatory network features associated with COPD will provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying sex differences in COPD susceptibility, emphysema, and lung function, and facilitate future development of sex-aware diagnostics and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Boston Lung Cancer Survival cohort contains an extensive amount of valuable questionnaire and biologic data that can be leveraged to extend our understanding of the natural history of lung cancer. The combination of biomarkers, tumor molecular characterization, radiomic features, and traditional epidemiologic risk factors in this rich resource enables powerful translational research and provides unique opportunities to explore novel predictors of overall survival and treatment outcomes. With continued support, the Boston Lung Cancer Survival cohort can continue to advance our understanding of the molecular heterogeneity of lung cancer, enabling effective diagnostic and therapeutic strategies that improve the health of individuals diagnosed with lung cancer.

PHR: Narrative Collective invasion is a major mode of metastasis observed in patients across most solid tumor types. We developed a new imaging-based technique to obtain molecular and epigenetic data of specialized cell types within the lung cancer collective invasion pack. We will use this information to probe the mechanistic underpinnings of Myo10 function within the collective pack.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is relevant to public health because early identification of behavioral and academic deficits for school readiness is crucial for timely intervention and prevention of more severe outcomes, such as conduct problems, problems with peer interactions, and school dropout. The expected results will have identified neural processes and cognitive control processes that explain how parenting practices influence children's school readiness. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NICHD mission that all children have the chance to achieve their full potential for healthy and productive lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Tuberculosis is a major global health burden, killing more than 1.5 million people every year, despite the availability of therapy. A central clinical and microbiologic feature of the disease is the ability of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) to resist complete elimination, both by the host immune system and by chemotherapeutic agents. This project will investigate the host and bacterial determinants that mediate persistence of Mtb within its human host.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Pneumonia has long been the leading cause of death from infection in the United States, but the evidence underlying standard clinical care remains relatively sparse. The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in practice changes that challenged existing standards. This project will examine changes in antibiotic and steroid use for pneumonia that emerge from the pandemic, and explore more tailored approaches that better match treatment to the complexity of individual patients. Our research team studied VA provider decision-making for pneumonia prior to the pandemic and compared the effectiveness of various treatments. This previous work allows us to examine changes in beliefs and approaches. Our proposed study will use rigorous re- search methods that combine interviews with healthcare data to examine how treatment for Veterans with pneumonia is evolving, and inform how it should evolve and be implemented. Our research will inform new treatment standards for patients with pneumonia that take into account individual patient differences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Amblyopia, or reduced vision due to the effects of early abnormal visual experience, affects approximately 3% of the human population. Designing effective treatments requires an understanding of the plasticity mechanisms that underlie this process, and how they are gated by behavioral states such as sleeping and waking. This proposal will test an influential theory about how sleep regulates experience-dependent plasticity, and will illuminate the processes that allow visual function to remain stable or improve in the face of sensory and learning-induced perturbations.
