IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol-exposed pregnancy (AEP) can cause lifetime intellectual and physical disabilities, including Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders, but AEP can be prevented with behavioral interventions. This project will be the first to systematically optimize a previously tested digital behavioral intervention, CARRII, for Native women at risk for AEP. The project will generate a new digital AEP intervention for Native women that could sustainably reduce AEPs in this high-risk subpopulation at acceptable costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals suffering from atopic dermatitis are at increased risk of developing severe infections, but the reason(s) are not well understood. Our goal is to determine whether the local tissue environment impairs the persistence or function of immune cells within the skin of patients with allergic diseases. Based on these studies, novel therapies may be developed to improve protection from infection in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Articular cartilage enables efficient and pain-free transfer of load across joints with the activities of daily living, but is often compromised by traumatic injury and disease, and has a poor endogenous healing capacity. To address this, we develop a novel therapeutic approach that leverages the interaction between regenerative bone marrow derived mesenchymal stromal cells and a small number of chondrocytes delivered using customized micro-scale hydrogels. We further develop a clinically relevant delivery system and evaluate the potential of this new therapy to foster the formation of functional tissue in a pre-clinical large animal model of cartilage repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microscopic tumor deposits missed by surgery cannot be resolved using current clinical imaging technologies and often harbor cell populations resistant to chemotherapy, representing a prominent source of cancer recurrence and mortality. The goal of this proposal is to develop a new paradigm for cancer therapy using multiplexed molecular imaging to detect residual cancer cells and to guide personalized photomedicine for targeting heterogeneous and chemoresistant micrometastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who are discharged from the hospital have high rates of early readmission; these readmissions are a significant burden to the health care system. The proposed research will combine social information with rich clinical data to develop a real-time readmission risk prediction algorithm that will be integrated into a patient-centric intervention and tested in real-world clinical practice settings. The information learned from this project will assist in providing individualized treatment at the transition from hospital to home and focused on reducing healthcare utilization and ultimately improving quality of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The major unmet need for colorectal cancer (CRC) patients is low efficacy and safety of the current clinically used drug therapies. We have identified oncogenic CHD1L, a relatively new molecular target that drives CRC tumor malignancy and poor prognosis for CRC patients. This project will validate the first-in-class inhibitors of CHD1L and evaluate them for therapeutic potential using biochemical, cell based, and in vivo models CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Erectile dysfunction (ED) imposes profoundly negative impacts on well-being of the affected males, particularly those with neurovascular defects (e.g., diabetes, hypertension, prostate cancer, etc.), but currently available treatments moderately manage the symptom at best. Encouragingly, we have discovered that a naturally- occurring biological agent, specifically stromal cell-derived factor-1 (SDF-1), possesses unique ability to potentially reverse the underlying cause of the disease. We thus propose here to develop novel SDF-1-based mRNA therapy for safe, sustainable and unprecedentedly curative treatment of ED.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autoimmune diabetes is characterized by an inflammatory reaction in and around pancreatic islets, followed by selective destruction of insulin producing b-cells. In this proposal, we explore the role of virus infection as an initiation event leading to the destruction of b-cells during the development of this disease. The focus of the current application is to identify pathways used by b-cells to defend themselves against damage associated with virus infection, and we hope that information gained in these studies will lead to a better understanding of disease pathogenesis and identify novel targets for the design of therapeutic strategies to prevent or delay disease onset.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding determinants and consequences of the latent HIV reservoir are important for development of HIV cure approaches and optimizing long-term outcomes for children with HIV infection (CHIV). The proposed study will examine HIV reservoir clonal dynamics in early- and late-treated CHIV, specifically evaluating the role of CMV infection, and will evaluate how the reservoir contributes to long-term neurocognitive outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the great toll substance abuse takes on society, the pace of discovery of new and effective prevention and treatment strategies is only modest, and major delays exist in translating such knowledge into improved health of patients and populations. There is an urgent need to increase the number of health care professionals conducting clinically applicable research in the prevention and treatment of substance use disorders. The goal of this grant is to expand, and deepen the health equity focus and national impact of, a substance use disorder research training program targeting students in the fields of medicine, nursing, dentistry, social work and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP) is the most common cause of inherited spasticity and associated disability worldwide. Loss-of-function variants in the genes encoding the adaptor protein complex 4 (AP-4) lead to a prototypical form of HSP in children and can serve as a genetic model to understand the contributions of defective protein trafficking and autophagy to neurodegeneration. This project will develop a cross- organismal screening platform to identify and characterize novel modulators of protein trafficking for the treatment of HSP.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The Wisconsin National Primate Research Center (WNPRC) base operating grant supports services and resources for research addressing human health issues utilizing non-human primate (NHP) models. The WNPRC provides a rich and integrated portfolio of cutting-edge services, resources, and scientific expertise that support NHP research with high impact and direct relevance to human and animal health and disease. With ongoing additions to WNPRC infrastructure, and expansion of the Center’s scientific components and collaborations, the WNPRC is poised to advance the translation of NHP research findings into new remedies for some of our society’s most pressing medical problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a compelling need to find better alternatives to current general anesthetics, all of which produce undesirable effects and derive from pre-1980 molecular discoveries. This MIRA proposal aims to secure continued research support for the PI, a physician-scientist and international leader in research on general anesthetics whose innovative and rigorous work, long supported by NIGMS, aims to advance the field by defining receptor-based anesthetic mechanisms and by using zebrafish as a model to accelerate anesthetic discovery and mechanisms research. The PI also advances the NIH mission as a grant reviewer and director of a research training program (T32) for anesthesiologists.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health; it will develop a novel approach to an HIV Cure by durably silencing and permanently inactivating viral expression. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop new models for prediction of cognitive outcomes including cognitive change and incident Alzheimer’s disease. Prediction models will be developed by applying advanced machine learning techniques to high-dimensional data including clinical, neuropsychological, genetic, and biomarker data. This approach will lead to predictive tools that can be effectively used in research as well as clinical decision making for patients in prodromal stages of Alzheimer’s disease or individuals with normal cognition and high-risk of developing Alzheimer’s Disease.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will generate software tools that increase the ability of scientists to use genome sequence data to advance human health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project focuses on largely unexplored mechanisms that multicellular eukaryotes have evolved to grow and protect themselves from death and diseases caused by insufficiency and defects in secretory protein synthesis. To achieve our goals, we will harness the power of the genomic resources and molecular tools of the model plant species Arabidopsis thaliana, which allow genetic and advanced analyses that are impossible to perform in humans and whole-body mammalian models. By studying the signaling pathways of conserved sensors that monitor the homeostasis of secretory protein synthesis, this work will reveal new mechanisms that coordinate growth, stress responses and cell fate decisions and thus improve our understanding of human growth and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Guanylate-binding protein 2 (GBP2) is a major interferon-inducible GTPase that fights against microbial pathogens by disrupting their membranous replicative niche. Structural and mechanistic insights gleaned from this research will fill a major gap in the knowledge of pathogen detection and elimination by cell autonomous immunity and will shed light upon the design of new therapeutics for both infectious and autoinflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative! Accurate protein biogenesis is a pre-requisite for the generation and maintenance of a functional proteome, and is critical for preventing the onset of numerous diseases rooted in defective protein homeostasis. The proposed studies will advance our knowledge of the molecular and cellular mechanisms that ensure protein homeostasis within the cell, and contribute to the general understanding of physiology and pathology of eukaryotic cells at a fundamental level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use and misuse is rising in females, which makes it essential to identify female-specific risk factors for alcohol misuse. The proposed project will build a better understanding of cyclical changes in objective (heart rate variability) and subjective (self-reported) emotion regulation as a risk factor for cyclical alcohol misuse in females. By studying alcohol misuse changes across the most frequently-experienced reproductive sex steroid transition (i.e., the menstrual cycle), the results of this study will contribute critical information to NIAAA’s priorities for building a better understanding of alcohol misuse in females across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a critical public health problem; however, the mechanisms underlying opioid use and relapse are still poorly understood. Stress is a clinically significant but experimentally understudied, correlate/predictor of drug motivation, use, and relapse. The proposed study will use neuromodulation via repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), contrasted at two different, theoretically motivated frontal- cortical sites to examine mechanisms of pharmacological stress-induced opioid seeking in people with OUD and to explore potential targets for future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a major problem in the US, largely influenced by consumption of Western-style diets that modulate the gut microbiota. However, most research to date has emphasized bacteria within the gut, but has neglected to examine fungal communities. Thus, this project will investigate the impact of diet on the gut mycobiota and the specific effect of Candida on increasing fat absorption and obesity. This knowledge is expected to facilitate novel approaches targeting the gut mycobiome to increase quality of life and reduce health-care costs related to obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus), rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis and Sjogren’s syndrome are autoimmune diseases in which white blood cells produce inflammation in the kidneys (nephritis), joints (arthritis), skin (scaly patches) and glands (salivary in mouth and lacrimal in eyes (dry mouth and eyes), respectively. Current treatments for these diseases leave a large unmet need. By examining the cells of the involved tissues one cell at a time and learning which genes each cell expresses, we will identify new targets for drug development to treat these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the top cause of severe lower respiratory tract disease in young children worldwide. This proposal seeks to use atomic-level structural information on the RSV G protein to rationally engineer it as an effective vaccine antigen that protects against RSV infection and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE DNA sequences can form structures that are “difficult-to-replicate,” which can serve as barriers to DNA replication and repair and lead to genome instability and cancer. Our proposal is designed to characterize the role of DNA2/MutSα complex in overcoming specific difficult-to-replicate structures, called G-quadruplexes, during DNA replication or repair. Our results will define the cellular pathways and molecular mechanisms involved in overcoming G-quadruplexes, will affirm that individuals with defects in these pathways are more susceptible to cancer, and will provide a solid foundation for new cancer treatment regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Despite the fact that steroid hormone receptors (SRs) are the most targeted proteins in medicine for a wide variety of conditions, development of next generation tissue or cell-selective drugs is limited by lack of high- resolution 3D structures. To fully understand SR biology and therapeutic opportunities requires structure analyses of the native state full-length receptor and associated coregulatory proteins as a complex on target DNA and to determine how protein interactions modulate the conformation and activity of SRs. The overall goal of the project is to fill this major gap in our knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is an established treatment for patients with recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI), but its role in treating acutely ill patients with severe or fulminant CDI is uncertain. Important safety concerns also remain around FMT, including the potential for transmission of harmful microorganisms or possible development of chronic conditions such as diabetes or heart disease due to changes in gut microbes resulting from FMT. This research will help determine if FMT has a role in the treatment of acutely ill hospitalized patients with severe or fulminant CDI, assess techniques to identify potentially harmful microorganisms that may be transmitted by FMT, and see if chronic conditions develop more commonly years after FMT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small vessel disease (SVD) of the brain is a leading cause of stroke and disability, including vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID). By using a set of advanced optical imaging tools and a clinically relevant mouse model of the most common monogenic inherited form of SVD, CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy), we will elucidate the mechanisms of microvascular dysfunction and the missing link between small vessel dysfunction and their capacity to provide adequate brain tissue oxygenation. We hope that this work will fill significant gaps in our understanding of the mechanisms and consequences of microvascular dysfunction in CADASIL, and inform about the vascular mechanisms of progressive neurodegeneration and cognitive impairment in more common forms of SVD as well as in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE We will develop, use, and extensively share two critically important resources of cognitive, biomarker, genetic, and related data from cognitively unimpaired 50-90-year-old persons with each common form of APOE, the major AD susceptibility gene, representing six levels of risk. We will clarify the impact of APOE, other genetic and non-genetic factors, and their interactions on the predisposition to, protection from and potential prevention of AD, inform the design and size of 12 or 24-month prevention trials using biological outcome measurements, and demonstrate the value of extremely promising blood tests in these endeavors. We will provide an extensively shared resource of data, findings, biological samples, and motivated APOE-tested volunteers for the research community, support a wide range of other studies, and increase the chance that our Alzheimer's Prevention Initiative (API) will help find and support the accelerated approval of AD prevention therapies before 2025.

PHR: The proposed studies will conduct a systematic, comparative study on trophoblast from mice and bovine embryos, as well as human trophoblast cell culture models, focusing on a novel mechanism in trophoblast formation and gene expression. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We propose to use the newly developed small molecule KH-3 to evaluate HuR-targeted therapeutics for inhibition of renal inflammation and subsequent renal fibrosis by using animal models that resemble chronic kidney disease (CKD) in many ways seen in human patients. Successfully carried out, these results will serve as an important basis for translation into the clinical setting with improved potential for patient care for those living with, or at the risk of, progressive CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the success of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in decreasing mortality for HIV-1-infected patients, ART has not cured the disease. A persistent viral reservoir in the T cells of HIV patients receiving potent ART is a significant barrier preventing an HIV cure. Including scientists from leading universities and Merck Research Laboratories, Qura Therapeutics, Emmune, ViiV Healthcare and Macrogenics, the Collaboratory of AIDS Researchers for Eradication (CARE) will develop and testing therapies that will destroy the viral reservoir and allow ART-free remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative 6 million children in the US suffer from asthma, and the likelihood that any child will develop asthma depends heavily on their genetic and epigenetic regulations. My statistical machine learning models will identify new genetic and epigenetic risk factors that are associated with childhood asthma by regulating the expression of disease-causing or disease-preventing genes. This knowledge will help to advance precision medicine approaches to treating childhood asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Young women’s breast cancer is a particularly deadly disease, and biology related to weaning is the likely cause. With weaning, changes occur in the breast that are very similar to a healing wound and cause increased incidence of metastatic breast cancer in rodent models. The purpose of this research is to test the ability of ibuprofen and vitamin D to prevent these deadly postpartum breast cancers, using relevant rodent models and a unique collection of normal human breast tissue obtained from women during the lactation/weaning cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The core pillars of this project are aimed at increasing our understanding of mammalian consumption behavior, the rejection of toxins, and the principles of sensory coding. As such, the work is directly related to improving human health in this era of obesity and binge-eating. Using electrophysiology in freely moving and consuming animals, along with pioneering computational techniques, I will examine the influence that the main feeding region, the lateral hypothalamus, has on cortical taste processing and behavior, paving the way for future research on intervention in disorders relating to hedonics and consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mendelian conditions, which include diseases, but also include phenotypic differences that may not be considered a “disease,” are caused mainly by mutations in the protein-coding regions of the genome. Although the genes underlying thousands of Mendelian phenotypes have been identified, there are thousands of Mendelian conditions for which the gene(s) remain to be discovered. We propose to use an extensive network of clinicians and investigators, next generation sequencing coupled with new analytical paradigms, and technological innovations to efficiently discover novel genes for as many Mendelian conditions as possible.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol dependence and multiple withdrawal experiences are related to increased severity of alcohol use disorder, craving, and resistance to treatment. Studies proposed in this preclinical application take a multidisciplinary genetic, pharmacological, and molecular approach to elucidate the role of TARP γ-8, a novel AMPAR auxiliary protein, in the regulation of dependence-escalated alcohol self-administration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Protection of DNA against damages and errors are integral to maintaining genomic stability. Defects in DNA metabolic processes that replicate and repair the genome lead to genetic instability and chromosomal rearrangements causing cancers, aging, and inherited disorders. Replication Protein A is central to coordinating almost all DNA replication and repair processes in the cell and our work focuses on deciphering the underlying molecular mechanisms which can be exploited to develop novel chemotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This renewal application is aimed at continuing to prepare physicians for independent careers in the investigation and treatment of childhood psychiatric disorders. Such training and education programs are urgently needed. This need is based on the large number of children affected, the considerable costs to society associated with their care, the limited effectiveness of available treatment and prevention programs, the small number of physician-scientists active in the field, and the potential for significant scientific advances in the foreseeable future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastasis is the main cause of cancer-related deaths however no effective therapies exist to specifically target metastatic disease. Here we use a clinically relevant patient-derived model of melanoma metastasis to examine the role of different isoforms of NAD+ kinase in oxidative stress resistance during metastatic colonization. Our study will establish the role and regulation of a specific NAD+ kinase isoform in metastasizing melanoma cells and determine the role of subcellular oxidative stress in limiting metastatic spread.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: A wealth of information has been accumulated about individual biological machineries that read our genetic information, and a number of critical regulatory steps within this multi-step process have already been identified. Nonetheless, an understanding at the molecular and mechanistic level of the true composition of these large biological machineries and how their interactions are precisely controlled is far from complete. Using a multi- pronged approach, we propose to investigate these machineries in their native state to elucidate their regulation and interactions, and thereby, identify key therapeutic targets and generate reagents that may serve as drugs or as leads for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are the target of more than a third of drugs current prescribed in the clinic, and new GPCR targeting therapeutics hold the potential to significantly improve human health. Recent breakthroughs have identified a population of GPCRs which signal from endosomes as a new therapeutic drug target. Toward this end, we seek to understand the fundamental mechanisms of GPCR sorting and signaling at endosomes. By understanding how these processes operate, our studies aim to guide future drug development targeting endosomal GPCR signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tissue inflammation is central to a wide range of human diseases, including immune-mediated and autoimmune diseases such as Psoriatic Spectrum Disease, Rheumatoid Arthritis, Sjogren’s Syndrome, and Systemic Lupus Erythematosus. The key cell-states driving tissue inflammation are now being discovered. Here we propose a Systems Biology Core to enable the AMP AIM network to define these key cell states, their spatial localization, and their interactions with each other.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The  burden  of  frontotemporal  dementia,  amyotrophic  lateral  sclerosis,  and  other  TDP- 43- related  proteinopathies  including  Alzheimer’s  disease  is  large,  yet  no  effective  therapeutics  exist  to  effectively  slow  disease  onset  or  progression.  The  studies  outlined  in  this  proposal  will  allow  us  to  determine  the  molecular  mechanisms  underlying  the  regulation  of  lysosomal  gene  expression  in  neurons,  and  to  rigorously  test  the  therapeutic  potential  of  a  novel  approach  to  increase  lysosome  biogenesis  in  animal  models  of  TDP- 43  proteinopathy,  which  may  eventually  lead  to  the  development  of  improved  treatments  for  a  range  of  neurodegenerative diseases in the future.

PHR: As a result of their numerous and varied biological roles, RNA and DNA are drug targets and therapeutic agents. The critical insight gained will expand understanding of how genes are regulated, an important consideration in treating diseases like cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a major national shortage of qualified clinicians trained to conduct rigorous research in clinical pharmacoepidemiology, and in particular research focusing on drug safety and comparative effectiveness research/patient-centered outcomes research. This training program helps to address this shortage by providing clinicians with rigorous didactic training and the opportunity to conduct mentored research mentored by outstanding program faculty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is the second leading cause of death in adolescents and young adults, and identifying high-risk young people remains an immense challenge. The proposed research will employ machine learning-based approaches to test whether non-verbal behaviors (i.e., paralinguistic characteristics, spontaneous facial action, and head motion) exhibited during suicide assessments can be used to identify adolescents and young adults with recent suicidal ideation. This project may inform the development of an objective method of detecting suicide risk at scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Cytokine signaling is essential to immune function and is an area with great clinical therapeutic potential. Dozens of cytokine families have different roles in the immune system which all signal through their specific combinations Janus kinases (Jaks) and STAT proteins. We propose using biochemistry, biophysics, and protein engineering to understand how the different cytokine receptor families interact with the Jaks and STATs which will identify new targets for tuning cytokine signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eccrine sweat glands are a type of ectodermal appendage and are essential for human thermoregulation. This proposal builds on our previous work implicating the transcription factor Engrailed-1 as a major determinant of eccrine fate to interrogate the eccrine gland developmental program. The aims of this proposal are to define the transcription factors that regulate Engrailed-1 expression during eccrine gland placode specification and to determine the downstream cellular and molecular targets of Engrailed-1 which execute the differentiation of eccrine sweat glands from these primordia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women have a two-fold higher lifetime risk for Alzheimer Disease (AD), vascular dementia, and related dementias (RD) compared to men. Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, including preeclampsia, eclampsia, and gestational hypertension, may contribute to sex differences in ADRD, with midlife experiences such as depression influencing the magnitude of risk. We propose to 1) create a model that can identify AD and related dementias in a large health administrative database; and 2) test the link (and mediating factors) between hypertensive disorders of pregnancy and ADRD, which will serve as the first step towards creating women’s tailored intervention that can mitigate ADRD risk for women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To preserve their vision, glaucoma patients must take daily eye drop medications; and yet, 40% of patients do not do this, and 20% are unable to successfully instill the drops into their eyes. We will quantify and understand the movement factors influencing eye drop instillation success and use this information to inform the development of a scalable Eye Drop Adherence Monitoring System that measures each time eye drops are dispensed and whether the drops are successfully instilled into the eye. Accurate monitoring of eye drop adherence is an essential step towards providing effective support for people to self-manage their glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diagnostic assessment of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) has benefitted from the development of standardized assessment tools. However, recent research indicates that the diagnostic validity of commonly used instruments varies substantially as a function of child characteristics (e.g., biological sex, language level, cognitive ability, behavior problems). Leveraging information from assessments of more than 17,500 children, the proposed study will determine how to optimize use of standardized instruments, alone or in combination, for determining ASD diagnosis in specific subgroups of children for clinical or research purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is the most common cause of severe vision loss in the working-age population in the world, and the standard drug treatment is the intravitreal (IVT) injection of anti-VEGF agents that must be frequently administered and are not adequately responded by 40% DR patients. Oral administration of fenofibrate, a PPARα agonist, has shown robust therapeutic effects on DR in type 2 diabetic patients; however oral fenofibrate has poor retinal absorption and IVT injection of fenofibrate is short-lived, requiring frequent IVT injections. Here, we propose a new method to provide sustained delivery of fenofibrate to effectively and safely treat DR with 2 or less IVT injections/year, significantly reducing the treatment burden of diabetic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative During slow-wave of sleep and absence epilepsy, the brain is unresponsive to sensory input; the thalamic reticular nucleus is thought to focus this neural “searchlight” of arising sensory attention. Here, we will leverage optogenetic and photostimulation techniques to determine the specific functional topography of electrically coupled networks, which form the dominant synaptic connection within TRN. The method established here can be applied to easily and quickly map coupled interneuron networks throughout the brain.

PHR: Programming of child asthma and respiratory health is influenced by maternal exposures such as a woman’s lifetime stress and consequent oxidative stress, an underexplored mechanism of prenatal programming of child respiratory health. The planned approach may allow for detection of relationships that vary across racial/ethnic groups and contribute to novel prevention and treatment strategies.

The fundamental insights will advance our understanding of biological timing and may ultimately lead to novel chronotherapies against clock-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Genomic analysis of genome-edited cellular therapies is critical to ensure their safety and efficacy. However, current methods for measuring on-target editing efficiency and identifying unwanted somatic mutations use antiquated methods or require modifications to the editing process and so cannot be used to analyze cellular products that will be given to patients. In this application, we propose to optimize our recently described whole- genome sequencing assay for somatic mutations in cancer (ChromoSeq) so that it can be used for rapid, accurate, and comprehensive genomic evaluation of fully manufactured genome-edited cellular therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: NARRATIVE  Sexual minority adolescents (SMA) are disproportionately affected by mental health problems (e.g., depression, suicidality) relative to their heterosexual peers, which is generally attributed to unique interpersonal stressors (e.g., sexual orientation-related rejection). In addition to experiences of rejection, rejection sensitivity (RS; i.e., expectations of rejection accompanied by anxiety and/or anger) also plays an important role in mental health, but little is known about its development and role in SMA's mental health. As such, the goals of the proposed R01 are to: (1) Determine the longitudinal and daily relations among sexual orientation-related rejection, RS (anxious and angry), and mental health (depression, suicidal ideation, and reactive aggression); (2) Identify mechanisms (social withdrawal, self- and other-blame in response to rejection, and sexual orientation concealment) underlying the longitudinal and daily relations between RS and mental health problems; and (3) Examine sexual orientation-related social support and acceptance as protective factors in the development of RS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of people in need of a liver transplant far exceeds the number of suitable donor livers, yet every year a substantial proportion of donated livers are discarded because they contain too much fat. Livers that contain too much fat are more susceptible to transplant-related ischemia reperfusion injury (IRI) resulting in poorly functioning grafts, a process that is neither preventable nor easily reversed. The proposed research will offer key insights into how lipid metabolism and composition participate in hepatic IRI, with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic approaches to attenuate or prevent IRI, ultimately increasing organ availability and improving recipient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several electrogenic proteins critical for electrical excitation in cardiac tissue (including voltage-gated sodium channels, inward-rectifying potassium channels, L-type calcium channels, the sodium- potassium ATPase, and the sodium-calcium exchanger) reside in distinct ion channel “pools” within cells, with a subset of these channels critical for conduction preferentially localized at the site of cell- cell junctions, the intercalated disk. While recent evidence suggests that cardiac conduction is sensitive to perturbations at the intercalated disk, the contributions of these distinct ion channel pools and the intercalated disk nanoscale structure in regulating conduction under both normal and pathological conditions are not fully understood. We hypothesize that distinct ion channel pools on the lateral membrane and both at and within the intercalated disk, and intercalated disk structure constitute the key components of a “global/local control” system that regulate robust cardiac conduction, mitigating sensitivity to changes in ion channel and gap junction expression, and that this system of regulation is disrupted during pathological settings, including non-ischemic heart failure.

PHR: Narration Human skin exhibits regional specificities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The metabolic activity of tumors and the structure and composition of their surrounding microenvironment are crucial, poorly understood components of cancer progression. By developing whole cell spatially-resolved models of tumor metabolism we will test our capacity to faithfully simulate metabolic growth and activity in different settings. In the longer term, we envisage that our computational approach will enable forecast of patient- and site-specific tumor growth and progression, and facilitate the screening of therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Title: Structural and functional analysis of a novel class of androgen receptor antagonists Castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) is currently incurable and is the second leading cause of cancer death in American men. Androgen-independent activation of the androgen receptor (AR) remains the major driving force leading to CRPC. Structural and functional analysis of a novel class of AR antagonists capable of inducing AR degradation in the nucleus may lead to new therapeutics for CRPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Sugar-rich diets can promote disease by modifying gene expression and metabolism in the human gut microbiota. We are investigating how dietary sugar consumption silences the activity of a highly conserved bacterial transcription factor necessary for gut colonization. We have identified molecular determinants that control the activity of this transcription factor and propose to elucidate how host sugar consumption reduces its activity in vivo. Our study will reveal how modern industrialized diets influence the human gut microbiota and identify novel molecular targets to manipulate gut microbial composition and metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Autoimmune diseases affect up to 8% of the US population and its prevalence is rising, setting the stage for an impending public health crisis that we do not yet understand and are not prepared to face. We will leverage a multidisciplinary team of leading investigators, cutting edge tools designed for at-home, longitudinal tissue sampling, and an innovative strategy to discover how autoimmunity begins, relapses, and spreads in a large population of at-risk individuals. This approach will provide insight into autoimmunity that will help physicians better manage, or even prevent, devastating consequences of these diseases in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer immunosurveillance ascribes a role of cellular immunity in eliminating transformed cells. Cancer immunotherapy approaches exploiting such activity have produced durable responses in a subset of cancer patients. Experiments proposed in this project will define a novel regulatory process of immunosurveillance response mediated by tumor-associated macrophages, which can be targeted for therapy of a wide range of malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Occupational exposures in women who work during their pregnancies can lead to poor reproductive outcomes, such as miscarriages or fetal malformations. The objective of this study is to evaluate the direct and multigenerational effects of the engineered nanomaterial, nano-titanium dioxide, on reproductive outcomes in females and how those may be mediated by vascular and oxidative stress mechanisms after maternal inhalation exposure. The fundamental knowledge discovered in these studies, along with the career development pursued by the investigator, will be used to identify ways to better protect the reproductive health of female workers in occupational settings as well as their daughters and potentially sons.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Multi-generational Effects of Maternal Engineered Nano-Material Inhalation Exposure on Microvascular and Reproductive Health Outcomes
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative Healthcare-associated infections (HAI) and antibiotic resistance (AR) cause patient suffering. This proposal from the Duke-UNC Prevention Epicenters Program includes four lines of investigation to decrease HAI, AR, and patient harm related to a) environmental disinfection, b) antimicrobial stewardship, c) diagnostic stewardship, and d) community-associated Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). Utilizing unique collaborative, multicenter research infrastructure, these investigations aim to decrease risk for patients and will focus on novel strategies to prevent environmental contamination from hospital sinks, decrease overuse of antibiotics, improve utilization of urinalysis and urine culture for the diagnosis of urinary tract infections, and identify novel sources for community-associated CDI.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CK20-004, Duke-UNC Prevention Epicenter Program for Protecting Patients from Infections, Antibiotics Resistance and Other Adverse Events

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer is the leading cancer among women, accounting for one-third of diagnosed cancers. While sus- picious mammographic ﬁndings may be clariﬁed with ultrasound imaging, a subset of ultrasound images yield inconclusive results, necessitating biopsies or follow-up procedures, which increase patient anxiety and places an additional burden on the time and resources of our healthcare system. The goal of this project is to develop ultrasound technology that will resolve existing ambiguities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This longitudinal study examines the separate and combined population-level influences of nutrition policy interventions for schools and modifiable characteristics of food environments around schools on academic performance overall and related racial/ethnic disparities. The study will generate new evidence on the extent to population-level nutrition policy interventions targeted at the school environment reduce racial/ethnic gaps in academic performance, a strong predictor of education, which, in turn is a salient determinant of health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanistic target rapamycin mTOR complex 1 (mTORC1), an evolutionarily conserved protein kinase complex, functions as a central controller of cell growth and proliferation. This proposal will investigate new upstream regulators for cellular mTORC1 activity. Our overarching goals are to understand how ubiquitinated Rheb-centered menbraneless structure facilitates mTORC1 activation and amplifies specific downstream signaling essential for cell growth and proliferation and organ homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Currently, there is still a need for the development of novel treatments for asthma which can change the asthmatic disease course rather than simply manage it. Since around half of all asthmatics suffer from an allergic form of the disease, understanding how our body recognizes allergens may be important in trying to prevent the establishment of an allergic state and the progression to allergic asthma. The present study seeks to characterize how the protein LMAN1 recognizes and downregulates the inflammatory responses to allergens, which may, in turn, provide support for future targeting of LMAN1 for the treatment of allergic asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinx individuals in the US are lonelier than non-Latinx White individuals, and Latinx individuals who drink consume more alcohol, engage in more hazardous drinking, and experience disproportionately greater alcohol problems than White individuals who drink. This project will identify precursors of loneliness in hazardous- drinking Latinx individuals and explain the link between loneliness and the development of problem drinking in this population. This research will fill an important gap in explaining the underlying social-cognitive, behavioral, interpersonal, and cultural mechanisms contributing to loneliness and alcohol problems in Latinx individuals, and it will have broad application to many additional health disparity populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses a major health problem associated with enzalutamide-resistant prostate cancer (ERPC) which is currently incurable and is taking thousands of lives every year (~34,500 deaths projected for the year 2022) primarily because ERPC cells are resistant to available therapeutic regimen in the clinic. Interestingly, we found that a pseudokinase, called Tribbles 2 (Trib2), is overexpressed in ERPC cells and tumors and inhibition of Trib2 decreases the viability of ERPC cells, suggesting that Trib2 plays a seminal role in ERPC phenotype and that Trib2 may turn out to be an attractive, novel target for prevention and therapy of ERPC. Thus, this project has been designed, which is focused to understand the regulation and role of Trib2 in ERPC cells, and to examine the in vivo effects of targeting Trib2 using mouse models, with a goal to develop a new molecularly targeted therapeutic strategy against ERPC.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are common during pregnancy and can cause serious maternal and neonatal consequences, but current clinical guidelines fail to provide guidance for first trimester management of UTI due to uncertainty about the relative benefits and harms of commonly used antibiotic regimens. Our proposed study will evaluate the utilization, effectiveness, and safety of commonly-used antibiotic regimens in pregnant women treated for outpatient UTI. Ultimately, the evidence generated by this study will inform clinical guidelines and antibiotic prescribing, which will lead to better outcomes in pregnant women and infants, improved antimicrobial stewardship, and improved long-term bacterial susceptibility to antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Achievement of the project aims will put Trace-Ability in position to support all manufacturers of cancer PET drugs in their full capacity with a fully-automated QC solution. The impact in the field of Oncology will be manifested in increased availability of FDG and other cancer PET scans and facilitation of new tracer development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a devastating mental illness with limited treatment options. Recent large-scale genomic studies identified Foxp2 transcription factor as having a significant contribution to this and other psychiatric diseases, however, the molecular mechanisms by which Foxp2 contributes to PTSD symptomatology are unknown. I propose a mechanistic approach to define upstream mediators and downstream targets of Foxp2 within specific cell-types and circuits that are implicated in fear-related behaviors in adult mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed study is designed to improve our understanding of the development of neural and behavioral cognitive mechanisms and social processes that comprise the transdiagnostic phenotype of heightened performance monitoring and overcontrol (HPM/OC) in relation to early markers of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and social anxiety disorder (SAD). Using cutting-edge and cost-effective electroencephalogram (EEG) techniques, we will investigate these relationships using three yearly assessments in a large sample of children spanning 4-9 years of age to assess developmental trajectories of cognitive Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) constructs in the emergence of the HPM/OC phenotype and in relation to relevant social contexts and psychiatric impairment. The overarching goal is a better understanding of the neurodevelopment of the HPM/OC phenotype in order to identify children at highest risk for multiple forms of psychiatric illness and to inform novel interventions that directly target the cognitive and social mechanisms of HPM/OC for optimal early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Xylazine, an animal tranquilizer, has been increasingly detected in opioids throughout the eastern United States, Puerto Rico, and Canada. Xylazine may increase the risk of opioid-related overdose or death and is associated with the development of severe infected ulcerating skin lesions in both injection and non-injection sites. This project is expected to significantly contribute to informing optimal harm reduction interventions that can be rapidly implemented to mitigate harms associated with xylazine adulteration.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Periodontal diseases are disorders associated with non-resolving inflammation affected by, and a risk factor for, other systemic diseases including diabetes. Effective treatments for periodontal disorders are needed to preserve both oral and systemic health. We aim to synthesize nitric-oxide, hyaluronic acid-based materials for localized oral delivery; delineate the mechanisms modulating microbial dysbiosis, immune dysfunction and tissue-stasis; and, test therapeutic efficacy for inhibiting periodontal disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T-cells are cell-based therapies that are being investigated as a novel immunotherapy treatment for several forms of cancer including glioblastoma. We propose to combine clinical imaging techniques to measure interstitial fluid flow with predictive modeling with the goal of characterizing barriers to optimal CAR T-cell administration and to identify imaging biomarkers for evaluation and prediction of clinical response to CAR T-cell therapy. Thus, we will be able to determine the best strategy for treating patients with this innovative and promising clinical treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disparities in access to care and inadequate insurance contribute to the disparities in behavioral health diagnoses and treatment for racial and ethnic minority children with special health care needs (CSHCN). Our study will examine the extent to which automatic enrollment in Medicaid via Supplemental Security Income (SSI) reduces these disparities. Using two complementary analytic sources with large-scale survey and administrative data, our findings will provide critical insights about how reducing administrative burden may improve health equity for disadvantaged and underserved CSHCN with behavioral health needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss and balance disorders are significant health problems worldwide, with many disorders having genetic causes. The research proposed in this study will utilize DNA and tissue samples from individuals with genetic hearing loss to develop protocols and methods for gene therapies. Mice engineered with the same pathogenic variants resulting in hearing and balance problems will provide the means for testing our innovative gene therapy approaches for genetic hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to characterize the relationship between late-onset epilepsy (epilepsy starting at age 60 or later, in the absence of stroke or other identified cause) with cognitive changes and AD biomarkers, hypothesizing that patients with late-onset epilepsy are at risk for cognitive decline and may have preexisting neuropathology. The results will be used to identify patients at risk for cognitive impairment who may benefit from clinical trials, and will contribute to scientific knowledge about the nature of late-onset epilepsy and its implication for future cognitive changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Brain arteriolosclerosis (B-ASC), the pathologic thickening of small blood vessels in the brain, is a common contributor of cognitive decline in aged individuals, but the genetic risk factors are poorly understood. This project will identify multi-omic risk factors of B-ASC and identify the shared genetic risk between B-ASC and associated neuropathologies. Findings will provide mechanistic insight into B-ASC and identify potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the 6.2 million U.S. adults living with heart failure (HF), the burden of poor quality of life, high symptom burden, complex treatment decisions, and frequent hospitalizations on patients, family caregivers, and the healthcare system is significant and growing; by 2030, the prevalence of HF is projected to exceed 8 million adults with direct healthcare costs ballooning to over $77 billion annually. Despite recent guidelines recommending the early introduction of palliative care to address these considerable burdens, the development of efficacious and scalable palliative care interventions for this population remains sluggish. The proposed training and research application aligns with the NINR Strategic Plan and aims to optimize an early palliative care intervention to maximally benefit quality of life among underserved individuals living with advanced HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging data demonstrate that most people with epilepsy are more likely to have seizures at certain times of the day. However, the mechanisms that underlie these daily rhythms in seizures remain unclear. This proposal seeks to leverage the power of the fly model system to identify underlying cellular and circuit mechanisms, with the end goal of identifying novel therapeutic targets and improving our ability to predict seizure occurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as it focuses on the function of genes related to autism spectrum disorder, which affects over 1 in 59 American children. The purpose of this study is to understand how integrin beta 3, an autism susceptibility gene, is necessary for the proper formation of brain circuits. Therefore, this research will provide fundamental knowledge about the brain that will inform new strategies for treating autism spectrum disorder and other neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of O6-methylguanine methyltransferase (MGMT) expression is common in cancers and confers sensitivity  to DNA alkylators, such as temozolomide (TMZ). Clinically, MGMT promoter demethylation is rare, whereas  MMR mutations occur frequently as a dominant mechanism of resistance to TMZ in many tumor types. KL50  Therapeutics, LLC is developing MGMT dependent–MMR independent alkylating agents that are anticipated to  possess the positive attributes of TMZ, while circumventing the unavoidable MMR loss mediated resistance  mechanism and, thereby, have a major impact on the way we treat GBMs and other tumors lacking MGMT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinitis Pigmentosa is a blindness disease in which rod phtoreceptors, which are necessary for night vision, degenerate due to inherited mutations, and subsequently, cone photoreceptors, which provide humans with daylight color vision, degenerate for unknown secondary reasons. In mouse models of Retinitis Pigmentosa, which recapitulate the human disease progression, the disease progression is recapitulated, but interestingly, some cone photoreceptors in the peripheral retina survive long-term. By elucidating the molecular and cellular mechanisms that impart survival to the peripheral cone photoreceptors, this proposed research aims to develop novel therapeutic approaches to promote cone survival in all regions of the retina, leading to preservation of daylight color vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This program is a multidisciplinary, collaborative effort between investigators at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the New England Eye Center. The program will develop next-generation optical coherence tomography (OCT) technology for structural and blood flow imaging and perform studies in early, intermediate and late age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The objective is to better understand the mechanisms of disease and to identify structural and blood flow features in the eye that can improve diagnosis and monitoring, predict risk and accelerate pharmaceutical development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Poor recovery from orthopaedic injury, including severe pain and impaired bone healing, affects millions of Americans. Myeloid-lineage cells (peripheral macrophages and spinal cord microglia) are mobilized to resolve tissue damage, however, persistent activation of these cells can be detrimental by contributing to pain and delayed healing. This work aims to develop approaches to monitor dysfunctional myeloid-lineage cells and modulate specific targets for novel therapeutics that will improve post-injury recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO INST OF MINING & TECHNOLOGY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant improvements in mine emergency response, self-escape and mine rescue operations are still high-risk operations with potentially devastating consequences. We propose to design and develop new autonomous and AI-based technologies and strategies to improve mine evacuation and mine rescue. We will incorporate the outcomes of the project into a comprehensive AR/VR and hybrid training products for mine emergencies.

PROJECT_TITLE: Design and demonstration of intelligent mine evacuation and mine rescue system

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. mining industry remains one of the most dangerous and challenging environments for workers according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), and the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA). BLS and MSHA show that mining fatality rate is five times higher than other U.S. industries with an average of 36 fatalities per year within 2009 and 2018. This research initiative will reduce miners’ risk of traumatic injuries and fatalities in underground mine emergencies via new wireless communication, improved human-robot interactions, and refuge alternatives, and mine fire and explosions response and evacuation management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The REPRIEVE trial assesses whether statins can prevent heart disease in people with HIV, a group at increased risk for heart attack and stroke, but without an established prevention strategy. REPRIEVE also determines the impact of statins on plaque in the arteries of the heart and blood markers of inflammation, and characterizes the COVID-19 pandemic in HIV. REPRIEVE completed enrollment of 7,770 participants in 2019; the proposed REPRIEVE extension will provide necessary time to collect the heart attack and stroke events crucial to address the REPRIEVE aims.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed preclinical studies will investigate the consequences of blast-induced traumatic brain injury (TBI), one of the most important issues facing our Veterans. We propose to conduct a comparative study of the effect of and recovery from blast tube induced injury in eight strains of mice that capture more than 90% of the genetic variation in commonly used laboratory mice. This work will improve our understanding of genes that contribute to variations in susceptibility and/or recovery from TBI, and thus will benefit the long-term health of our Veteran population by laying the foundation for future mechanism-based studies of therapeutic agents to blunt neurodegenerative sequelae and promote functional restoration following blast-TBI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Gastric cancer is the second most common cause of cancer-related death worldwide. American military actions often expose soldiers to areas with higher prevalence for gastric cancer and increasingly immigrants from high gastric cancer regions in South America are playing a greater role in the US military. Thus, gastric cancer represents a probable increased risk for future Veterans. Given the dismal overall survival for patients with gastric cancer, identification of pre-cancerous lesions and the development of strategies to arrest the progression or even reverse these changes is a high priority. The present proposed investigations seek to establish a greater knowledge of the induction and reversibility of pre-cancerous metaplastic changes in the stomach and evaluate novel approaches to arresting pre-cancerous changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Dementia (AD) is a leading cause of cognitive dysfunction and death, but is lacking effective treatment. Cellular senescence has recently been implicated in age related disease pathology, including AD. The work outlined in this proposal will provide insight into the role of a newly described senescent cell population that may lead to a better understanding of AD and the development of new AD therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circadian rhythm disruption is a common feature of Alzheimer’s disease and one of the major causes of patient institutionalization. A common mouse model of the disease has been found to exhibit a phenomenon known as circadian reprogramming, in which a subset of genes loses circadian expression while another subset gains circadian expression. This project will determine how transcription factors coordinate circadian reprogramming and generate novel circadian expression within the context of neurodegeneration, which will provide novel insight into how Alzheimer’s disease progresses and potentially uncover new pathways to alter disease course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative Successful completion of these studies will identify the cellular sources of a protein, known as osteoprotegerin, that inhibits bone loss. In addition, the proposed studies may identify the cause of the rapid bone loss following discontinuation of a common type of osteoporosis therapy known as denosumab. In the long-term, these studies may identify strategies to prevent bone loss due to a variety of conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans have dormant cells capable of limited regeneration, harnessing this potential requires a deeper understanding of how these cells form during development and how they are maintained in adults. The model tunicate Ciona, an invertebrate closely related to humans, shares many of our chordate genes and signaling pathways, and can use these shared mechanisms to reformulate its nervous system and regenerate its entire brain. The goal of this proposal is to shed new light on novel genetic mechanisms to control stem cells.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hormones and neurotransmitters, as well as most pharmaceuticals, do not act in isolation but are subject to feedback regulation and cross-talk from other signaling pathways, including those that sense nutrients such as glucose. Our long term objective is to understand how cells respond to hormones under changing physiological circumstances and to predict how those circumstances affect pharmacological responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This application proposes to investigate the “clues” that can be found in HIV-1 patients that describe their likelihoods to develop resistance to Env-targeting therapeutics. Our published and preliminary studies have revealed that each strain of HIV-1 has an inherent and measurable propensity for mutations to appear at Env sites that mediate escape from each therapeutic, which can be calculated using sequence properties of the protein in an infected individual. These investigations have the potential to facilitate personalized antiviral treatment by establishing the tools to quantify the likelihood of each patient to develop resistance to each agent before initiation of therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perturbations of the intercellular signaling systems that control organ growth are a major source of human disease, associated with a wide range of developmental, physiological disorders as well as most forms of cancer. The proposed research is relevant to public health because solving how such systems normally function to direct as well as terminate growth as organs develop is essential for the development of more effective diagnostic and therapeutic treatments for this enormously broad range of afflictions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission to reduce the burden to society arising from genetic and environmental disorders of fundamental aspects of human development and physiology.

PHR: NARRATIVE The goals of I4C 2.0 are to advance our scientific understanding of the viral reservoir and to develop immunologic strategies for HIV-1 remission and eradication by a highly collaborative and multifaceted research program. We will evaluate combinations of state-of-the-art immunologic strategies aimed at either long-term, ART-free virologic control or complete virus eradication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective interpersonal communication is associated with improved health related outcomes, yet it is unclear to what extent this occurs in triadic clinic visits in dementia, and few tools exist to support it. The objective of this project is to characterize the extent to which interpersonal communication occurs during triadic visits in dementia, examine how this is related to health outcomes and use this understanding to adapt an innovative clinic visit audio recording intervention, HealthPAL for use in this setting. The results are expected to have a major positive impact by providing a rich understanding of communication during triadic visits in dementia, and proof-of-principle of the usability, feasibility, and acceptability of visit audio recording to enhance interpersonal communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histone proteins are essential for all DNA-dependent processes and misregulation of histones contributes to chromatin-based aging defects. This proposal aims to determine the function of variant histone H3.3 in aging cells and to gain mechanistic insight into how canonical and variant histones cooperate to regulate genome function. The principles uncovered from these studies will increase our fundamental understanding of histone regulation and could inform the development of therapeutic pathways to improve healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knee osteoarthritis results in more years lived with disability compared to any other musculoskeletal condition representing a critical public health problem. By determining the biomechanical consequences of muscle fatigue in older adults with knee osteoarthritis, this project will address a knowledge gap related to the mechanisms for this disability. Our mechanistic investigation of muscle fatigue in an osteoarthritic, aging population will identify promising targets for interventions to mitigate or prevent fatigue and related mobility declines, as such, this project is highly relevant to the missions of NIH and NIA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Understanding how the brain creates memories remains one of the greatest challenges in neuroscience research. The goal of this research project is to identify the cellular and network mechanisms which allow for visual recognition memory. Elucidating these mechanisms will not only provide a deeper understanding of normal brain function, but will also provide insight into disorders where visual perception, learning and memory are disrupted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE

PHR: Project Narrative Region 3 of the Network of the National Library of Medicine (NNLM), hosted by Gibson D. Lewis Library at the University of North Texas Health Science Center (UNTHSC) in Fort Worth, Texas, will serve the states of Arkansas, Kansas, Louisiana, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma, and Texas. The Regional Medical Library (RML) supports the mission of the NNLM to provide health professionals, the public health workforce, educators, and the public with equal access to biomedical and health information resources and data. The RML will offer diverse trainings, funding mechanisms, and regional and national programming, with a focus on collaboration and continuous assessment to develop a highly-trained workforce and serve as trusted ambassadors between the National Library of Medicine and the communities they serve.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Perianal fistulizing complications of Crohn’s disease are common and morbid, which are routinely treated with prolonged and frequent antibiotic courses, despite lack of evidence for efficacy. This proposed multicenter study is relevant to improving the appropriate use of antibiotics by promoting antibiotic stewardship and decreasing healthcare related infections, because it focuses on treating and preventing perianal fistulas and abscess through developing multi-disciplinary comprehensive evidence-based treatment guidelines for the judicious use of antibiotics while improving care for children with Crohn’s disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of AHRQ’s mission to produce evidence to make health care safer and higher quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching objective of this project is to enable multimodal noninvasive stimulation and recording of human brain circuits with high anatomical and temporal precision. The project is to create a closed-loop brain interface that integrates simultaneous neural recording and high-fidelity MRI acquisition with steerable transcranial stimulation. The proposed brain interface is a new noninvasive tool for studying human brain circuits in vivo and for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sepsis is the second leading cause of death in non-coronary intensive care units (ICUs) and is in the top ten causes of death in the U.S. Acute Lung Injury (ALI) and Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) are common complications of sepsis Despite advances in treating sepsis, specific therapies are not available and clinical trials using the FDA-approved Xigris (recombinant form of human activated protein C) and Eritoran (a TLR4-MD2 antagonist) have not been successful. The goal of this project is to boost the innate immune system so that the host cells will function better to eradicate bacterial pathogens in organs due to sepsis-induced systemic infection in order to mitigate excessive tissue damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because sixty percent of arteriovenous fistulas created in hemodialysis patients in the United States fail to mature for successful use on hemodialysis. Improving the understanding of the pathogenesis of arteriovenous fistula maturation failure will lead to development of new therapies to treat this important clinical problem, and will help reduce the use of hemodialysis catheters. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge to help reduce morbidity and mortality for patients on hemodialysis requiring a vascular access.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Post-Doctoral Training Program in Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities (IDD) Research provides interdisciplinary biobehavioral training focused on IDD and prepares trainees for a career of research in this area. IDD are a diverse group of conditions that affect 6.99% of U.S. children; the scientific workforce focused on IDD research is considerably smaller than the magnitude of this public health need, creating an urgency for training programs to develop new investigators in this field. The success of our training program is evidenced by the high rate of placement of “graduates" in faculty and research-intense positions, the success of former trainees in receiving research awards by NIH and other federal sources, the expansive volume of publications by our trainees in top-tier journals, and the longstanding fidelity of our trainees to IDD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to inform clinical trials by providing a new tool (i.e., practice effects on measures of daily functioning) for predicting cognitive progression in seniors with and without cognitive impairment. By completing this pragmatic project, we would be able to offer more efficient screening of potential participants for clinical trials, which would reduce participant burden and financial costs associated with these trials. Practice effects also have considerable clinical benefits for diagnosis and prognosis of cognitive disorders in late life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This new projects will explore the role of the Long Interspersed Nuclear Element-1 (LINE-1, or L1) in type I interferon-mediated SLE. We will continue to characterize autoantibodies against L1-encoded proteins, ask how early in the disease they appear, how L1 transcription is upregulated in SLE, which cells that express it, and if the L1 expressing cells also contain reverse-transcribed RNA and interferon beta. Finally, we will test inhibitors of L1 reverse transcriptase in these cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 30,000 Americans die from hepatocellular (liver) carcinoma (HCC) every year and current treatments do not provide long-term benefit, highlighting the urgent need for new and effective therapies. We have discovered that a protein called EZH2 is required for the growth of HCC tumors, and found that inhibiting EZH2 not only blocks HCC tumor growth but also enhances the ability of the immune system to eradicate the tumor. The results of the experiments proposed in this application will establish the mechanism by which EZH2 functions as an HCC oncogene and evaluate EZH2 inhibitors, alone or in combination with other anti-cancer drugs, as novel HCC therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on understanding the mechanisms of pancreatic β-cells senescence and the optimal strategy to therapeutically target them. Cell autonomous and non-cell autonomous mechanisms will be studied in biologically relevant models such as primary human and rodent islets. Achievement of the proposed aims will advance our knowledge of senescence biology in a highly metabolically relevant cell type with important implications for type 2 diabetes mellitus.
