IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Lay Summary  Goals of this study are to define the local factors that promote normal repair and block aberrant tissue remodeling and loss of lung function in patients with respiratory viral infections and chronic lung disease. We will define roles for alveolar epithelial lipocalin-2 in recruitment of airway basal cells to injured alveoli and roles for airway basal cells and their secreted factors in modulation of alveolar stem/progenitor cell function. Completion of this work will provide new insights into mechanisms of declining lung function in patients with acute or chronic lung disease and may allow development of novel interventions to improve outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Two out of three people in the United States are impacted by cardiometabolic diseases (CMDs), which collectively cost the country hundreds of billions of dollars annually. Hispanics/Latinos are disproportionally afflicted by CMDs and disproportionately suffer from CMD complications. This proposal will investigate CMD trajectory arising from individual metal/metalloid exposures and their mixture in an established cohort of Hispanics/Latinos in order to identify modifiable risk factors for these conditions and to aid prevention strategies for this high risk, underrepresented population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Models of hospital addiction consultation and linkage to community-based treatment following discharge from inpatient hospitalization may be an effective approach in reducing the adverse health and economic consequences of the opioid epidemic. Information generated from economic evaluations of such healthcare models will promote successful implementation in representative public hospital settings. The goal of this project is to identify the resources/costs required to implement and sustain such a model, disseminate a costing tool for stakeholders to assess viability in their specific health system, the extent to which the intervention costs could be offset by outcomes related to increased engagement in opioid use disorder treatment, and calculate its economic value to both patients and health systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obesity has dramatically increased the burden of cardiovascular disease, and a major goal of the NIH/NIDDK is to reduce this burden. The goal of this application is to discover how to target liver estrogen pathways to improve glucose and lipid abnormalities in obesity and diabetes, which is expected to help reverse the impact of obesity on cardiovascular risk. Our project identifies pathways that mediate sex differences in cardiovascular disease, which is also an NIH priority area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Chemical changes to our genetic information that do not change the underlying DNA sequence itself are referred to as “epigenetic” changes, and are increasingly being recognized to be altered in a wide range of lung diseases. How these epigenetic alterations contribute to the onset or progression of these diseases, and whether we can modify the epigenome to treat lung diseases remains largely unknown. This proposal will define how the SWI/SNF complex establishes patterns of chromatin accessibility (a type of epigenetic change) during development of the lung epithelium, and how these same patterns are modified by the SWI/SNF complex following repair after lung injury in the adult.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Young sexual and gender minorities who have sex with men (YSGMSM) carry a disproportionate burden of the HIV epidemic in the United States, yet Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) uptake and adherence has been inadequate for these groups despite evidence that it is safe and effective at reducing HIV transmission for YSGMSM. Syndemics theory is used to characterize convergent and mutually reinforcing social (e.g., race), structural (e.g., neighborhood poverty), and digital (e.g., social media consumption, access to internet) factors impacting HIV risk in YSGMSM. This proposal incorporates this syndemics approach into iTech’s P3 study, an NICHD-funded RCT to improve PrEP adherence among YSGMSM, to understand how convergent digital and neighborhood factors impact PrEP adherence in YSGMSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical care following peripheral nerve injuries is currently limited to a “wait and watch” approach based on patient history and/or physical exam, increasing the likelihood of losing motor and sensory function following these injuries. To address this limitation, we propose a program of innovative, technical developments that will provide a set of quantitative magnetic resonance imaging parameters for characterizing peripheral nerves fol- lowing injury and after surgery. If successful, these new strategies could identify injuries that require surgery and predict surgical failures much earlier than current techniques, improving outcomes for patients with periph- eral nerve injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it reveals a compensatory plasticity mechanism induced by cell death that could be harnessed as a treatment strategy to promote vision in photoreceptor degenerative diseases where compensation does not naturally occur. Secondly, this work will define the time course of constructive and destructive remodeling in the inner retina to better understand expected prognoses of retinitis pigmentosa diseases and their treatment outcomes by photoreceptor or optogenetic rescue therapies. Thus, this research is relevant to NEI’s goal to understand how plasticity and rewiring impacts signaling between photoreceptors and neurons and how this could be harnessed in degenerative disease and injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Koch PPG – Overall Program NARRATIVE Heart Failure remains a major health problem world-wide and there are gaps in research that are needed to be filled in order to develop innovative treatments to minimize cardiac injury and repair the failing heart. Understanding molecular mechanisms, and gender differences involved in cardiac injury and repair is imperative in order to begin to develop these novel therapies. This includes how the injured heart communicates to distant organs to create co-dependent pathologies such as cardiorenal syndrome and all projects within this Program Project have goals to move towards translating discoveries into development of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Research on wearable sensing technologies have predominantly focused on electronics-based systems; however, the most common forms of point-of-care or at-home devices remain simple, electronics-free approaches. This project will focus on understanding and enhancing the safety and efficacy of a new class of spray-on polymeric sensor that produces a visual color change in response to target stimuli as customized by its chemical functionality. In doing so, this work toward development of a low-cost, easy-to-use, and widely deployable spray-on sensor technology platform will lead to future implementations as a discreetly wearable device for health and environmental exposure monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH One of the most potentially profound, but usually overlooked, aspects of public health interventions is the possibility that the intervention will change not only the behavior of individuals in a community, but the social structure of the community itself, even affecting people who were not targets of the intervention. This project will build on an existing RCT and create a new and very unusual dataset, capturing how the structures of real-world networks and the position of aging adults within them change over time in response to a randomized exposure to a health intervention. We will use this data set to answer important questions about how the positions, roles, and health of older adults are affected by public health interventions. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. Inefficient communication among providers and caregivers of community-dwelling persons living with dementia (PLWD) can allow minor health issues to escalate into medical emergencies, resulting in increased hospitalizations, emergency department visits, and significant costs to health systems. The proposed application supports the Principal Investigator in acquiring requisite training to inform the development and preliminary testing of a user-centered mobile health (mHealth) application that facilitates communication among adult day service centers, caregivers, and primary care providers around the needs of PLWD. In doing so, this study works toward national goals of reducing fragmentation in health care delivery, optimizing care quality and efficiency, and expanding support for PLWD and their families, especially those in diverse communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In some genes the sequence which is read (“expressed”) in a cell can be altered by a mechanism known as RNA splicing. In this study, we will identify genetic variants that contribute to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) by altering RNA splicing. This will result in greater understanding of the ways that genetic factors contribute to COPD, and this information might be used to identify and develop new COPD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PET and calcium imaging with fiber photometry will be used to investigate how alterations in dopamine D3 receptor and metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGlu5) signaling impact cocaine-relevant decision-making behaviors in rats. Aim 1 will investigate the relationship between individual differences in midbrain dopamine D3 and neural activity in meso-cortico-limbic circuits during decision making and cocaine self-administration. Aim 2 will assess neural activity in select cortico-striatal circuits during decision making before and after cocaine to determine how disruptions in mGlu5 signaling mediate addiction-relevant (seeking/taking) behaviors and alter decision-making behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polygenic Risk Scores (PRS) combine information across numerous genetic variants to improve disease prediction; however, lack of diversity in PRS research to date threatens applicability in non-European ancestry individuals. The NHGRI Polygenic Risk Score Diversity Consortium will conduct collaborative data integration, analysis, and methods development in existing research cohorts to improve PRS prediction across diverse populations. As Coordinating Center for the Consortium, we will perform genotype and phenotype data harmonization, lead collaborative analysis, contribute to methods development, help identify Ethical, Legal, and Social Implications (ELSI) of PRS, facilitate data sharing, and coordinate program logistics and outreach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 1 in 4 deaths among elderly patients in the U.S. occur following an ICU admission, during which patients often spend their final days incapacitated and connected to various forms of life support. These patients’ family members suffer psychological distress when faced with decisions about whether to transition from life-prolonging treatment to comfort-focused treatment when it becomes clear that a patient’s health goals cannot be achieved. We will conduct a randomized trial to determine whether a scalable, interactive tool can help lessen the psychological burden on family members and improve the quality of care provided older adults in ICUs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The genomics workforce faces a shortage of people with data science skills and is also lacking diverse representation. These problems impact the quality of research being conducted, and the lack of diversity leads toward both explicit and implicit bias within genomics data sets and among those conducting research. The UW-GRTDS will address these problems by recruiting diverse trainees with data science skills, thereby helping to diversify the genomics workforce and promoting a higher quality of genomics research for the benefit of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia worldwide and is characterized by the presence of extracellular senile plaques in the brain that are composed of aggregations of small peptides called beta- amyloid (Aβ). We hypothesize that microglia, which are the immune cells of the brain, contribute to clearance of Aβ via a process called autophagy, but this process is impaired in AD. Here we will examine how specific small non-coding RNAs (miRNA) alter expression of key proteins that participate in autophagy process and we will test whether reducing the expression of a specific miRNA can correct autophagy, restore degradation of Aβ, and reduce AD pathobiology.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE South Africa has among the highest incidence of HIV-associated tuberculosis in the world, with this condition and COVID-19 being leading causes of death in South Africa. This application seeks renewal of the Fogarty HIV- associated Tuberculosis Training Program through which the University of Cape Town is partnering with Vanderbilt University Medical Center and Johns Hopkins University to provide research training opportunities to develop the next generation of researchers working on the epidemiology, treatment issues and immunology of HIV and tuberculosis as well as HIV and COVID-19 interactions. In this Training Program we will place strong emphasis on training clinician scientists/researchers, attracting medical students to HIV-associated tuberculosis and HIV-associated COVID-19 research, and on demographic transformation of the research platform to redress disparities persisting from apartheid.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative This R25 Research Education Program (renewal of R25 AG053227) proposes to continue both the annual week- long summer workshop on integrating genomic and social science data, Genomics for Social Scientists (GeSS), as well as the annual 4-day course specifically focused on epigenetic data. These two annual courses, a series of online modules, and web-based resources will continue to build the capacity of social and behavioral scientists of aging to understand and collaborate on genomic research using NIH-funded resources, such as the Health and Retirement Study. Investing in the education of social and behavioral scientists and developing tools and trainings that are relevant to their entry into genetic research will more fully realize the potential of the millions of dollars that have been spent on adding biological data to social science studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a request for a new R25 award to support summer experiences at the Medical College of Wisconsin (MCW) in Milwaukee for undergraduate students from underrepresented groups (URGs) in science and medicine to receive hands-on cardiovascular research experiences, training in science-related skills, education about careers available in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), and learn tools for breaking down barriers, thriving, and resilience that are tailored to the trainee’s intended career path of becoming a physician, a scientist, or working in another STEM-related career. MCW receives 200 to 300 more applications each spring semester from undergraduates from URGs than available summer positions so there is great need at MCW for federal support of this R25, and the MCW Cardiovascular Center has 36 well-trained, well-funded faculty mentors available within its four areas of research expertise in which to provide this training: 1) atherosclerosis, thrombosis, and vascular biology (plaque, blood clots, and blood vessel health), 2) cardiac biology and heart failure (heart structure and function), 3) cardio-oncology (cancer’s effects on heart and blood vessel health), and 4) hypertension (high blood pressure). At a time when the burden of cardiovascular disease continues to rise and the diversification of the biomedical workforce is greatly needed, our training program is designed to inspire and fully-equip our undergraduate trainees from URGs for future careers within STEM, especially in areas related to cardiovascular research, thereby enhancing the diversity of the future biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The NHLBI’s Bench to Bassinet Program (B2B) was launched to accelerate pediatric cardiovascular translational research from discovery to early translational testing to clinical testing. The B2B is comprised of the Pediatric Cardiac Genomics Consortium (PCGC), the Cardiovascular Developmental Biology Data Resource Center (CDDRC), and the Pediatric Heart Network (PHN). Objectives of the PCGC are to identify genetic causes of human congenital heart disease and to relate genetic variants present in the congenital heart disease patient population to clinical outcomes. The CDDRC will expand the use of data previously generated by the B2B Cardiovascular Development Consortium (CvDC) to a broader number of data scientists by assembling the data into a queryable data repository complete with computational tools. The Administrative Coordinating Center (ACC) provides the infrastructure to enhance collaborations among the PCGC, CDDRC, and the PHN to identify and facilitate the translational research process for the most important pediatric cardiovascular clinical care problems. Our proposed ACC to support the PCGC and CDDRC is a unique, integrated combination of world-leading pediatric cardiovascular clinical/translational research expertise, advanced infrastructure, outstanding institutional support, and state-of-the-art technology. We believe these strengths to be critical for an ACC to successfully partner with the B2B program and NHLBI in leading the coordination of knowledge and data for this important pediatric cardiovascular research effort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Microglia cells are the innate component of the brain’s immune system and have an important role in maintaining homeostasis of neuronal function under physiological condition and mediating an inflammatory response after neuronal injury. Ischemic stroke elicits a strong neuroinflammatory response characterized by massive microglia activation. The data gained in this research proposal will have important implications for developing novel therapeutic interventions to mitigate cerebral ischemia by targeting the modulation of the neuroinflammatory response following stroke via TGF-β signaling modulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the known dangers of air pollution to children with asthma, physicians have few tools to identify and integrate information on a patient’s environmental and social stressors into clinical medicine. The goals of this research project are to understand the relationship between the following: 1) environmental estimates of air pollution and urinary air pollutant biomarkers, and 2) the role of biological and geospatial air pollutant markers, stress on asthma morbidity. Successful completion of this project will produce an Asthma Integrated Risk (AIR) Clinical Prediction model that incorporates these data sources in order to provide clinicians an effective tool to assess a patient’s integrated host, social and environmental risk for asthma morbidity and improve the health of inner city children with asthma.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: Tanzania faces an unfinished HIV testing, treatment, and viral suppression agenda because of implementation gaps, particularly in children, adolescents, and young adults and is also in the early stages in determining how to best integrate prevention, screening, and care for non-communicable diseases into HIV programs. The long-term success of HIV care and treatment programs and achievement of the HIV targets in Tanzania can be ensured and improved through the HIV Implementation Science training program – a joint initiative by the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health in Boston and Muhimbili University of Health and Allied Sciences (MUHAS) in Dar es Salaam that will build research capacity on rigorous Implementation Science, Impact Evaluation, and Health Systems Research methods to test the performance of approaches, structures, and programs in the delivery of HIV interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: K07 Project Narrative With the number of U.S. family caregivers shrinking and the demands on their health and wellbeing increasing, we are facing a family caregiver public health crisis. By connecting new and established interdisciplinary researchers, we can spark new and innovative solutions for the benefit of family caregivers and their care recipients. This K07 Academic Leadership Career Award proposes to formalize connections and promote collaborations across disciplines and academic entities at the University of Utah and Utah Health Sciences to provide the necessary infrastructure, mentoring, content and methodologic expertise to improve the support of family caregivers of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The active movement of proteins, vesicles, and organelles along the extended axons of neurons is called axonal transport, and is essential to maintain healthy motor and sensory neurons, which have axons that can extend up to a meter in humans. Defects in axonal transport cause neurodegeneration, and occur in diseases such as Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS or Lou Gehrig's Disease) or Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease. We are investigating the molecular mechanisms regulating axonal transport and organelle dynamics in neurons, and hope that our progress will provide new insights into the development of targeted therapeutic approaches in future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Current imaging technologies are limited in their number of “channels” that can be used to observe cancers in detail. If one were able to image beyond the few limited number of channels in vivo, one could use imaging in completely new ways, analogous to the transformation that multiplexed flow cytometry has undergone over the last decade. This in turn would allow deciphering effects of drug action, resistance mechanism, immune cell responses and basic cancer biology in intact microenvironments. The goal of this proposal is to further develop a new bioorthogonal technology (SAFE-IVM) to enable ~30 channel in vivo imaging. The new method will allow us to perform in depth studies and will likely lead to new insight and experimental therapies in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis is the most common cause of tooth loss worldwide and a risk factor for atherosclerosis, rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes mellitus, and other diseases. Here we functionally characterize newly discovered gingival solitary chemosensory cells, showing how they detect oral bacteria and act as immune sentinels to protect against periodontitis. Our work provides a promising new approach to treating and preventing periodontitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Cataract surgery has greatly decreased the burden of blindness worldwide, however, current surgical methods are unable to remove all lens cells, and these undergo a wound healing response post surgery, leading to the formation of scar tissue within the eye, compromising vision. This work will provide fundamental insights into the mechanisms that lead to the inappropriate maintenance of the myofibroblasts that produce scar tissue after cataract surgery. This information will inform the design of strategies to prevent fibrotic posterior capsular opacification, yielding improved visual outcomes for cataract patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cortical diseases, including schizophrenia, epilepsy, and stroke, exert a tragic cost on millions of Americans and have a large impact on public health. This project aims to expand our understanding of the physiological underpinnings of cortical receptive fields and their behavioral role by examining the circuit mechanisms that give rise to them. Through cellular-resolution lesions combined with large-scale activity recording via two- photon calcium imaging, this project asks how interactions between groups of similarly and distinctly tuned sensory neurons shape receptive fields and contribute to perception. !

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson’s disease (PD) often results in widespread motor dysfunction. PD is a progressive and degenerative condition, and thus frequent and granular assessment of motor function is critical to effective management of motor symptoms. In this proposal, we will use an innovative pose estimation approach to enable objective quantification of many motor features of PD using only simple digital videos that can be recorded from common household devices (e.g., smartphones, tablets, laptop computers).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cryptococcal antigen (CrAg) screening in the blood and preemptive treatment for those who are CrAg positive, prevents the development of cryptococcal meningitis and death; however, 30% of CrAg+ persons die, even with the current standard of care. We propose a phase III randomized trial to evaluate a more potent antifungal, AmBisome, in conjunction with standard fluconazole, to prevent neurologic infection. The findings from this study will impact international HIV treatment guidelines on the optimal management of CrAg+ persons, in order to reduce neurologic disability and mortality in people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Home- and community-based services (HCBS) allow older adults, and particularly those with dementia, to remain living at home by supporting health as well as custodial and social needs. Despite widespread use of these services, little is known about the organizations delivering them or how well they are coordinated. Our project will identify and characterize the HCBS organizations that serve those with dementia, and then generate evidence on how well they support coordinated care in order to guide ongoing policy and practice-based efforts to help clinical and social service providers better serve a highly-vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE What are the neural and molecular mechanisms through which psychological stress leads to an inflammatory response, thus increasing risk for cardiovascular disease? The present project will use neuroimaging and pharmacological tools to answer this question, exploring the neural activity patterns and brain network configuration in response to stress that is associated with increases in inflammation, as well as how experimentally blocking one important stress signaling pathway (i.e., beta-adrenergic signaling) shapes neural and inflammatory responses to stress. Ultimately, these studies will fill critical gaps in our knowledge regarding the mechanisms through which stress may lead to cardiovascular disease risk, and help to identify novel targets for future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skeletal growth is achieved as growth plate chondrocytes follow a tightly controlled multi-step differentiation process. This project will test the hypothesis that the transcription factors SOX5/6, SOX9 and RUNX2/3 fulfill many of their key functions in these cells in a highly cooperative manner. Verification of this paradigm-shifting hypothesis should deepen understanding of the genetic mechanisms driving skeletogenesis, help uncover the molecular basis of various types of skeletal dysplasias, cartilage tumors and joint degeneration diseases, and illuminate new strategies to prevent and treat these diseases.

PHR: The single-base-pair resolution maps of DNA (hydroxy)methylation will be generated in sorted inhibitory and excitatory neurons at key time points of postnatal brain development and adulthood, as well as in the brains of psychiatrically normal individuals and patients with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing an ultra-long-acting injectable platform for the medication assisted treatment of substance abuse disorder (SUD). Once this platform is developed, there is the promise that a paradigm shifting impact will have been made for patients with SUD, for which current long-acting therapy options are sub-optimal. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission and CEBRA that aim to foster highly innovative, high-risk and high impact, and conceptually creative research related to the treatment of SUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE: Results from the proposed study are expected to provide fundamental knowledge on the role of sensory experience-mediated changes in chromatin and gene expression in flexible behavior. The proposed experiments will identify basic epigenetic, molecular, and circuit principles by which the environment induces changes in gene expression to alter function of individual or ensemble of neurons within a circuit and ultimately modify organismal behaviors. Thus, our findings may lead to novel and cheaper sensory experience-based therapeutic strategies that harness similar types of plasticity against psychiatric disorders, such as autism spectrum disorders, depressive and anxiety disorders, where misprocessing of sensory information accentuates anxiety and social behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In 2015, the South African National Tuberculosis Programme introduced Bedaquiline (BDQ) to strengthen existing regimens for the therapy of rifampicin-resistant TB. Of great concern, mutations associated with BDQ resistance (rv0678 and atpE) have been identified in Mtb isolated from patients who have never received BDQ or clofazimine (CFZ). In this proposal, we will test our overall hypothesis that mutations in rv0678, atpE and elsewhere in the Mtb genome dysregulate central metabolism which contributes to BDQ and CFZ resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The proposed research seeks to advance and deploy molecular simulation methods that can contribute to the NIH's mission to seek fundamental knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability. Atomic-resolution simulations will be used to understand the mechanism by which insulin binds to its receptor and itself to enable design of improved insulin therapies for treating diabetes melli- tus. Coarse-grained simulations of cytoskeletal networks will be used to parse the contributions of participating molecular processes to tissue patterning during development, with implications for understanding developmental defects and, more broadly, neuronal synapse formation, wound healing, and tumor growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  In the United States alone, about one million people have Parkinson’s disease and 50-60,000 new cases of PD are diagnosed each year. The causes of PD in most of these cases remain unknown; however, environmental factors have been implicated. The focus of this grant is of two folds: first, to elucidate the mechanisms by which manganese induces neurotoxicity through impaired autophagy and second, to identify potential novel therapeutic targets for PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative The purpose of this study is to test the efficacy of the “Migraine Manager” portal recently developed to promote better self-management in adolescent patients with migraine and their families using evidence-based assessment and intervention. We will evaluate the effect of Migraine Manager on headache frequency, health- related quality of life, and migraine-related disability compared to an attention control group in a single site randomized controlled trial. Positive results of this trial will have a significant impact on the migraine population by providing an efficacious clinical tool that can be disseminated and implemented broadly to underserved adolescents with migraine, who would not otherwise receive evidence-based self-management support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Four highly homologous genes of the SLO family encode potassium channel pore-forming subunits that are broadly expressed among tissues, share the feature that they are regulated by dynamic changes in specific cytosolic ion concentrations, and broadly influence function and electrical excitability in cells in which they are found. Rich diversity in function of such channels arises from tissue-specific expression of two families of auxiliary subunits ( and ), which in some cases have been implicated in various pathologies linked to specific SLO family channels, such as hypertension and epilepsy. Using methods of electrophysiology coupled with genetic manipulations that delete specific subunits from mice, this project is a long-term effort to define the functional properties conferred on SLO family channels by their auxiliary subunits, how channels of a specific subunit composition impact on cellular physiology, and whether such channels may underlie any pathological changes in cell physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is little guidance to help people with dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and their caregivers know when the person with DLB is approaching the end of life. This study will identify factors that predict the end of life in DLB and factors that affect quality end of life care. The information gained by this study will (1) help physicians, people with DLB, and caregivers better plan for the future by knowing what to expect and (2) identify areas where care can be changed to improve end of life experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SHARP (Summer HIV/AIDS Research Program) is an innovative and highly-applied HIV and substance use summer research experience for undergraduates who are underrepresented in science and medicine. SHARP scholars engage in research under the mentorship of leading HIV investigators, engage in peer-to-peer support, didactics, workshops and lectures, and have opportunities to shadow and participate in community events and other learning experiences designed to inspire them to pursue further studies and careers in public health-oriented clinical, socio-behavioral, and community-focused research. SHARP is a pathway program that aims to train the next generation of scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research leverages the REDIAL Consortium infrastructure to better understand the drivers of disparities in a debilitating side effect of methotrexate chemotherapy. Specifically, this study will integrate patient- reported outcome, metabolomic, genomic, and advanced neuroimaging data to identify novel biomarkers of clinical methotrexate neurotoxicity in pediatric ALL patients. This research has significant translational potential and may inform the delivery of targeted interventions to high-risk patients, with the goal of reducing unnecessary morbidity and improving outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are immunotherapies increasingly used in patients with wide varieties of cancers; however, they can also cause autoimmune toxicities affecting multiple organ systems, including the kidney. Currently, the pathogenesis of ICI-induced kidney injury is not well-understood, and epidemiologic studies suggest a high fraction of ICI-treated patients develop clinically-significant decline in kidney function over time. Using single-cell genomics and longitudinal biomarker studies, this proposal seeks to identify pathways that can help understand how acute and chronic kidney disease develops after ICIs to ultimately lead to novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to prevent kidney disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Newborn screening has immense benefits for babies with genetic diseases; however, some newborn screening tests have inherent inaccuracies that can cause delays in treatment or can subject some babies to unnecessary therapies. Improving diagnostic tools for the three genetic disorders targeted by this grant (Krabbe Disease, Pompe Disease and Mucopolysaccharidosis type I) will ensure that newborn babies who will benefit from treatment for these disorders will receive it promptly, and that the health of infants who do not require intervention will not be jeopardized by potentially dangerous treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The only known cure of an HIV-infected individual was the result of an allogeneic stem cell transplantation, for leukemia, using cells from a donor carrying the CCR5∆32 mutation. To translate this to a treatment appropriate for patients without cancer we are combining advances in stem cell engineering with novel approaches to transplantation. Our goal is to recapitulate the elements of this cure without the unacceptable side-effects of the cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the success of combination antiretroviral therapy (ART), HIV-1 remains a substantial public health burden. Our consortium will optimize targeted methods to modify and enhance HIV-specific immunity, and implement these approaches in a manner that can be safely and feasibly applied for all persons living with HIV. The role of the NHP core is to support preclinical modeling studies associated with each project in our consortium, and to direct our findings towards future studies in ART-suppressed HIV+ patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance  Studies proposed in this Program will advance our understanding of how proteins present on the surface of human blood platelets become unintentional targets of the immune system, leading to a devastating bleeding disorder in fetuses and neonates. We will also examine how a functionally-important receptor that forms the glue between the cells that line our blood vessels regulates the movement of blood cells and fluids into and out of underlying tissues during conditions of acute and chronic inflammation. The novel animal models and tools that will be developed as a result of this broad and ambitious Program will lead to new diagnostics and novel personalized therapeutics for treating diseases of the blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The only documented cures of HIV/AIDS involve intensive chemotherapy and transplantation with hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPC) that are genetically resistant to HIV-1 infection. Chemotherapy itself does little to HIV, but adds toxicity. The beneficial effect of the transplant is likely due to the regeneration of an HIV-resistant immune system. This proposal combines methods of reducing transplant conditioning toxicity, engineering HIV resistant HSPC and improving immune regeneration. This project tests a recently developed method of improving T cell regeneration in transplantation to augment immune reconstitution and viral reservoir targeting using engineered HSPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative and Relevance to Public Health Our proposed work will perform high resolution peripheral quantitative computed tomography scans in over 3,000 Framingham 3rd Generation participants to determine: 1) the role of metabolomics in age-related bone loss and fractures; and 2) to determine if clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential contributes to bone density, microarchitecture and strength. Discoveries related to these aims may identify targets for therapeutic interventions to prevent skeletal deterioration and fractures, which will prevent mortality, morbidity and disability. Fracture prevention will also reduce economic costs of health care required to care for these injuries. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may offer a curative strategy for HIV. However, current conditioning is highly toxic and often precludes transplant in non-life-threatening settings. By developing safer and targeted methods of nongenotoxic conditioning, we aim to lower the barrier to transplant and expand the use of curative transplant in HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 persists in viral reservoirs throughout the body, even during suppressive antiretroviral therapy (ART). Because latent virus may appear months or years after ART is withdrawn, an effective anti-HIV strategy must likewise persist indefinitely. In this project, our goal is to enable long-term remission of HIV-1 by seeding gene- modified cell products that will persist life-long, and act as sentinels against reactivated virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addiction is a major public health concern as it affects millions of individuals afflicted with the disorder, and has negative consequences for society at large. Great advances have been made in understanding the actions of drugs of abuse on the brain, but much remains to be learned. The purpose of this training grant is to foster interest in addiction among graduate students supported, such that these students will devote their research and eventually their careers to the study of the neurobiological bases of addiction and development of effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Risks of complications and death for adolescents and young adults (AYA) with sickle cell disease (SCD) increase dramatically following the transition from pediatric to adult care. To reduce these risks, it is critical that AYA with SCD develop self-management skills prior to transition to adult care; however, easily accessible tools to assist with SCD self-management skills development are scarce. This study will support the testing of a web-based application (app) that provides AYA with SCD with tools and resources to develop self-management skills that can reduce risks of complications and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a major public health crisis with no available cure. We propose innovative translational big data analytic methods to improve our understanding of the genetic, molecular and neurobiological mechanisms of AD, facilitate the identification of novel promising targets and drugs for repurposing, and ultimately have a translational impact on disease treatment and prevention. The resulting methods are also expected to impact biomedical research in general and benefit public health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is typically associated with a constellation of metabolic abnormalities and diseases, including dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes. However, not all individuals with obesity develop these complications; some have a higher propensity for the adverse metabolic effects of excess adiposity. This proposal focuses on identifying how the gut microbiota and the immune system drive the heterogeneity of metabolic abnormalities in individuals with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Portopulmonary hypertension (PoPH) patients suffer from a cardiovascular disease with very high morbidity and mortality that occurs exclusively in those with underlying liver disease. Although both the incidence and prevalence of chronic liver disease and PoPH have been increasing, the mechanisms by which liver dysfunction leads to PoPH, the optimal markers of disease, and the best treatments to improve outcomes in this high-risk population, are all poorly developed. This work, focusing on dysregulated vascular endothelial growth factor signaling and hepatocellular dysfunction, addresses this urgent and growing clinical need by identifying and developing new biomarkers that will enable more accurate diagnosis, improved risk stratification, and more precise treatment for patients with PoPH, ultimately leading to improved clinical outcomes in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Lipid trafficking pathways play central roles in cell physiology and in responses to challenges by microorganisms. Some intracellular pathogens including Toxoplasma gondii, an opportunistic pathogen in HIV/AIDS patients, subvert these pathways during infection. Our goal is to study the molecular mechanisms employed by Toxoplasma to hijack the vesicular and nonvesicular trafficking in mammalian cells for lipid scavenging and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative We will determine the molecular mechanisms regulating alveolar macrophage selfrenewal and inflammatory activity, and the downstream effects on pulmonary inflammation and tissue recovery during influenza virus infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) The efficient development of new medicines for disease treatment and prevention plays a vital role in improving the quality of human life. The work described herein focuses on the invention of novel copper-catalyzed chemical reactions for the construction of carbon- carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds. In doing so, this research will provide new tools for the efficient synthesis of biologically relevant molecules from simple starting materials using earth-abundant catalysts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences, lay) Our present knowledge of mitochondria highlights activities beyond energy production and into their decision- making role in a multitude of cellular processes. While our insight on the essential roles of mitochondrial signaling in disease-relevant processes such as innate immunity is rapidly expanding, several questions remain regarding the origin, mechanisms, and significance of such phenomena. With powerful genetic approaches and cutting- edge technologies, we aim to clarify the relationship between mitochondria and innate immunity, with the potential for paving new therapeutic approaches for human diseases with inflammatory components.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) cause serious morbidity and mortality for premature infants in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit, and early detection and treatment improves outcomes. We have made important discoveries toward developing early warning systems for sepsis and NEC using advanced vital sign analytics in a multi-center collaboration and are expanding analyses, collaborating sites, and methods to develop generalizable predictive monitoring algorithms. In doing so, we also aim to build an open access data and analytics platform that will ensure rigor and reproducibility of the work and spur new discoveries to further improve outcomes of preterm infants.

PHR: Project Narrative Malaria remains a major public health problem in Kenya, where progress towards malaria elimination has stagnated and the threat of disease resurgence persists. Enhanced epidemiological surveillance systems are needed to identify foci of transmission for targeted malaria control and to evaluate the effectiveness of malaria control programs. In settings of rapidly declining transmission, where asymptomatic infections predominate and silently sustain transmission, high-resolution spatial and epidemiological data are particularly needed to inform the development of optimal malaria control strategies aimed at eliminating transmission reservoirs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Byron Lai, PhD – R21  Project Narrative This home-based, telehealth trial will pilot the preliminary efficacy of a scalable sprint interval training program with enjoyable themes and music to improve cardiovascular fitness and cardiometabolic health among children with cerebral palsy. This project has the potential to address a large knowledge gap in the extant literature, because there are no widely accessible, evidence-based, enjoyable, and age-appropriate modalities for improving cardiovascular fitness or cardiometabolic health among children with disabilities who have mobility disabilities. The study findings will inform a larger, definitive efficacy study that can be easily implemented by researchers and health professionals across a variety of settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Although true in all disciplines, the role of a collaborative biostatistician is particularly important in addiction research given the types of problems commonly addressed, such as the use of complex study designs, large amounts of informed missing data and study dropout, along with the need to quantify complex mechanisms of action or underlying relationships. The Collaborative Undergraduate Biostatistics Experience (CUBE) program provides a unique opportunity for underrepresented minority students in STEM from around the country to work together in a vibrant academic collaborative environment with active researchers from a variety of disciplines related to addiction. Guided by Lent, Brown, and Hackett’s (1994) Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT) conceptual framework, the CUBE program is built on the following four pillars: 1) training in introductory biostatistics; 2) training in R programming; 3) professional development (PD); and 4) a collaborative research project addressing research questions in the area of addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The use of aromatase inhibitors (AI) such as letrozole for breast cancer therapy is associated with severe joint and muscle symptoms, which compromises adherence and persistence with AI therapy. Currently, no clearly effective therapies exist for prevention or treatment of AI-associated musculoskeletal symptoms. This proposal focuses on preclinical validation of sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor 1 (S1P1) modulators as a potential strategy to alleviate AI-associated musculoskeletal symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Gene identification for many substance use disorders continues to be hampered by small sample sizes. We propose to apply new multivariate genomic techniques to increase the power to identify genes involved in substance use disorders, and to characterize the risk associated with identified variants in diverse longitudinal samples in order to understand how genetic risk unfolds across development, and in conjunction with the environment. Each of these areas represents critical steps in using genetic data to improve prevention, intervention, and treatment for substance use disorders, and will lay the foundation as we move into an era of personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While previous studies have shown that ATF4 functions as a transcriptional regulator in diverse cell types and tissues under various physiological and pathological conditions, including cardiac diseases, little is known as to the specific role of ATF4 in cardiomyocytes. Our proposed studies will help us to understand the biological function of ATF4 in cardiomyocytes at molecular, cellular, and physiological levels, specifically the mechanism by which ATF4 regulates cardiomyocyte proliferation and function in a p53-dependent and -independent manner, as well as to determine a safe therapeutic window for the potential application of ATF4 and/or p53 inhibitors in cardiac diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mammalian retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), the neurons that convey information from the eye to the brain, cannot regenerate their axons once the optic nerve is injured, resulting in permanent vision loss. Some degree of optic nerve regeneration has been achieved in the past, but the extent of regeneration remains far from a level needed for significant visual recovery, pointing to the need for more effective therapies. Based on our recent transcriptome-based analysis of receptors for trophic factors, chemokines, and peptides that are expressed in adult RGCs, I will carry out a systematic bio-activity screening in vitro and in vivo to identify novel growth- and survival factors, followed by a complementary study to identify the responsive RGC subtypes, with the goal of discovering novel growth- and pro-survival factors to enable multiple RGC subtypes to survive injury and extend lengthy axons, potentially augmenting optic nerve regeneration well beyond currently achievable levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Dementia diagnosis, prevention and treatment has entered an exciting new era where a patient can be diagnosed with a simple blood test and new drugs promise to target the abnormal proteins that accumulate in the brain and cause the slow death of neurons, memory and thinking. While this is an occasion for celebration, almost nothing is known regarding the burden of dementing illness, what types of dementia are most prevalent, or how well new dementia blood tests work in Native American individuals. The current study seeks to answer these questions so that all Americans can benefit from the 21st century advances in dementia care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Glucose variability which reflects fluctuations into hypo- and hyperglycemic ranges have been linked to diabetes complications, but little is known about factors that affect glucose variability in type 2 diabetes. This study will examine personal factors and social-built environmental factors associated with glucose variability among multi-ethnic adults with type 2 diabetes in real-time, natural living environment. The findings from the proposed study will facilitate effective treatment by identifying risk factors of glucose variability and inform the future development of personalized just-in-time interventions targeting lifestyle behaviors with an increased understanding of glucose variability by providing support for healthcare providers’ clinical decisions and patients’ diabetes self-management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) Alzheimer’s disease (AD) features oxidative stress and transcriptional dysregulation that leads to impairments in hippocampal-dependent learning. We hypothesize that reduced bioavailability of the antioxidant all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), combined with epigenetic changes in the hippocampal dentate gyrus, accelerate AD onset. Using a novel approach that integrates behavioral, transcriptomic, and metabolomic/lipidomic data, this proposal tests the hypothesis that the synergistic combination of ATRA supplementation and an FDA-approved histone deacetylase inhibitor maintains hippocampal-dependent learning and ATRA-sensitive gene transcription more effectively than either monotherapy alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Children in underserved communities across the western United States are disproportionately exposed to and affected by air pollution including wildfire smoke. There is a need to identify local resources and implement interventions to improve air quality in order to lessen the health burden on youth. Through Youth Participatory Action Research (YPAR), this project will engage high school students to work within their school communities to increase local air quality knowledge, to implement interventions in their schools to reduce air pollution, and train them to be more informed and proactive citizens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative A better understanding of modifiable factors that can prevent dementia onset, like educational attainment, is critical given that existing biomedical interventions have failed to reverse or slow the course of disease. We propose to build an interdisciplinary network of scientists whose joint expertise is vital to achieving NIA’s goal to reduce educational disparities in Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD): population health scientists, with their robust expertise in the social and behavioral factors, including educational attainment, that shape dementia risk and resilience, and ADRD researchers, with their robust expertise in the biology and neurocognitive aspects of ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 1,000 genes have been implicated in autism spectrum disorder (ASD), but we don’t yet have a clear understanding of how each of those genes influences biology and behavior relevant to ASD. The proposed research uses an innovative strategy in a powerful animal model to understand if and how >100 of these genes, combinations of these genes, and gene variants from ASD patients cause changes to neurobiology and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor cells encounter many types of stress, such as nutrient scarcity, throughout disease progression that can promote adaptation and resilience but may also yield tumor-specific therapeutic vulnerabilities. The research proposed here describes a novel response to nutrient stress. Studying this stress response mechanism and understanding how it is employed by the cancer cell to support disease progression may thus facilitate the development of cancer therapeutics aimed at exploiting this response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our studies are designed to lay the groundwork for novel therapeutic approaches to improve the outcomes of liver transplantation and other clinical conditions with hepatic ischemia reperfusion (IR) injury, such as liver resection, hemorrhagic shock and trauma. We uncovered a previously unappreciated function of eosinophils in promoting liver repair after IR injury. If successfully completed, the proposed studies will elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms and provide strong evidence supporting the therapeutic potential of eosinophils in accelerating liver recovery after transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the pathophysiology of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is complex and multifactorial, vascular comorbidities and cerebrovascular insufficiency occur in almost two-thirds of AD patients. However, how cerebrovascular insufficiency interacts with and contributes to AD remains poorly understood. In response to RFA-AG-23-014 (Mechanisms of Brain Hypoperfusion in AD/ADRD), we propose to test the hypothesis that cerebrovascular insufficiency perturbs the AD brain vasculome, eventually leading to cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The greatest risk factor for developing Parkinson’s disease, outweighing all others, is age. However, it is unclear how aging predisposes the brain to PD. This project studies the mechanism of how microglia become senescent, characterizes the senescent microglia, and determines the impact of senescent microglia on dopaminergic neurons using human Parkinson’s disease postmortem brains and human microglia derived from induced pluripotent stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will define the strategies employed by the important human pathogen Acinetobacter baumannii to combat calprotectin-dependent zinc starvation during the pathogenesis of pneumonia. All microbial pathogens require zinc acquisition and metabolism to colonize the vertebrate host; therefore, these studies will be broadly applicable to numerous infectious diseases. Moreover, this work has the potential to uncover new principles in metal biology and cell wall synthesis that may lay the groundwork for the design of intervention measures to target these emerging infectious threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative LAMA2-deficient congenital muscular dystrophy (LAMA2-CMD) is a genetic disease that causes skeletal muscle and nerve damages in children. We will evaluate the therapeutic benefits of LAMA1 upregulation to compensate for the lack of LAMA2 in mouse and patient-derived cellular models. These findings will pave the way towards the development of a mutation-independent therapeutic interventions for LAMA2-CMD and other muscular dystrophies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Auditory recognition disorders in speech and language are typically thought to result from neurological abnormalities in the central auditory system rather than the periphery. Yet little is known about the neural mechanisms that underlie the type of complex audition that we routinely rely on in real-world scenarios, particularly for primates. This innovative proposal aims to address this issue by examining the perceptual and neural circuitry supporting vocal recognition in dynamic cocktail party environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent and young adult (AYA) survivors of childhood cancer are at risk for second cancers and other chronic health conditions (so-called “late effects”), yet their engagement in long-term follow-up care declines as they transition to adulthood and adult-oriented follow-up care. We aim to fill a significant knowledge gap by testing an adaptive re-engagement intervention specifically targeting AYA who are not currently engaged in follow-up care, and that aims to enhance appointment making, attendance and self-management. The goal is to identify optimal intervention strategies to meet an AYA’s individual needs for re-engagement in care and self-management, ultimately reducing morbidities and health disparities in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: NARRATIVE Definitive diagnosis of prostate cancer (PCa) relies on the collection of multiple core needle biopsies and their histopathological analysis but the multifocal nature of PCa makes cancer foci easy to miss, leading to a high rate of false negative results. Elevated PCa incidence rates, aggressiveness and mortality are more substantial in African American than in Caucasian American men. Our studies seek to identify and validate specific functional and phenotypic profiles of mast cells and molecular signatures present in benign biospies collected from PCa patients to improve PCa diagnosis, also having implications in PCa race disparity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Magnetoencephalography (MEG) and Electroencephalography (EEG) are non-invasive brain imaging tools for studying normal human cognition as well as neurological and psychiatric illnesses, including epilepsy, schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder, autism spectrum disorders, and Alzheimer’s disease. The neuroscience research community has an ongoing need for validated and documented open-source software to perform analysis and to facilitate reproducible and large-scale research involving electrophysiological data. This project continues to develop and support Brainstorm, open-source software that meets these needs with well-documented and tested novel analyses using MEG and EEG in combination with anatomical MRI and intracranial EEG data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The mechanisms of emergence, or ‘waking up’, from general anesthesia with volatile anesthetics are poorly understood, and delays in emergence are associated with anxiety, confusion, operating room delays, and increased medical costs. If the mechanisms underlying emergence can be resolved, it may be possible to develop strategies for active promotion of recovery of consciousness. The aim of the experiments in this proposal, which are supported by significant preliminary data, is to define the role of astrocytes, a cell in the brain that supports neuron function, in regulating emergence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: mRNA editing by RNA binding protein regulatory networks, increasingly associated with numerous neurodevelopmental disorders, greatly expand the complexity of the mammalian nervous system. These studies will employ state of the art bioinformatic analyses to identify protein-mRNA relationships important for generating neuronal cell types during development. These relationships will then be tested in a high-throughput in vitro system providing vital insight into the mechanisms underlying the hierarchical organization of cortical cell diversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Opioid use disorders (OUDs) have been associated with a 4-fold increase in drug overdose deaths in the past decade, and current treatments including medications that block the opioid receptor require a withdrawal period during which time many patients relapse and tragically may overdose and die. This project will assess a new device, non-invasive Vagal Nerve Stimulation (nVNS), that does not require surgery or implantation, and that electrically stimulates the vagus nerve as it passes through the neck, dampening the sympathetic nervous system and modulating brain regions in a way that may help patients during the opioid withdrawal period and reduce relapse. Studying the effects of nVNS on opioid craving and brain and physiological responses in patients with OUDs has the potential to reduce relapse and save lives, as well as increase our knowledge of changes to the brain and physiology that underlie OUDs and successful response to treatment.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will facilitate early detection of cognitive decline in older adults through development and implementation of an automated risk assessment and cognitive screening tool for use in primary care. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a seizure disorder often with devastating effects, particularly in the large number of patients for whom current treatments are ineffective. The proposed research will capitalize on the use of the first CNS infection-induced mouse model of TLE developed, by our group, to perform state of the art in vivo and in vitro 2-photon imaging experiments using our innovative genetically encoded calcium indicating protein toolkit. In addition, transgenic mice will be employed to study TLE in interacting networks of neurons and microglial cells during the process of epileptogenesis to test the hypothesis that tumor necrosis alpha signaling from microglia to neurons contributes to seizure generation following CNS infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  Disruption of genomic regulation is accompanied by striking functional changes across cell types and species. However, how mobile genetic elements are regulated throughout life, across biological sexes, and how they influence physiology in response to external or internal cues, remains largely unknown. By leveraging big data and state-of-the-art experimental approaches on vertebrate models including mouse and the emerging African turquoise killifish, the proposed research program will advance our understanding of mobile genetic element control in healthy somatic cells, and shed light on how these elements can influence vertebrate health and disease. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nuclear pore complexes (NPCs) selectively transport cellular material into and out of the cell nucleus and are a nexus for the control of gene expression. Despite advances in our understanding of how NPCs are constructed, we still do not know how NPCs mediate and control key elements of nucleocytoplasmic transport and structurally adapt to perform specialized functions, such as accommodating high transport flux or passage of very large cargoes. Investigating these biological processes is necessary to understand how NPC defects can lead to many developmental, viral or oncogenic diseases, so opening up the possibility for drugs to therapeutically modulate NPCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Colorado Pulmonary Alcohol Collaborative (CoPARC) supports fundamental research to understand how alcohol misuse affects the lungs and extrapulmonary organs, thereby contributing to pneumonia and respiratory failure, along with other adverse health effects. CoPARC's infrastructure provides specimens and data from participants and patients with alcohol misuse, ranging from asymptomatic individuals to critically ill patients, with associated control groups. Investigators receiving materials from CoPARC will advance knowledge of strategies to minimize the impact of alcohol misuse on lung health, and improve outcomes in patients affected by pneumonia, respiratory failure, and the collateral damage that occurs in these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Identifying the mechanisms linking daily work conditions and corresponding strain reactions to unsafe commuting is a precursor to intervention development. The proposed project synthesizes a video-based naturalistic driving approach validated in the transportation safety community with a daily survey methodology widely used in occupational health research to explicate the process through which daily work conditions and work-related strain reactions influence worker safety while commuting.
PI_NAMEs: CALDERWOOD, CHARLES C (contact);HICKMAN, JEFFREY ;SMITH, RYAN CHRISTOPHER

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanisms Linking Daily Work Conditions and Work-Related Strain Reactions to Unsafe Commuting

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: The study will benefit Veterans by identifying a patient and family centered balanced set of quality measures of palliative and end of life cancer care to inform VA operations as well as further research. The study will prioritize indicators to extract, and that will become candidates for routine VA use, on the basis of direct patient and family input. In doing so, the study will set a standard for VA quality measurement in general; furthermore, it will create generalizable information on how Veterans and families can be more directly involved at the facility level as participants in quality measurement and improvement of palliative and end of life cancer care. ImPACS will characterize variation in quality measures prioritized by patients and family members to also show where VA can take action to improve care in response to Veteran and family priorities with a focus on disparities among rural and nonwhite Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Hoarding Disorder is a common and severe neuropsychiatric disorder that contributes to profound functional, social, and occupational disability, as well as increased risk for a number of adverse health outcomes and safety hazards. The research proposed in this fellowship application will comprehensively assess heterogeneity in the symptom profile of individuals with hoarding disorder and will provide greater insight into the etiology and developmental course of hoarding symptoms. This work will therefore propose a novel framework for detecting hoarding symptoms on a population level, knowledge that will improve both the identification and treatment of HD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans develop hypertension and its co-morbidities at an earlier age, have a greater frequency and severity of hypertension, have poorer control of blood pressure, and die disproportionately (2-fold) more from hypertension as compared to whites. Despite these known disparities, there has been little attention or advancement in the management of blood pressure in the African American population. Our laboratory’s advanced physiological model paired with novel analytic tools may mechanistically predict the types of patients that should respond to therapy, ultimately improving patient drug regimens and their success rate in this underserved and understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxious smokers account for a greater proportion of tobacco-related disease, underscoring the need to identify common mechanisms of anxiety-smoking risk. This application proposes four training goals and three research aims to launch a unique line of research that integrates best-practices in mechanism-focused addiction research, translational learning models of anxiety pathology, and psychophysiological data collection and analysis. The goal is to refine knowledge of physiological processes that underlie anxiety pathology, maintain smoking behavior, and promote their high comorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Uterine cancer is the most common gynecologic malignancy and exhibits one of the largest racial disparities in mortality risk among all cancer types. Evidence shows that black women are significantly more likely than white women to be diagnosed at advanced stage of uterine cancer which explains more of the racial gap in mortality risk than any other factor, yet there has been a major void in our knowledge regarding reasons for this disparity in stage at diagnosis. By rigorously examining three unique healthcare databases and conducting a novel population-based patient survey with linked cancer registry data, this study seeks to understand how various clinical, behavioral, sociocultural, and healthcare system factors in the diagnostic pathway may contribute to black-white disparity in early diagnosis of uterine cancer and to inform target areas for future interventions to address this health inequity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative RNA-targeting chemistries are the foundation for new classes of therapeutics that circumvent challenges associated with protein-centered drug discovery. Numerous cellular RNAs contain functionally-important tertiary structures that may specifically engage small molecules, yet there is currently no scalable platform for identification of these sites or small molecules that specifically engage these sites. The goal of this training and research proposal is to train the applicant in and allow the applicant to create a screening and bioinformatic platform for high-throughput discovery of covalent chemistries that modulate function of human RNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE  We propose to conduct a well-powered social epigenomics study to investigate individual and social contextual factors in relation to DNA methylation, biological age, and lung cancer risk in a cohort of African Americans and European Americans at an elevated lung cancer risk. Our results will help us to better understand the mechanistic relationships between individual and neighborhood socioeconomic factors and lung cancer risk. The findings may provide useful information that could be used to ameliorate the lung cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells directionally migrate by protruding structures which are supported by the actin cytoskeleton and adhesion sites within the leading edge. To understand the biology of cell motility, an actin modifying protein called the mammalian diaphanous-related formin 1 (mDia1) that is switched on/off by the upstream p21 Rho family of small GTPase (RhoGTPase), is important in coordinating cell motility. Here, we will develop a near-infrared mDia1 biosensor to enable multiplex, simultaneous analysis of mDia1 activity together with a RhoGTPase biosensor in living cells and to study their dynamic functions during cellular leading edge protrusion formations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to impact human health by enabling the synthesis of tropolone natural products and derivatives thereof. Specifically, a sustainable and scalable platform for reaching useful tropolone cores will be developed to provide access to understudied bioactive tropolone natural products. Directed evolution strategies will be used to engineer biocatalysts to have improved physical properties and to possess the substrate scope to enable access to privileged natural product scaffolds. The development of this platform will allow for deeper studies of these valuable molecules which in turn will result in further understanding of natural products and their applications as therapeutics for human diseases.
