IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Sexually reproducing organisms rely on meiosis, a specialized cell division that generates haploid gametes, for genome inheritance from parent to offspring. Misregulation of this process results in gametes with an incorrect number of chromosomes, the primary cause of age-related infertility, miscarriage, and developmental disorders such as Down Syndrome. My proposed research will address the regulatory mechanisms that ensure faithful transmission of genetic information, informing the design of therapeutic interventions in human reproduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lysine demethylase 5 (KDM5) proteins are essential for development, and their dysregulation is a key driver of intellectual disability and several forms of cancer. The C-terminus of KDM5 is a poorly characterized region of the protein but appears to mediate demethylase independent role(s) essential to viability and proper development in Drosophila. Using a variety of molecular approaches, we will define the critical regions of KDM5 required to regulate transcriptional programs(s) necessary for development and uncover important demethylase independent KDM5 roles which could contribute to human disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative From a biologist’s perspective, cell migration is a hallmark of tissue morphogenesis in development, wound healing, and cancer metastasis. From a physicist’s perspective, collective cell migration can be viewed as a soft matter with collective mechanical phenomena. This research proposal will develop non-invasive methods and optogenetic tools to model in vivo force generation and transmission, further revealing the relationship between mechanical information and cell shape, and connect these aspects to observed biological phenomena (such as the Leader/Trailer polarity in Ciona) to provide a better understanding of collective cell migration.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Research suggests that extensive repetitions of upper extremity (UE) activity can improve UE recovery post- stroke. A home exercise program (HEP) is commonly prescribed as part of rehabilitation therapy to facilitate greater repetitions of UE activity. Unfortunately, patient adherence to HEP is often low, limiting overall recovery. Behavioral interventions may be helpful in improving adherence, but there is no evidence of the effects of such interventions in stroke rehabilitation for Veterans. There is a need to understand the relationships among Veteran stroke survivors’ psychosocial factors, barriers and facilitators to HEP adherence, and objective HEP adherence. This is a necessary first step toward future development of a behavioral intervention that adequately addresses barriers and facilitators related to psychosocial factors to increase HEP adherence and promote recovery for Veterans with stroke.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans have numerous risk factors (e.g., PTSD, TBI, cerebrovascular problems) for later-life cognitive and functional decline. Evidence supports the effectiveness of strategy-based cognitive rehabilitation therapies, including compensatory cognitive training (CCT), for such decline. However, questions remain about the length of time that CCT-driven improvements in cognitive and everyday function last, and whether additional ‘booster’ training sessions could provide additional benefit to aging Veterans who previously underwent treatment. The proposed study will examine the long-term durability of CCT in Veterans aged 55+ and will provide an opportunity to develop and pilot test a series of CCT booster sessions that can be personalized toward individual everyday functional goals. Ultimately, this study has the potential to improve cognitive function, functional independence, and quality of life for older Veterans. Results will advance cognitive rehabilitation science, inform future CCT treatment strategies for this high-priority Veteran population, and could improve healthcare for aging Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cervical cancer patients treated with standard of care (SOC) chemoradiation therapy (CRT) commonly experience disease recurrence, and current clinical testing and cancer genomic data cannot predict which patients will fail therapy before treatment or promptly detect disease recurrence after treatment. Our recent publications demonstrated that HPV genotypes and HPV alternative splicing affect LACC CRT response and patient outcome, and our preliminary data additionally identified a diversity of predictive HPV genomic structures (HPV-GS), including HPV-human gene fusions which affect their human oncogene partner expression. In this proposal, we will develop new HPV-GS based pre-treatment biomarkers, identify CRT-resistant HPV-GS in the context of CRT-induced clonal evolution, examine their mechanistic significance, and evaluate whether HPV-GS ctDNA tests can monitor LACC recurrence and metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders (NHPIs) experience social inequities, such as low socioeconomic status, and suffer from a disproportionately higher prevalence and earlier onset of Type-2 diabetes mellitus (DM) than other racial/ethnic groups, however, the interactions between the social environment and biological mechanism(s) that underlie these disparities are unknown. We posit that the social environment conditions the epigenomic landscape and gut microbiome composition that regulate inflammation and metabolic pathways, which may precede the onset of DM. The prevalence of protective or adverse social factors may impinge on this “immunoepigenetic-gut microbiome axis” to give rise to the DM health disparities observed in NHPIs, a potential outcome of this study with generalizable implications for improving early identification of DM to enable preventative strategies for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Both ethnic/racial minority and college student populations suffer from sleep disparities, including short sleep duration, poor sleep quality, and irregular sleep schedules. Yet, there is scant longitudinal research exploring the mechanisms and pathways through which race-related sleep disparities impact health and academic outcomes concurrently and over time among diverse college students. The current study employs an innovative combination of daily diaries and actigraphy, biannual surveys, annual dried blood spot biomarker samples, and anthropometric assessments to investigate the impact of sociodemographic and environmental stress on race-related sleep disparities from the first through senior year of college; informing researchers, public health experts, and educators about the social-biomedical mechanisms through which stress impacts ethnic/racial minority health and academic disparities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Teen drivers who have committed a traffic violation are at increased risk for crashes, injuries, and deaths. Through partnership with the local Juvenile Traffic Court, this randomized controlled trial will assess the effectiveness of an innovative in-vehicle driving feedback technology, with and without parent training, on reducing risky driving events, unsafe driving behaviors, and recidivism among high-risk teen drivers, which correlates with NICHD’s mission to prioritize research on teen driver safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The ability of cells to control their shape and architecture in response to changing cell-external and -internal conditions is the basis of almost every aspect in normal physiology. Deficiencies in this control are the cause of innumerable pathologies and diseases. In this research program, the PI and his laboratory will continue to develop innovative research methods integrating molecular cell biology, live cell microscopy, computer vision, and statistical and mathematical modeling to probe the complex interplay of spatially and temporally distributed chemical signals and mechanical forces that underlie the morphogenic processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite experiencing multiple stressors, immigrant populations, including those of Mexican immigrants, generally have better health outcomes than subsequent US-born generations. Recent research indicates that individual experiences and stress exposures translate into physical changes to biological systems; other factors may buffer the negative effects of the exposure. This project is designed to identify the stressors involved in immigration, and potentially the biological mechanisms they target, with the potential goal of improving behavioral, psychological, and physical health of immigrants and subsequent generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all synapses in the brain exhibit some form of short-term plasticity, yet the computational functions of this plasticity are poorly understood. This proposal applies innovative methods to develop fundamental knowledge about how synaptic plasticity implements the canonical computation of temporal pattern separation. An improved understanding of how the brain processes information over time could help guide the development of improved therapies for memory-related disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Vagus nerve stimulation may hold the key to treating many different conditions, including obesity. Obesity is a growing epidemic in our country. Obese Veterans are at risk for hypertension, diabetes, and depression. Stimulating the vagus nerves, which innervate the stomach, with small, therapeutic levels of electricity provides a potential avenue for weight loss but is not well understood. Successful reduction of excess body weight has been reported, but stimulus parameters are quite variable, and it is unclear how parameters map to outcomes. To facilitate stimulus optimization, both invasive recordings and non-invasive imaging studies should be conducted in animal models first. Ideally, stimulus would be applied bilaterally and near the stomach, but currently available electrode interfaces do not allow this. This research aims to a) develop a new interface that will allow bilateral stimulation near the stomach and b) map the relationship between stimulus parameters and 1) nerve recruitment and 2) brain activity. Studies will be conducted in rats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE, or lupus) is a chronic multisystem autoimmune disease characterized by the production of autoantibodies, disproportionately affecting women and African Americans, with whom it is associated with significant mortality and morbidity, and without safe and effective treatments. This project seeks to identify and characterize the epigenetic mechanisms by which positive and negative social experiences affect gene function and thereby influence SLE in African American women. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it could lead to improvements in our understanding of the etiology of SLE and its disparities, facilitating the development of targeted precision medicine approaches to reduce morbidity, mortality, and close the health disparities gap.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dysfunctional angiogenesis and the resultant lack of vascularization is a potentially lethal issue that affects tens of millions of patients in the United States alone. Current treatments do not contend with the complexities of the angiogenic process and fail to promote stable blood vessel growth. Here we propose an investigation into the role of macrophages in angiogenesis, and the design of a biomaterials-based strategy to control macrophage behavior and promote complete vascularization and healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alaska Native people predominate in rural Alaska where the lack of roads creates a dependency on air medical evacuation (medevacs) for access to emergency care which in turn creates the highest medevac rate, the highest airplane crash rate, and the poorest access to emergency care of any region in the US. Work proposed in this grant aims to generate a novel medevac outcomes database from existing electronic health records, combine those data with community-engaged qualitative methodology to ultimately create context-specific machine learning models able to classify the appropriateness of medevac utilization. This continuum of research has the potential to directly address the disparities in access to and outcomes of emergency care experienced by both Alaska Native people in rural Alaska and by rural Americans more generally, by improving the safety, timeliness and appropriateness of medevacs.

PHR: The Hispanic Clinical and Translational Research Education and Career Development (HCTRECD) program at the University of Puerto Rico Medical Sciences Campus (UPR-MSC) will continue to develop and implement innovations that will enhance our program’s capacity and infrastructure to support even more Hispanics in research careers that can address how to reduce health disparities. To continue pursuing this goal, we will improving methodological knowledge and skills and addressing barriers to obtaining K awards. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical inactivity is associated with worse asthma outcomes, and African American women are disproportionately impacted by both physical inactivity and asthma. Research aimed at addressing the unique asthma-related and culture-specific barriers to physical activity in this vulnerable population of women is needed. The proposed study will test the efficacy and implementation potential of ACTION (A lifestyle physiCal acTivity Intervention for minOrity womeN with asthma) to increase physical activity and asthma health outcomes to reduce the burden of asthma in African American women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project seeks to reduce the unequal burden of hypertension after pregnancy of Black women, which is a major driver of severe maternal disease and death and long-term heart disease. We propose a novel trial that compares an enhanced multi-level intervention (home blood pressure monitoring and postpartum heart health doula support) to usual care that will be an equitable, scalable and sustainable strategy to improve the health of all women with hypertension in pregnancy. Our intervention is aligned with the NIMHD objectives to generate new knowledge to improve health outcomes of racial minority populations affected by health inequities using a multi-level intervention that addresses patient, health professionals, system and community factors.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence suggests that access to green schoolyards may facilitate play and physical activity to help prevent excess weight gain in children, improve academic outcomes, and help the community at large. The Little Rock Green Schoolyards Initiative, a program aiming to promote outdoor learning and play in low-income schools, is a unique opportunity to evaluate the role of such interventions on physical activity through environmental and social pathways. The program also provides an opportunity to evaluate the potential impact of green school yard interventions on other academic and community outcomes and assess potential barriers to successful implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human inferior colliculus plays a major role in auditory processing, but technical limitations have made it difficult to study in vivo. In this project we will implement ultra-high field magnetic resonance imaging techniques in living humans to characterize the anatomy and connectivity of this subcortical auditory structure and its role in speech category learning. This will uncover structure-dependent MRI contrast within living human midbrain and its contributions to speech communication with clinical applications related to hearing disorders and midbrain auditory implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Shah, Vallabh O and Herman Carla Falls and fall-related injuries are major health risks for our disparity population of American Indian elders. Our pilot study showed 52% of Zuni elders reporting a fall during the past year, which is significantly higher than the US national average of one out of three adults 65+. In partnership with Zuni Pueblo leadership and community stake holders, we seek to study the feasibility of implementing Community Health Representative (CHR) delivered fall risk screening and evidence-based Otago Exercise Program to address lack of access to home- delivered physical therapy and health disparity, as well as empower elders to address fall risk, avert injury, and preserve aging in place within their community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Spinal cord injury (SCI) affects 1.3 million Americans. The proposed experiments in this application are relevant to public health because they will elucidate mechanisms for how neuronal activation promotes axon growth, thus identifying potential therapeutic targets. Additionally, they will test whether neuronal activation – alone or in combination with other manipulations – promotes functional axon regeneration after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Defects in homeostatic signaling at synapses are associated with a variety of neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases including epilepsy, autism, schizophrenia, Fragile X Syndrome, ALS, and Alzheimer's Disease. However, the mechanisms that ensure stable synaptic strength remain poorly understood. This proposal seeks to reveal fundamental mechanisms that initiate and maintain homeostatic signaling at synapses, insights that are necessary for understanding disease etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We recently discovered that mice with hyperactive stress circuits exhibit an increased incidence of SUDEP. Given that both stress and SUDEP link to disruption of central circuits responsible for the regulation of cardiorespiratory function, this application will interrogate a potential, novel pathophysiological mechanisms contributing to SUDEP involving hyperactive stress circuits and exaggerated cardiac vagal output. This application has the potential to uncover a novel mechanism contributing to SUDEP risk, which may also be relevant to other forms of sudden death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent alcohol use has a detrimental impact on the brain and is a risk factor for impulsivity and development of addictive disorders in adulthood. Despite this, there is a fundamental lack of mechanistic understanding of how adolescent alcohol use affects the brain because most research effort has focused on adult models. The proposed project seeks to determine how voluntary adolescent alcohol drinking causes impulsivity and alters neural networks in adulthood in order to elucidate neuronal consequences of adolescent alcohol exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  A new class of anticancer drugs called PARP inhibitor has been approved by US FDA to treat recurrent ovarian cancer. However, resistance has also been observed, and patients receiving PARP inhibitors eventually develop cancer progression. In this project, we plan to investigate a new mechanism of PARP inhibitor resistance in ovarian cancer, and test the therapeutic potential of a new compound, called ALDH1A1 inhibitor, in treating PARP inhibitor-resistant ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This grant aims to increase understanding of disease biology in patients with an atypical presentation of Alzheimer’s disease. We will use longitudinal imaging techniques to determine whether brain function, iron deposition and genetics are related to how the proteins tau and beta-amyloid spread through the brain. The findings will improve our understanding of the mechanisms that drive the disease and could ultimately allow the appropriate targeting of future therapies in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses the family planning goals of Healthy People 2030. It does so by generating foundational demographic knowledge that is necessary to our understanding of intended and unintended childbearing, adolescent childbearing, and short interbirth intervals. Its results will contribute to our understanding of how fertility has been affected by the pandemic, which is a prerequisite for addressing this impact, e.g. by identifying and appropriately targeting policies and social security programs that will allow people to recover from this shock to their childbearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research develops a novel strategy to identify and target the natively expressed forms of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor as they contribute to addiction, a persistent public health issue in the United States. Using a yeast-display immune screen, this project will generate a new biological tool to accurately track and modify the activity of these receptor proteins in the brain, thus providing a promising avenue to develop improved tools for smoking cessation and other addiction therapies. This proposal is thus highly relevant to the NIH's primary function of studying and treating human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Tobacco product packaging is a particularly important form of advertising and marketing. There is a need for research that examines whether introducing standardized tobacco packages (that is, replacing colorful, logo- heavy packages with drably colored packages that include little, if any, color or product branding) diminishes risk of tobacco use. The research proposed in this application will conduct an experiment with young adults to fill this gap, and to inform policy decisions relating to tobacco package design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The thalamic reticular nucleus (TRN), the major source of thalamic inhibition, plays critical roles in regulating information passing between thalamus and neocortex. TRN dysfunction may underlie sensory abnormality, attention deficit and sleep disruption across multiple neurodevelopmental disorders. Despite its central importance, current understanding about how TRN neurons regulate such diverse functions is still limited. The current proposed work aims to investigate structure-function relationships in distinct TRN networks regulate behavioral processes in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Interventional Oncology is emerging as the fourth pillar of cancer care alongside medical, radiation, and surgical oncology. Interventional oncologists provide minimally invasive image- guided therapies to treat cancers without the toxicities and disfigurement of chemotherapy, radiation or surgery. The role of a senior IO Clinical Research Specialist is to foster new clinical trial designs and collaborations which are essential to determine how and when interventional oncologic therapies should be integrated into multidisciplinary care plans to achieve optimal outcomes for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: For healthy metabolism, it is imperative that adequate amounts of sulfur are supplied and that toxic sulfur- containing metabolites are consumed (salvaged) or otherwise removed. When this ability is compromised a number of different scenarios arise that lead to different pathologies in humans and lower organisms. This study considers how sulfur and carbon salvage mechanisms influence metabolism of pathogenic bacteria that cause serious infections in millions of people, with the idea that this work could lead to a specific therapeutic strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Schizophrenia is a severe and debilitating brain disorder with obscure neurobiological mechanisms and limited treatment options. The proposed study will investigate unique aspects of schizophrenia neurobiology— disease course and aging—along the adult lifespan. This research will contribute to fundamental knowledge about brain systems critical for schizophrenia neurobiology, and motivate future studies on the development of precision treatments tailored towards schizophrenia trajectory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is relevant to public health because sustained HIV viral suppression is a key health outcome, benefiting the individual’s health (reduced morbidity, comorbidities, and mortality) and the community because sustained HIV viral suppression is associated with preventing HIV transmission. As the United States makes advancements in HIV care and treatment and gets closer to ending the HIV epidemic, we need to ensure that no one is left behind. People with HIV with low incomes who rely on state AIDS Drug Assistance Programs (ADAPs) experience geographic disparities in viral suppression, and for this population, we will identify the specific policies and healthcare delivery programs that increase sustained viral suppression rates and reduce sustained viral suppression disparities related to race/ethnicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As the HIV epidemic has matured, disproportionate high numbers of new infections are continuing to occur in the Southeastern US. UAB and UMMC have a rich history of HIV/AIDS research and patient care and are uniquely positioned to study the most contemporary scientific questions emerging over the next decade. As such, the UAB/UMMC site will significantly contribute to the knowledge and scientific evidence base aiming to understand the impact of HIV on men and women living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop and validate machine learning algorithms using raw accelerometer and gyroscope sensor data collected at the hip and wrist for use in free-living adults. These algorithms will be able to estimate energy expenditure and classify the type of activity being performed, significantly improving upon current methods that typically only use accelerometer data. These algorithms will have direct benefit to those examining dose response relationships between sedentary behaviors, physical activity and health outcomes in adults, in the physical activity and public health fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: DAISY Project Narrative: March 2020 The Diabetes Autoimmunity in the Young Study (DAISY) will evaluate environmental risk factors for development of islet autoimmunity (IA), in particular those responsible for the increase in T1D incidence in children born between 1993 and 2010. DAISY will investigate the role of enteroviral infections in the etiology of T1D using samples collected from birth and novel technologies. Finally, we will assess progression to T1D among youth with IA older than 15 y.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 1 diabetes develops as a result of a complex dialogue that is established between immune cells that infiltrate the pancreatic islet and injured and dying β cells. miRNAs are small noncoding RNAs that modulate expression of genes, and accumulating data suggest that β cell miRNA expression patterns are dynamically modulated during the evolution of type 1 diabetes. This proposal seeks to define the role of inflammatory-induced miRNAs in β cell death and diabetes pathophysiology and will test the idea that detection of β cell-derived miRNAs can serve as biomarkers of type 1 diabetes risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among the aging population it remains unknown whether Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) and its alcohol-related cognitive and brain decline increases risk for diagnostic mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or even can result in a classic irreversible dementia. Characterization of brain pathology and its relation to cognitive deficits in AUD compared with MCI and identification of modifiable risk factors may provide biological markers and enhance mechanistic understanding of these disorders. Development of a translational animal model of AUD brain pathology will permit discovery of biological factors in addition to alcohol itself that contribute to brain damage and inform intervention and treatment efforts for reversing pathology and impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This project aims to develop highly mature bioengineered human heart tissues based on the fact that mature adult cardiomyocytes contain more than one copy of DNA (i.e. they are polyploid). We will construct engineered human heart tissues made of polyploid cardiomyocytes and study their structure, function, genetic and metabolic properties, and response to stress. The outcomes of these studies will enable generation of improved organ-on- chip systems for drug development, studies of human heart disease, and regenerative medicine applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol consumption is associated with increased risk and aggressiveness of breast cancer, suggesting that alcohol may enhance tumorigenesis and progression of breast cancer. We hypothesize that alcohol-induced tumorigenesis and aggressiveness are mediated by different mechanisms. This proposal will elucidate the mechanisms of alcohol-induced tumor promotion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dopamine neurons projecting to different regions in the striatum exhibit distinct properties and serve distinct functions. The goal of this proposal is to identify the molecular mechanisms by which such functionally segregated dopamine circuits are established in the mammalian brain. Since defects in dopamine signaling underlie many neuropsychiatric disorders, our work may also suggest novel strategies to treat such disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE More potent and sustained androgen receptor targeting has driven an increased incidence of neuroendocrine prostate cancer (NEPC), a lethal form of prostate cancer, that involves a lineage plasticity program. Our preliminary data demonstrate that the loss of protein kinase C (PKC)l/i promotes a metabolic reprogramming that supports cell proliferation and epigenetic changes favoring lineage plasticity during NEPC. The scope of this study is to investigate the role and mechanism of action of PKCl/i to orchestrate serine metabolism and epigenetic regulation in NEPC, and to identify novel vulnerabilities that can be exploited therapeutically for its treatment.

PHR: NARRATIVE Despite a significant burden of disease, few research training programs focus on the urgent health priorities critical to women worldwide. The UNC Global Women’s Health Fellowship addresses this gap through a comprehensive two-year program that provides didactic training, overseas field experience, and intensive academic mentorship. Trainees gain the necessary skills and expertise to become independent investigators and leaders in the field of global women’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Early life stress/adversity (ELS/ELA) is a risk factor for age-related disorders, including psychiatric, neurological and cognitive disorders. Yet, prospective, longitudinal, studies across the life span are critical to identify biomarkers of ELA risk embedded earlier in life, to develop early intervention strategies. The goal of this proposal is to use a prospective, longitudinal design in nonhuman primates and innovative statistical methods to identify early biomarkers/pathways and underlying mechanisms of ELA-related accelerated neural aging trajectories and cognitive decline from young adulthood to middle age. We will leverage a unique population of adult female macaques with ELA (social subordination stress) currently living in social groups and longitudinally characterized from birth through puberty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We will systematically engage local policy, community, and academic stakeholders to develop and refine a dynamic conceptual framework that elucidates drivers of racial/ethnic disparities in diet in cities. We will also implement an agent-based simulation model to examine how high levels of racial/ethnic residential segregation in U.S. cities, the inequitable distribution of food outlets, pervasive income inequality, and the lower price of energy-dense, non-nutritious foods relative to healthier foods work in combination to constrain healthy food choices of racial/ethnic minorities and lead to disparities in diet and obesity. We will use the model to evaluate how inequitable job and income loss due to the COVID-19 pandemic will affect diet disparities, and how multiscale federal, state, and local policies can either exacerbate or reduce disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Relevance Up to 40% of adults with type 1 diabetes have insufficient sleep which is associated with negative health consequences including poor blood glucose control and greater diabetes complications. We propose a sleep intervention (Sleep-Opt) that uses wearable sleep tracking technology, telephone coaching and informational content designed to improve sleep and glycemic control in working-age adults with type 1 diabetes. Sleep-Opt could lead to reduced development of diabetes complications and improve quality of life for adults with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WALTER REED ARMY INSTITUTE OF RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), are deeply impacted by educational disparities and inequities in the US public school. Our objective in this proposal is to disseminate sustainable near-peer mentor-led science enrichment programs within underserved high school classrooms through university partnerships. The proposed work will help establish the near-peer mentor model as a way to address systemic inequities in STEM education and increase the capacity for recruitment of students from underrepresented backgrounds into STEM internships at our and partnering institutions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative: The proposed research focuses on improving our understanding of the role of maternal genetic factor ET-1 in PE, especially its effects on the embryo-maternal interface, and the mechanism of Nam protecting against the detrimental effects of elevated ET-1 levels observed in PE. In defining such factors/pathways involved in the functions of ET-1 during PE and the possible interactions with Nam, potential preventive and/or therapeutic strategies for PE may result, which could improve short- and long-term health outcomes of mothers and their offspring. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH mission of reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is an evaluation of a housing intervention, Operation Safer Ground, that was quickly implemented in response to the risk of COVID-19 among people experiencing homelessness. We will use qualitative methods to describe the development and implementation of the program, define its operational characteristics, and investigate contextual factors; we will use quantitative methods to see what happened over time among program participants and nonparticipants. The proposed study will provide information to improve the long-term response to the COVID-19 pandemic and help us prepare to protect vulnerable populations in future public health crises.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Protean Bio has identified a novel peptide mimetic (D6PV) and the goal of the current study is to complete IND enabling studies to develop a therapeutic based on D6PV by conducting toxicology studies and manufacturing GMP drug substance and drug product for future Phase 1 trials in normal healthy volunteers. Successful completion of aims proposed here will result in the development of a novel therapeutic as an intravenous formulation with a rapid onset of action for the treatment of hospitalized patients with acute pancreatitis to reduce the length of stay in the hospital and reduce or eliminate the morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative To comprehensively understand the cellular states that drive biological function and pathology, it would be ideal to identify biomolecules in their spatial context within fixed cells and tissue by combining both imaging-based screening with omics-level profiling by next generation sequencing (NGS). We propose to develop a light- directed spatial barcoding platform for highly parallelized, deep profiling of individual cells transcriptomic states within user-defined areas of tissue and clinical samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER)-Associated Degradation (ERAD) is a major protein quality-control program that monitors and degrades unfolded or misfolded proteins. This project will define the function and mechanism by an unprecedented ERAD program regulates RNA modification and subsequent lipid metabolism under the circadian clock. The findings obtained from this project will open new paradigms for the studies on the physiological ERAD and RNA modification and shed new light on developing therapeutics for lipid-associated metabolic disorders, particularly non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and hyperlipidemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): The L polymerase protein of nonsegmented negative-strand (NNS) RNA viruses contains an RNA dependent RNA polymerase and a suite of unconventional mRNA capping enzymes including a polyribonucleotidyltransferase and a dual-specificity cap methyltransfease. Understanding how those activities are controlled to ensure that the viral genome is expressed is of intrinsic interest and has the potential to impact the development of antiviral drugs and live attenuated vaccines. Here we will compare structural and functional insights into this protein for a prototype NNS RNA virus, vesicular stomatitis virus and the human pathogen rabies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE STETAMENT) Liver diseases cause about 30,000 deaths annually in the US, and the progression of fatty liver (nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, NASH) is the most common cause of liver dysfunction worldwide. To date the factors that promote fat deposition in the liver and the transition from steatosis to NASH and cirrhosis in humans are unknown in specific human genetic backgrounds. One obstacle to study such pathological transition is the absence of appropriate human liver tissue model. Environmental (epigenetic) factors, and genetic disease drivers have been associated to the NAFLD development and progression. This project aims to improve public health by utilizing organ engineering technology and stem cell engineering to constitute mini-livers that mimic human fatty liver disease with success to determine the role and mechanism of NAFLD-high risk or protective genetic variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TRPV1-2 and TRPM2 ion channels are multimodal sensors that transduce a variety of signal modalities into electrical signals to allow cells to adapt to their changing environment. In this proposal, we will use a combination of patch-clamp electrophysiology and fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy to measure the energetic coupling between the sensing modules and the channels’ gates and among different sensing modules to explain the molecular mechanisms by which environmental signals control the gating process.

PHR: NARRATIVE  This study will lead to the identification of better tests for the diagnosis of urinary tract infections. This study will  also identify new tests that can be used to differentiate urinary tract infections involving the kidney from urinary  tract infections involving the bladder. The tests developed in this study may eventually help reduce  inappropriate use of antibiotics while at the same time reducing the incidence of renal scarring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is a potentially curative therapy for many malignant diseases whose applicability has been impeded by the development of its most serious complication, acute graft versus host disease (aGVHD). Our goal is to develop clinically relevant strategies that validate prospectively biomarkers for aGVHD will allow for biomarker-based preemptive trial and better harnessing of treatment in many patients with hematological cancers. The fundamental insights gained from these studies will have broad and rapid implications to cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The MACS and WIHS are major studies of the progression of HIV infection in men and women who are representative of the epidemic (e.g., racially and ethnically diverse, variable degrees of engagement in care) in the United States. The goal of the newly merged cohort is to study the “health span” of people living with HIV now. The relevance of the proposed research would be to contribute fundamental knowledge on the impact of factors (i.e., sex, race and ethnicity, somatic and gonadal aging, psychosocial, genetic) on HIV progression and risk for comorbid conditions (i.e., cardiovascular disease, cancer, neurocognitive impairment, and lung, kidney, liver and physical function changes).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The Bronx Clinical Research Site (CRS) will support the Combined Cohort Study (CCS) to understand and advance the study of comorbidities associated with HIV infection and its treatment, providing leadership in studies of cardiovascular disease, HPV, and metabolic conditions of aging. We will continue to follow our large numbers of well-characterized women currently enrolled in the Bronx Women's Interagency HIV Study, as well as recruit primarily racial and ethnic minority men and women with or at-risk for HIV to reflect the NYC HIV epidemic, and allow us to investigate the impact of age, sex, race/ethnicity, and health disparities on HIV-related comorbidities and HIV disease progression across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will refine the Facing Eating Disorder Fears (FED-F) for anorexia nervosa (AN) relapse-prevention treatment designed to prevent relapse after discharge from acute treatment. We will assess the feasibility, acceptability, clinical efficacy, and target engagement of this treatment versus treatment as usual. The proposed research has significant public health relevance, as it will directly lead to a highly accessible and deployable treatment that can decrease AN relapse and the high societal burden associated with AN. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s strategic aim 4.3 as it will lead to the creation of an innovative evidence- based service delivery model using technology that can be easily disseminated to communities in need during a critical period of transition of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Women with perinatal mood and anxiety disorders (PMAD) may suffer from barriers to treatment. We will use national Medicaid, private insurance, and survey data to examine disparities in negative utilization and delivery outcomes to determine patient, community, and societal characteristics associated with these outcomes. We will also convene an Expert Panel to assist in generating a guide to evidence-based policymaking for state PMAD planning, and based on interviews with state maternal and infant health and mental health policy officials, develop tailored recommendations to inform future policy and targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Narrative The biological significance of fibrillar protein assemblies in both health and disease, makes understanding the molecular underpinnings of their interactions essential for intervention. Protein interactions with collagen fibrils are critical for healthy cellular function, while self-assembly of intrinsically disordered α-synuclein monomers leads to pathological oligomer and fibril formation associated with Parkinson’s Disease. Using an integrative set of biophysical tools combined with cellular assays, our studies will reveal mechanisms that underlie fibril-protein interactions and will inform design of therapeutics to encourage functional or discourage pathological interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and its progression to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) are major medical conditions in the United States that are the leading cause of liver transplantation and for which there are no therapeutic options. The EphB/EphrinB bidirectional signaling molecules are an emerging target for effective treatment of NASH fibrosis/cirrhosis and associated metabolic disorder. The work proposed will (1) develop first-in-class small molecular weight drug-like chemical antagonists that target EphB/EphrinB bidirectional signaling, and (2) test the effectiveness of such compounds in reversing established NASH fibrosis and cirrhosis in clinically relevant small animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease. Albuminuria and excess lipid accumulation are important mechanisms for DKD progression. The proposed research will enable us to establish new therapeutic strategies to halt the progression of DKD by examining the biochemical pathways that prevent kidney cells from injury in obesity and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Very early onset inflammatory bowel disease (VEO-IBD), diagnosed at <6 years of age, is a heterogeneous, severe, potentially fatal disorder of increasing incidence, where traditional IBD treatments often fail. Single gene defects are suspected to be the cause of VEO-IBD in a large number of cases, and elucidation of genetic risk factors would undoubtedly enhance our understanding of pathogenesis and suggest novel therapeutic approaches. The goal of this proposal is to widen our genetic analysis through WGS and leverage transcriptome modifications to enhance our capacity in identifying causal variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The MACS-WIHS Data Analysis and Coordination Center (DACC) brings together two datacenters that have served successfully as the scientific partner and operations center for the MACS and WIHS cohort studies, respectively. The merged datacenter will utilize best practices from both groups to advance knowledge of the basic science, clinical science, and epidemiology of HIV infection in the US, with a focus on HIV-related comorbidities. We will provide epidemiological and statistical expertise to scientific initiatives, as well as continue our quality assurance program in partnership with the clinical research sites that integrates expertise in data management, study coordination, statistical methodology, and scientific disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the availability of potent antiretroviral therapy, HIV-infected men and women continue to suffer from premature morbidity and mortality, including cardiovascular and pulmonary disease, neurocognitive dysfunction and malignancies. The goal of the Chicago Cook County Clinical Research Site of the MACS/WIHS Combined Cohort Study is to investigate the mechanisms of HIV-associated co-morbidities in order to inform interventions that will ultimately improve the quality of life and prevent premature disability and death of people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment advances in psychosis may be limited by the use of phenomenology-defined diagnoses based on symptomatic outcomes, rather than by neurobiological constructs monitored by quantitative characteristics. The Bipolar-Schizophrenia Network for Intermediate Phenotypes (B-SNIP) uses biomarkers to define psychosis subgroups with the goal of testing the advantages of B-SNIP biomarkers for diagnostic and therapeutic decisions, consistent with principles in the NIMH Strategic Plan. We propose to test Biotype1 psychosis subgroup with clozapine, and predict a differential clinical response to clozapine compared with Biotype2, marked by normalization of IEA, cortical attractor network activity and an advantage over usual antipsychotic drugs, establishing low IEA in Biotype1 as a predictive biomarker for clozapine efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to understand why nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) act as opportunistic pathogens that are readily cleared by healthy lungs but can cause pulmonary infections in individuals with chronic airway diseases. Using animal models and human cells, we will characterize initial events that occur when NTM interact with specific immune cells (macrophages), and demonstrate how local environments within different parts of the lung determine whether or not macrophages can kill inhaled NTM. Results from the proposed research will aid development of novel therapies to treat non-resolving NTM infections in people with chronic airway diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is part of a Program Project designed to determine the effects of obesity on tumor promotion in an animal model of pancreatic cancer. We will test the hypothesis that obesity leads to visceral adipose tissue inflammation, which promotes pancreatic cancer development, and investigate the effects of the lipid-lowering drugs, statins, on adipose tissue inflammation and pancreatic cancer development. Our studies will provide the scientific rationale for the use of statins in chemoprevention of pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) is an emerging cancer therapeutic target whose functional inhibition by two widely used small compounds (JQ1 and I-BET) often leads to suppression of cancer-associated phenotypes; nevertheless, insensitivity to drug treatment and development of drug resistance upon prolonged treatment remain serious concerns in cancer therapy. In our preliminary studies, we found that BRD4 has two predominant protein isoforms with the long (L) form likely being tumor-suppressive and the short (S) form potentially being oncogenic. In this proposal, we will investigate the functional role of BRD4-L and BRD4-S in regulating breast cancer cell growth and tumor progression and in gene programming using biochemical and molecular biological approaches, synthetic chemistry, genomics, proteomics, and mouse breast cancer tumor models with concurrent analysis of human breast cancer specimens, which collectively will unravel the mechanisms by which BRD4 regulates normal and cancer cell growth and tumor progression as well as provide a rationale for BRD4-targeted cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The central hypothesis to be tested in this Project is that statins significantly delay or prevent the tumor-promoting effects of the high fat, high calorie diet (HFCD) either singly or acting synergistically with metformin. Since statins, including simvastatin, are FDA-approved drugs widely used in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular diseases, the outcome of the studies will provide the scientific rationale for its use in chemoprevention of pancreatic cancer and elucidate its mechanism. Our results may also be transferable to other obesity-related cancer and even non-malignant chronic diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Noninvasive neuromodulation methods hold great promise for treating a wide range of neurological and psychiatric disorders. However, reported effects are often small, difficult to reproduce and the basic mechanisms underpinning them are not clear. Understand the basic tDCS mechanism is the first step towards improving noninvasive neuromodulation methods, leading to improved therapies for neurological and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Despite significant progress in the fight against pancreatic cancer, survival rates are dismal and the prognosis remains bleak, with less than 7% of patients living longer than 5 years following diagnosis. There is a dire need for new treatment strategies and pre-clinical models to evaluate emerging therapeutic approaches. This interdisciplinary proposal will deploy histotripsy, which is the first non-invasive, non-ionizing, non-thermal, image-guided tumor ablation modality that destroys tumors through the precise control of acoustic cavitation, targeting pancreatic cancer in pre-clinical mouse and novel orthotopic pig models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is designed to determine the effects of obesity on tumor promotion in experimental models of pancreatic cancer. We will test the hypothesis that obesity produces unique signals in the microenvironment of developing pancreatic cancer that are responsible for alterations in tumor fibroblastic cells called pancreatic stellate cells (PaSC) so that they produce signals that promote proliferation and apoptosis resistance in the cancer cells as well as shift the immune response in the tumor making it resistant to immune defenses. We will also test if the cholesterol lowering drug simvastatin and the anti-diabetes drug metformin prevent these PaSC promoting effects on the developing tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Various types of extracellular matrix (ECM) play important roles in shape and pattern formation during cardiac development through dynamic interactions with cells. Our research team will create three-dimensional human embryonic heart models that mimic chamber formation, and utilize artificial intelligence (AI) and ECM microarrays to identify the ECM that most effectively induces chamber-shape formation. Then, we will analyze the biological and physical effects of the optimized ECM at single-cell resolution to elucidate the mechanisms of ECM-cell interactions for cardiac development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sinusoidal and lymphatic vessels are lined by distinct, VEGFR3-expressing endothelial cells, but the mechanisms by which these specialized vasculatures grow remain incompletely understood. Our preliminary studies reveal a reciprocal negative regulatory loop between VEGFC-VEGFR3 signaling and CDH5 function such that gain of CDH5 function confers loss of sinusoidal or lymphatic growth like that observed with loss of VEGFC or VEGFR3, and loss of CDH5 function enables growth of sinusoidal and lymphatic vessels in the complete absence of VEGFR3. This proposal will define the molecular mechanisms of this regulatory axis, and test the ability of CDH5 manipulation to enhance sinusoidal and lymphatic growth in mature animals to improve hematopoietic and lymphatic regeneration in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The current project targets body image as a risk factor for poor weight loss outcomes. Using the Obesity- Related Behavioral Intervention Trials (ORBIT) model, an empirically-supported body image intervention developed for adolescent females will be refined to increase suitability, appropriateness, and enhance treatment effects for women with overweight or obesity who are attempting weight loss. Utilizing a systematic approach to addressing risk factors for poor treatment outcome is aligned with priorities for personalized obesity medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: African American women are three to four times more likely to die of pregnancy related complications than non- Hispanic white women. This study will scale a community, provider, and system-level intervention to reduce African American maternal morbidity and mortality disparities and will test the intervention using data from all Medicaid insured women who deliver in Michigan from 2016-2019 and 2021–2024 (approximately 540,000 births, including 162,000 births to African American women).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HCT) is a curative therapy for hematologic malignancy; however, chronic graft-versus host disease (cGVHD) remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. Steroid, the standard initial therapy of cGVHD, often is unsuccessful in preventing permanent organs damage and has been associated with toxicities. This research proposal is to understand how medium chain fatty acid (MCFA) signaling regulates cGVHD pathobiology and validate MCFA- metabolism targeting as a valid approach to treat cGVHD and steroid refractory cGVHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to understand how alterations in insulin peptide presentation can promote changes in T cell selection that lead to increased autoimmunity and diabetes pathogenesis. Improved knowledge of how changes in peptide epitopes affect the generation of pathogenic effector T cells versus selection of suppressive T regulatory cells will have broader application to a more mechanistic understanding of T cell selection in the thymus as well as for mechansisms of peripheral tolerance. Finally, results of our work will determine if manipulation of insulin peptide epitopes can provide a potential target for furture efforts in tolerance induction and therapeutic intervention Type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Kaposi's sarcoma (KS) is the most common cancer in people living with AIDS, and lymphomas are the second most common. The Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV) also called human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is the etiologic agent of KS and some lymphomas. We will develop laboratory models that resemble diseases caused by KSHV, including the immune tumor microenvironment, which will allow us to test new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Expansion of a GGGGCC repeat in the C9orf72 gene is the most common known cause of two devastating neurodegenerative diseases, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and frontotemporal dementia. This repeat generates toxic proteins in patient brains through a non-canonical form of RNA translation. My project is aimed at elucidating how this unusual form of translation works and developing tools aimed at reducing its efficiency as a path towards therapeutic development in these currently untreatable disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Directed evolution is a valuable technique for the development and optimization of proteins with valua- ble new functions, as well as for the elucidation of fundamental biological mechanisms that impact the ability of proteins to robustly explore mutational space. A major issue that currently limits the power of these ap- proaches, however, is that current directed evolution workflows are currently performed almost exclusively in simple systems such as test tubes, yeast, or bacteria. This research will (1) build and apply next-generation, human cell-based directed evolution platforms to open new doors in research and biotechnology and (2) apply evolution strategies in human cells to illuminate how the proteostasis network impacts protein evolution, espe- cially as it relates to diseases like cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Maternal-fetal medicine clinicians still lack the ability to understand placental health and function, critical for a successful pregnancy, in real time with non-invasive methodologies. We propose to use experimental interventions in a nonhuman primate model expected to result in inflammation, placental and decidual lesions, and disrupted intervillous blood flow to refine and optimize magnetic resonance imaging as a method for the real-time assessment of placental function. Since inflammation and disrupted blood flow are thought to be primary contributors to adverse pregnancy outcomes including fetal growth restriction, these studies will work towards the ultimate goal to be able to identify problems and “treat the placenta” to improve the health of both mothers and babies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The vast majority of justice-involved youth struggle with multiple behavioral health problems. Substance use, disruptive behavior, depression, and trauma-related stress are among the most common co-occurring problems. A small fraction of youth receive needed treatment services as problems begin to emerge, however, due to the dearth of accessible, effective early treatment resources within the juvenile justice system. This research aims to develop and pilot test a theoretically grounded, web-based, multicomponent behavior change early intervention that features personalized, youth-centered elements to optimize efficacy, equity, usability and engagement, and that will expand access to treatment at the early-stage level for underserved adolescents.

PHR: Project Narrative: Reducing excess food consumption in response to food advertising is a public health goal for preventing excess weight gain and the development of obesity in children. Food marketing is a major contributor to childhood obesity, and the proposed research will identify neurobiological and behavioral characteristics that protect some children from overeating in the presence of this cue. These findings will have direct implications for the development of more effective strategies to reduce energy intake for the prevention of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sodium MRI (NaMRI) has been challenging due to inherently low signal-to-noise and resolution but holds much promise in the study of neurological diseases including Mild Traumatic Brain Injury (MTBI) where the underlying mechanisms are still unclear and effective therapies are badly needed. Here we propose innovative multinuclear imaging techniques including advances in coil design, acquisition optimization, image reconstruction as well as cutting-edge MRI microstructure modeling to optimally quantify in vivo NaMRI signal in MTBI. We will study the relationship between NaMRI, microstructural injury and clinical outcome at 3.0 Tesla, translating promising evidence from cell and animal studies to a clinical MTBI population in the search for effective noninvasive surrogate imaging markers for injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Precision medicine promises to customize medical care to the individual patient based on their genome and individual environment and behaviors. However, we lack a basic understanding of the causal connections between the genome and complex trait hierarchies, in which a suite of sub-phenotypes all contribute to produce a high-level phenotype. This research will use a model system to provide general insights into trait hierarchies, with relevance to many health-related trait hierarchies, such as coronary artery disease, exercise endurance, or metabolic syndrome.

PROJECT_TITLE: Genome evolution across complex trait hierarchies

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because determining how C. difficile is able to benefit from the loss of colonization resistance in the gut has major implications for the development of microbiome based therapeutics for prevention and treatment of CDI and many other GI diseases. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burdens of human illness. The research is also relevant to the part of the NIGMS’s mission that pertains to supporting basic research, which increases the understanding of biological processes and lays the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention. The contribution of the proposed research is significant because it will define the dynamic relationship between nutrient availability and bile acid metabolism at the level of the individual microbial species in commensal Clostridia and within a microbial community. This proposal seeks to define their individual and combinatorial roles in how the gut microbiota is able to provide colonization resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinically significant anxiety and depression symptoms co-occur in nearly half of individuals seeking treatment for alcohol use disorder and reduce one's likelihood of responding to current treatments. Reductions in positive valence processing, including the experience of and response to positive emotions and situations, are often observed for both alcohol use disorder and anxiety/depression and relate to worse clinical outcomes. The proposed study will (a) further develop and refine a novel behavioral intervention, Amplification of Positivity for alcohol use disorder and co-occurring anxiety and depression (AMP-A), using both clinician and participant feedback and (b) examine the impact of AMP-A on self-reported positive valence processing, as well as clinical symptoms related to alcohol use, anxiety, and depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will delineate mechanisms by which sickle cell disease, the most common inherited blood disorder in the U.S., causes accelerated damage to arteries in children and adults which can lead to devastating mental and physical disabilities, and even death, predominantly affecting a racial minority in the United States, but millions globally. Identifying proteolytic culprits, effects on the biomechanics of the vessels, and physiological consequences will provide new strategies to protect the vasculature of people born with this genetic disease, improving their quality of life, which is relevant to NIH’s mission of enhancing health, lengthening life, and reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Payer coverage and economic value continue to be critical factors in determining whether genomic medicine is appropriately and efficiently implemented into clinical care and health policies. However, genomic tests are now emerging that present particularly difficult challenges for coverage and value determinations because they (a) will be used for screening and early detection in asymptomatic populations in addition to disease management in patients with a condition, and (b) use less-transparent methods, such as algorithmic scores, to establish linkages between genetic markers and disease. Our objective is to assess payer coverage decisions and the economic value of two types of emerging genomic tests for disease management and screening: cell-free DNA tests and tests based on polygenic risk scores.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal seeks to elaborate how DNA repair enzymes protect against mutations caused by damage (deamination) occurring to 5-methylcytosine (mC), a modified DNA base that has essential functions in regulating gene expression. A large fraction of point mutations in cancer and genetic disease are attributable to mC deamination. The studies will reveal how repair enzymes counter this threat and inform why these mutations are still prevalent in human DNA. The studies will also reveal how these enzymes contribute to regulating the levels of DNA methylation (mC), which is important because aberrant DNA methylation is implicated in diseases including cancer, and in ageing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a systemic inflammatory disorder affecting approximately 3 million adults in the United States; interstitial lung disease (ILD), particularly pulmonary fibrosis, is the most common lung complication of RA and is associated with increased mortality. This study aims to define how syndecan-2 (SDC2), an antifibrotic proteoglycan, affects the development of lung fibrosis in the setting of arthritis. The results of this work will provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms driving the pathogenesis of RA-associated lung fibrosis and identify potential therapeutic targets to treat patients with this progressive disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE (3 sentences)  To optimize care for neonatal seizures and their consequences, we propose to use observational methods to study (1) the best second-line anti-seizure medication for acute neonatal seizures (phenytoin/fosphenytoin vs levetiracetam), (2) the potential for subsequent chronic use of sodium channel blockers (i.e., oxcarbazepine) to increase the risk for infantile spasms syndrome, and (3) the reliability and validity of our published model to predict epilepsy among neonates with acute symptomatic seizures who survive into infancy. We will conduct this work using the Pediatric Epilepsy Learning Health System, a consortium of US academic pediatric epilepsy programs that work collaboratively to improve outcomes for children with epilepsy through cycles of electronic health record collection and analysis. The proposal aligns with the 2020 Epilepsy Research Benchmarks and will directly inform clinical care for neonates with acute symptomatic seizures, as well as lay the foundation for epilepsy prevention trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application proposes to establish The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill as a Clinical Research Site (CRS) for the Multicenter AIDS Cohort Study (MACS)/Women’s Interagency HIV Study (WIHS) Combined Cohort Study (MACS/WIHS-CCS). We propose to rapidly establish the UNC MACS/WIHS-CCS CRS, contribute meaningfully to the MACS/WIHS-CCS Unified Science Agenda, and undertake ambitious research that encompasses pulmonary, cardiovascular, neurocognitive, and other HIV-related comorbidities; HIV pathogenesis/cure; social epidemiology and health outcomes; behavioral research; and advanced epidemiologic methods. By contributing a representative population of men and women, innovative science, and a strong, multidisciplinary cadre of investigators, UNC will enhance the efforts of the MACS/WIHS-CCS, expand the range of questions that can be addressed and, in collaboration with the entire group, improve the health of men and women with or at high risk for HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This application is for renewal for 7 years of the Baltimore-Washington DC site of the Multicenter AIDS Cohort Study (MACS), a longstanding study of the natural and treated histories of HIV infection men who have sex with men in four US cites (Baltimore-Washington, Los Angeles, Pittsburgh, Chicago) which has made many important contributions to the treatment and understanding of HIV infection since 1984. For the next 7 years, we propose to integrate our site with the 9 WIHS sites into a new MACS-WIHS Combined Cohort Study (CCS) which will follow men already enrolled in Baltimore and Washington, DC, and also recruit a few new men replacing those who have been lost to the study, in order to better understand the long-term consequences of living with HIV, including possible effects on chronic diseases and aging, and to improve our understanding of the mechanisms of these consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The NC CRS is part of the longest-running prospective study of the natural and treated history of HIV infection in people at risk for becoming infected. This ongoing study chronicles biological and psychosocial factors that have shaped the epidemic, tracking HIV disease and HIV-related comorbidities. The knowledge gained regarding effects of the virus and aging on inflammation and immune dysfunction, which render some people more susceptible to HIV-related comorbidities than others, will improve the clinical care of people living with HIV/AIDS, guide public health public health policy, facilitate discovery of novel drug targets, and contribute to vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to test whether a novel behavioral activation/problem solving based counseling intervention results in higher rates of smoking cessation than standard behavioral counseling among HIV+ smokers in Botswana. It will also assess whether changes in hypothesized mediators (depressive symptoms, use of substitute reinforcers and avoidance of complementary reinforcers of smoking behavior and problem solving skill) are the mechanisms behind successful quitting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Risky drinking behavior (i.e., episodic binge and high-intensity drinking), which peaks in young adulthood, is estimated to account for more than 40,000 deaths annually and over $167 Billion in economic costs in the United States. Young adult risky drinkers are a heterogeneous group, which makes them very difficult to study and to predict who will go on to develop lasting problems with alcohol use and alcohol use disorder. This research will implement cutting-edge machine learning techniques, and apply them to data collected from daily surveys and passive smartphone sensors in young adult risky drinkers to develop personalized models of problematic alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NAFLD/NASH is the most common chronic liver disease with a heavy social burden but no effective drug treatment at present. Our project for the first time aims at developing a personalized genetic medicine for NAFLD/NASH, which has a great impact on both improving the human health and reducing social burden. We use a novel and unprecedented approach in this project, which has a great potential to establish a new paradigm for drug develop for other common diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Drugs of abuse activate specific cell populations within brain reward circuits, but it is not clear what molecular mechanisms regulate this process or how drug experience can result in long-lasting changes within these cells. This proposal will examine the role of Reelin, a large extracellular protein, in regulation of the molecular and genetic mechanisms that contribute to cellular and behavioral responses to cocaine. This research will contribute fundamental knowledge to our understanding of how brain circuits drive motivated behaviors in the context of substance abuse disorders, and has the potential to identify novel cellular targets for addiction therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dysregulation of inhibitory signaling is implicated in a wide array of neurological disorders and diseases, including those with cognitive and/or affective components. The goal of this project is to investigate the role of a family of modular regulatory complexes and related factors that shape the strength, sensitivity, and temporal precision of a prevalent form of inhibitory signaling in neurons. Successful completion of this project will yield new insights that could be leveraged to develop novel therapeutic approaches for neurological problems characterized by aberrant inhibitory signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer is a leading cause of cancer morbidity and mortality in the United States. Pathway activation of signaling proteins is hypothesized to be a crucial step in the progression of prostate cancer toward a lethal variant of prostate cancer that lacks androgen receptor signaling known as neuroendocrine prostate cancer (NEPC). The proposed research will aim to identify RET transcriptional regulation and implicate RET tyrosine kinase signaling as a key therapeutic target for NEPC with the goal to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with lethal NEPC.
