IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GH and IGF-1 act on peripheral tissues to importantly influence growth, metabolism and body composition across the human lifespan. In GH disorders, these are substantially altered. Central effects of GH may also affect these processes. This project utilizes human models, healthy subjects and GH deficient patients administered GH, to investigate the GH-AgRP axis, which we hypothesize is a key mechanism of GH’s nutritional and metabolic effects. We study the potential role of GH-stimulated AgRP in GH-induced metabolic abnormalities and a potential therapy for them. This project will provide valuable insights into the role of AgRP and the GH- AgRP axis in GH disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed studies will facilitate the therapeutic development of a novel class of oxysterol molecules that have been found to inhibit transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β), Hedgehog (Hh) and Toll-Like Receptor (TLR) signaling that are the main drivers of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Our lead compound, Oxy210, inhibits NASH as well as atherosclerosis and inflammation in white fat tissue in a humanized mouse model and has favorable pharmacokinetic and safety profiles. In proposed studies in this application, we will provide further support for the candidacy of Oxy210 for development into potentially potent orally available anti-fibrosis compounds for the treatment of NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Circadian desynchrony, such as in millions of shift workers, is a strong risk factor for diabetes and atherovascular disease (AVD), the leading cause of death in the United States. We and others have shown the critical function of the central and intrinsic molecular clocks in regulating cellular stress pathways, and that their disruption leads to diabetes and AVD. However, the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood and there is no specific therapy to prevent circadian desynchrony-induced diabetes and AVD. We have assembled an interdisciplinary Multi-PI team with complementary expertise to investigate how loss of synchronization between environment, central clock and peripheral clocks leads to dysregulated cellular stress responses and cardiometabolic diseases, and test potentially translatable environmental and pharmacological protective interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement  Deregulation of the ERK1/2 signaling cascade is found in 30% of all tumors and multiple developmental abnormalities. While virtually every component of the cascade is target for therapeutic development, the effective targeting of this pathway in disease relies upon a clear understanding of all the intricacies in modulating numerous signaling components. The results of this study focused on the non-canonical regulators of the ERK1/2 pathway may lead to the discovery of new diagnostics as well as new treatments for diseases including Noonan-like Syndrome and some cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Although several model systems exist for bacterial viruses, the proposed research will result in a greater mechanistic understanding of the diversity these viruses use to recognize their host cells, replicate and assemble to produce additional progeny viruses, and persist in the environment. Given the ongoing issues with antibiotic resistance and renewed interest in using viruses to combat bacterial infections, these goals are relevant to human health by specifically addressing current issues with phage therapy. This proposal is relevant to the NIAID’s mission by providing foundational information for treating infectious diseases or detecting bacterial contamination prior to infection by specifically examining the interactions between these viruses and the causative agent of bacillary dysentery, Shigella flexneri.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate Cancer is a serious health crisis in the United States and remains the second leading cause of cancer-related male deaths despite implementation of new screening methods and therapeutic drugs for this disease. Glycosylation, involving the covalent attachment of carbohydrates onto proteins and lipids, is shown to impact their molecular stability, cellular localization, biological function and malignancy - but virtually nothing is known about the new field of glycosylated RNAs (glycoRNAs) or their role in human disease such as prostate cancer. Innovative/exploratory work described in this proposal employing a spectrum of human prostate cancer cell lines and an in vivo mouse model for prostate cancer will drastically improve our understanding of glycoRNA mechanisms involved during prostate tumor progression and lead to novel RNA-based biomarker and treatment strategies for lethal prostate cancer.

This research is relevant to public health because it is anticipated that the results will improve our understanding of the relationships between obesity and metabolic disorders. The proposed studies are relevant to the mission of the NIDDK because they are expected to identify new therapeutic approaches for the management of common disorders related to excessive lipid accumulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of highly curable head and neck cancers is rapidly rising and there are more long-term survivors than ever. Radiation treatment is very commonly given at doses sufficient to cause crippling late cranial neuropathy (nerve dysfunction) and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) that can progress to the point that it results in a lifelong feeding tube or death from aspiration pneumonia even after cancer is cured. This application seeks to understand how abnormal nerve function in the tongue may be present and measured long before it is evident in clinic, hopefully to provide an earlier therapy target to help swallowing function before irreversible damage is done.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project develops novel imaging capabilities for optical coherence tomography (OCT) systems in the clinic. Analyzing the polarization state of the OCT light may enable earlier detection of glaucoma, which is the leading cause of irreversible blindness. Used for intracoronary imaging after myocardial infarction and coronary syndromes, it may improve patient management and help prevent future adverse coronary events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Recent advances in HIV science make ending the epidemic achievable, yet barriers to implementing proven strategies in practice persist. HIV disparities, rising incidence of HIV in marginalized populations, increasingly complex HIV co-morbidities, presence of social and structural barriers, and the need for cost-effective approaches present continuing challenges to public health. CIRA will provide a nexus for scientific inquiry and research collaborations to advance implementation of effective solutions to the epidemic in the U.S and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many cancers, including metastatic prostate cancer, resist molecularly targeted therapy by altering their phenotype from one that is dependent on the target to one that is not. Here we characterize genetic mutations and epigenetic mechanisms that drive transformation from androgen dependent prostate cancer to androgen independent prostate cancer. The goal is to identify new approaches for treating lethal prostate cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project conducts early-stage development of a paper-based device to facilitate the efficient recovery of high-quality nucleic acids from breastmilk for use in breast cancer risk assessment and national epidemiologic studies. The proposed device will facilitate the collection and loading of breastmilk on a small paper card which can be sent through the mail and stored flat at room temperature for long times, or indefinitely, allowing subsequent recovery of nucleic acids. The project addresses the requirement to process relatively large volumes of breastmilk on the card and develops a means to retain nucleic acids while drawing excess fluid into a disposable layer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Soil-transmitted helminth infections represents a significant global public health and economic burden. Therefore, there is an urgent need to improve our understanding of genetic and environmental modulators of type 2 cytokine-dependent immunity in order to identify novel preventative and therapeutic approaches for this group of infectious agents. Based on our new preliminary data, the focus of this proposal is to dissect the influence of diet-induced modulation of microbiota-derived metabolites in regulating type 2 cytokine responses and protective immunity to helminth infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Protein tyrosine phosphatases contribute to an enormous number of diseases (e.g., diabetes, obesity, cancer, Alzheimer's disease, autoimmunity, and heart disease) but lack targeted therapeutics. This project uses microorganisms to build molecules that inhibit or activate these enzymes. In doing so, it builds a framework for molecular discovery that will facilitate the study, design, and assembly of new varieties of therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients initiating hemodialysis are at significantly higher risk of morbidity and mortality than age- and sex- matched patients from the general population. Empagliflozin, a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor, has been shown to reduce cardiovascular risk, heart failure, and to slow kidney function decline in patients with kidney disease, but the safety and efficacy of this therapy among patients with kidney failure initiating hemodialysis is not clear. We propose a pilot randomized placebo-controlled clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of empagliflozin in patients initiating hemodialysis and thereby inform the design of a larger multi- center study to evaluate hard clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: With the epidemic burden of obesity and metabolic diseases, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is becoming one of the most common hepatic diseases worldwide. Our project proposes to study the mechanisms underlying liver macrophage pro-inflammatory activation and the contribution of this process to NAFLD development and progression. Knowledge gained from our studies may lead to novel therapeutic strategies in the treatment of obesity-associated NAFLD/NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Children and adults born extremely premature (<28 weeks gestational age) are 17 times more likely to develop heart failure by early adulthood, yet the reasons and rate of progression are poorly understood. This study will develop cardiac growth and function trajectories, with the expectation to identify poor cardiac growth and accelerated rates of functional decline in children and adults born preterm. Study results will provide justification for future early intervention studies to promote cardiac growth and preserve cardiac function after preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Progressive difficulty in performing everyday functional activities is a key diagnostic feature of dementia syndromes, but little is known about the neural signature of functional decline, particularly during the very early stages of dementia. We apply a novel neurophysiological approach to measure brain activation during complex gait based functional tasks to establish a biomarker and predictor of functional decline during the preclinical dementia period before overt impairment is observed. Establishing the clinical relevance and biological basis of the neural signature of functional decline will improve early detection and maintain functional abilities, independence, and quality of life in older adults at-risk for dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Now in its 55th year, Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) is a foundational resource, a knowledgebase of human genes and genetic disorders and traits that is accessed annually by over 2.7 million unique users worldwide. Its core mission is (1) describing, naming, and classifying genetic diseases, and (2) providing easily accessible and computable information on gene-disease relationships through rich, structured text, brief clinical synopses, and a table that tracks the progress of disease-gene discovery. Expert MD- and PhD- biocurators review and summarize information from the biomedical literature to create this authoritative, comprehensive and timely resource that is essential for the practice of medicine, and directly advances basic, translational, and clinical research, as well as therapeutic discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) highly requires precise radiation delivery in the presence of tumor motion to eradicate tumors with highly potent dose while minimizing normal tissue dose to reduce treatment toxicity. Our proposed study aims to develop a real-time volumetric imaging-based tumor tracking and dose verification system for lung photon SBRT that will substantially improve treatment accuracy and precision and guarantee high treatment quality throughout the entire treatment course. This system is expected to revolutionize the current clinical practice of lung radiotherapy, and can be adopted for a wide range of clinical applications and easily adapted for liver and pancreas SBRT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persons with opioid use disorder in methadone and buprenorphine treatment programs are a very vulnerable population with exceptionally high combustible cigarettes smoking burden and yet limited success in achieving meaningful clinical outcomes in tobacco treatment. We propose an open-label, randomized controlled trial to compare the effect of electronic cigarettes to combination nicotine replacement therapy on combustible cigarettes smoking reduction. If effective, electronic cigarettes would provide an additional tool for tobacco harm reduction among this difficult-to-treat vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Lymphedema, which is symptomatic swelling caused by damage of the lymphatic system commonly caused by cancer treatment, can have devastating and permanent clinical and financial consequences for patients. We propose developing a noninvasive, MRI-based, clinically- translational technique that can provide anatomic maps of the lymphatic system in vivo, enabling surgeons to plan surgery to avoid lymphatic damage. If successful, this method would potentially shift the entire paradigm of lymphedema management, from a current focus on therapy to one of prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Narrative (Relevance) The DNA of our cells is frequently broken and must be faithfully repaired for life to continue. Failure of faithful DNA break-repair by genetic recombination leads to birth defects, infertility, and cancer. Inhibitors of DNA break-repair in bacteria can be developed into novel, sorely needed antibiotics to combat the ever-threatening emergence of drug-resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Targeting RAS/MAPK oncogenic signaling using RAF and MEK inhibitors has shown significant activity in cancer patients, but the antitumor effectiveness of these drugs is limited by adaptive resistance. Further, the effects of RAS/MAPK-targeted therapies on normal tissue, including the immune system, are largely unknown. Our goal is to study mechanisms of RAS regulation and adaptive resistance to MAPK inhibition, develop more effective pharmacologic combinatorial strategies for MAPK-dependent tumors and identify molecular determinants of response to these strategies that can be used as predictive biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed project will develop a novel teixobactin-lipopeptide hybrid antibiotic for the inhalation treatment of lung infections caused by bacterial `superbugs' which are resistant to all current antibiotics. The future outcomes of this innovative project will significantly advance medicine and directly benefit patients by developing urgently needed new treatments for otherwise untreatable bacterial lung infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative – Public Health Relevance The use of pluripotent stem cells for regenerative medicine holds enormous potential for understanding the root causes of diseases, as well as designing innovative strategies for treating a host of human disorders. However, this rapidly growing field is in need of highly trained scientists with expertise in stem cell biology, regeneration, and the technological methods for their applications in regenerative biology and medicine. The Frontiers in Stem Cells and Regeneration Course at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, MA promotes advances in the field by bringing together scientific experts and students in an advanced, hands-on training course, thus enhancing the training of the next generation of highly skilled stem cell scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will investigate the causative clinical factors, demographic variables, and genomic variants associated with bicuspid aortic valve aortopathy, a heritable condition with poorly understood pathogenesis. The proposal will use artificial intelligence methods of predictive modeling to discover clinical and demographic variables associated with BAV aortopathy as well as whole genome sequencing analysis to define the drivers of this complex disease. Successful completion of this study will allow development of precision medicine tools to predict aortic disease risk at the individual patient level. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extensive evidence in humans and animal models suggest that reduced long-range connectivity and disconnection between brain areas are signatures of schizophrenia. However little is about how such reduced connectivity affects specific circuit components and cortical function. The overall goal of this project is to determine how altered bottom-up and top-down connectivity in schizophrenia impacts sensory processing, and unveil the role of neurogliaform cells, a GABAergic cell type highly affected in schizophrenia, in bottom-up and top-down sensory processing in health and in the context of schizophrenia. Ultimately, such knowledge has the potential to offer new opportunities for identification of biomarkers of disease and for therapeutic interventions that target specific circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Cardiometabolic (CM) diseases including cardiovascular (CV) and metabolic diseases are interconnected and positively associated with multi-domain Cardiometabolic Risk Factors (CMRFs) such as metabolic dysregulation, obesity, physical inactivity, poor nutrition, and other emerging factors (including and especially sleep disorders). CMRFs are highly and increasingly prevalent in the young population that foreshadows a future epidemic of incident CM diseases as they age, but existing studies on CM health have primarily focused on the adult and senior population with little to no knowledge on adolescents and young adults. We propose a multi-study cross-dataset secondary analysis for CM subgroup discovery and risk prediction in adolescents (11-18) and young adults (19-39) using two combined datasets from NHANES and NSRR, providing evidence-based guidelines to facilitate early and targeted interventions and help establish health promoting behaviors in adolescents and young adults, and eventually improving CM health care in their transition to adulthood and reducing CM health disparities and costs in the U.S. as the young population ages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Persons of Mexican and Central American heritage have the highest rates of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), leading to rising morbidity from cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Behavioral weight loss interventions may improve NAFLD outcomes, but little is known about how to do so effectively among this population. The proposed research will provide important insights into behavioral strategies and interventions to reduce the burden of this public health problem and health disparity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor cell motility is a complex but carefully coordinated process that contributes to disease progression by enabling tumor cells to disseminate away from the primary tumor (metastasize). Extracellular vesicles (EV) have recently been identified as important contributors to tumor cell motility and cancer metastasis, however, it remains unknown how cancer can control the production of such vesicles and how this is coordinated with other mechanisms of cell motility. We will investigate how integration of cell-cell adhesion with vesicle biogenesis ultimately controls EV production and aim to show how this coordination controls tumor cell motility and metastasis.

PHR: This project is focused on characterizing how stabilizing the active sites of protein kinases in specific conformations affect their biochemical and cellular properties. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In a complex, yet structured world, abstraction is a process that identifies the common features across past experiences in such a way that both allows for a more compact representation and can be generalized to new experiences so as guide behavioral and emotional responses. Here we develop a theoretical framework and analytic toolkit for studying how the human brain learns, represents, and utilizes abstract knowledge in a format that supports generalization, and how this process of abstraction interfaces with motivational states. Our work promises to elucidate the mechanisms of abstract learning in the human brain and lays the foundation for studying how abstraction and generalization go awry in psychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is a leading cause of death worldwide, with tragic consequences for individuals and their families. Despite major resources invested over the last decades to find strategies to reduce the incidence of suicides and suicide attempts, rates of attempted and completed suicide have increased in the last 20 years. The proposed research seeks to address the need for rapid, safe and effective treatments to prevent suicide in the most vulnerable periods (i.e. psychiatric hospitalization and post-discharge weeks) by studying individualized MRI-guided accelerated transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) to a novel parietal brain target and assessing both target engagement (to a new suicide biomarker) and clinical efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE G. Zarkada Abnormal formation of new blood vessels is the fundamental cause of catastrophic vision loss during ocular neovascularization, stressing the urgent need for development of new treatments. We have identified components of the transforming growth factor-β (TGFβ) signaling pathway that strongly affect retinal angiogenesis, both in pro- and anti-angiogenic ways. We propose to selectively manipulate TGFβ signaling components in endothelial cells, in order to treat retinopathy in preclinical models of retinal vascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastrointestinal disorders caused by pathogenic bacteria represent a serious health problem worldwide by causing high mortality in infant, immunocompromised and elderly people and contributing to chronic inflammatory conditions, such as inflammatory bowel diseases. This project will improve understanding the pathogenesis of gastrointestinal bacterial infections by exploring novel mechanisms that regulate pathogen interactions with intestinal epithelium and bacterial invasion into host cells. Furthermore, it will identify novel targets for pharmacological prevention of intestinal colonization by pathogenic bacteria, which would decrease morbidity and mortality of a large cohort of patients with enteric infections.

PHR: Project Narrative: Liver cirrhosis is one of the leading causes of death worldwide, and alcoholic liver disease (ALD) accounts for half of cirrhosis-associated death. Alcohol-induced DNA damage and the consequent hepatocyte cell death have been shown to participate in ALD progression. Clarifying the involvement of ALD-induced aspartate beta- hydroxylase down-regulation in exacerbating hepatocyte DNA damage and cell death may identify the potential therapeutic approach for ALD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Kingdom of eSwatini has the world’s highest prevalence of HIV, but has become a world leader in HIV treatment and achieved dramatic declines in HIV mortality. In contrast, deaths from many non-communicable diseases (NCDs) in eSwatini are increasing, including the second-leading cause of death after HIV: cardiovascular disease. This project will examine the potential efficiency of HIV/NCD care integration over the future course of the HIV epidemic, identify optimal health benefits packages produce the greatest health benefits across major communicable and non-communicable diseases, and consider potential adjustments to health benefits due to the risk of future health systems disruptions such as pandemics, conflict, and natural disasters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Segmental-loss peripheral nerve injuries are currently rather in-effectively treated with cadaveric nerve allografts, stimulating slow regeneration of outgrowing axons with various drugs or other substances. Our proposal seeks to investigate and develop potentially synergistic methods of axon fusion and localized immunosuppression of peripheral nerve allografts to circumvent these problems and lead to a new standard of treatment for segmental-loss peripheral nerve defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Cigarette smoking is the leading cause of death and morbidity from any addictive drug, responsible for 400,000 deaths per year in the US, and direct healthcare costs exceeding $170 billion/yr. Only ~20% of smokers achieve long-term abstinence using standard of care pharmacotherapies and there have been no FDA authorized anti-smoking treatments with a novel mechanism of action (MOA) since 2006. Following a recent pre- IND meeting with the FDA for ATI-1013 (an anti-nicotine human monoclonal antibody with a novel MOA that has achieved pre-clinical proof-of-concept), this project is focused on completing the remaining preclinical drug development and regulatory work in accordance with the specific FDA recommendations received to obtain an approved IND and begin clinical testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin resistance is a key factor in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes, which affects more than 400 million people worldwide. This proposal aims to study the mechanism, regulation, and physiological function of spatiotemporal regulation of insulin signaling by key regulators of cell division. This research may establish uncontrolled loss of insulin receptor at the cell surface as a cause of insulin resistance in type 2 diabetes, and suggest novel therapeutic targets in treating this prevalent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Oxycodone is consistently among the medications most widely prescribed for pain, but is also most widely abused and involved in overdose deaths, creating an urgent need for interventions that preserve oxycodone analgesia while curtailing its abuse potential. Research shows that the neuropeptide oxytocin has no recognized abuse potential, might reduce the abuse liability of opioids, and simultaneously has analgesic properties. The present study will determine if oxytocin will significantly reduce the abuse potential of oxycodone and experimental pain, which could lead to a novel therapeutic particularly among mid-age and older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project seeks to increase our ability to accurately and reliably assess the clinically important construct of alcohol craving. Potential psychobiologic correlates of alcohol craving will be investigated which, if deemed reliable, may provide a much needed objective marker of craving to the field of addiction science. Further, the development of an ecologically valid virtual reality cue-exposure paradigm will advance our ability to induce craving in the laboratory and provide a platform by which future craving-related interventions can be tested.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant investment in biomedical research to reduce the burden of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) on individuals, their families, and society, most innovations generated have not been designed for scalability or implementation outside of research settings and are poorly diffused across the various healthcare delivery organizations. Over the past decade, an interdisciplinary team of scientists at Indiana University (IU) has developed and tested agile methods to design, implement, and diffuse evidence- based behavioral and social science interventions. In response to the NIA RFA-AG-22-010, the IU team is proposing to leverage its expertise in agile science to train the ADRD research workforce on agile methodologies for designing (Agile Innovation), implementing (Agile Implementation), and diffusing (Agile Diffusion) “nudges” to influence the behaviors of patients living with ADRD and both their care professionals and informal caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Chronic exposure to ambient particulate matter (PM) leads to systemic inflammation and cardiovascular disease. Promoting the endogenous active mechanisms of resolution may interrupt persistent inflammatory inputs induced by PM. Here, we will assess the impacts of PM exposure on the cellular facilitators of resolution and determine whether their response to PM governs systemic immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is a serious public health problem whose biological basis remains unknown. Here, we use a new technology to directly measure dopamine and serotonin, neurotransmitters thought to be central in depression, in awake individuals with and without depression as they undergo depth electrode monitoring for epilepsy. In order to make significant advances in understanding and developing novel therapies for the disorder, directly and accurately studying neuromodulator responses in humans is required.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is a frequently fatal type of blood disorder with few therapeutic options due to challenges in distinguishing and targeting the abnormal immature cells in the bone marrow. We have discovered that the levels of a specific receptor called CCRL2 are significantly higher in MDS cells compared to healthy cells and this molecule promotes the growth of these abnormal cells. We propose to determine the specific mechanisms of the growth activities of CCRL2 in MDS and develop therapies that will effectively suppress the growth of abnormal cells in MDS patients. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Early diagnosis of pancreatic cancer (PDAC) remains challenging due to its asymptomatic nature, lack of early detection biomarkers, and limited availability of samples. This Clinical Validation Center (CVC) proposal aims to validate a previously optimized panel of biomarkers in blood and cyst fluid for risk stratification and early detection of PDAC in high-risk surveillance (pancreatic cystic lesions and subjects with a family history of malignancy due to germline mutation), and sporadic cohorts that are an increased risk for having an undiagnosed PDAC (patients with new-onset diabetes and chronic pancreatitis). A combination of retrospective and prospective studies will establish the clinical utility of biomarker panels for detecting interval malignancy in surveillance cohorts and early detection of sporadic malignancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UW/Fred Hutch Center for AIDS Research (CFAR) is a multi-institutional consortium based in Seattle which catalyzes new HIV research and develops new research leaders across the multidisciplinary spectrum of basic, clinical, epidemiologic, statistical, sociobehavioral, and implementation science expertise necessary to bend the curve of the global HIV epidemic. During 35 years of continuous funding, the UW/Fred Hutch CFAR has facilitated substantial growth in research infrastructure, domestic and international partnerships, research impact, and development of emerging HIV researchers (with a return on investment on CFAR developmental awards of 1767%) with high added value and aided by significant institutional commitment. Through our proposed eight Cores and two Scientific Working Groups, we aim to expand multidisciplinary HIV research that spans bench to bedside to populations and grow new researchers, research leaders, infrastructure, and resources to impact the global epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement/ Narrative The impact of air pollution and psychosocial stress on mental health outcomes remains poorly understood, particularly in the younger populations in which psychiatric symptoms often first arise. This proposal will explore the impact of air pollution and non-chemical stressors in relation to symptoms of anxiety and depression in preadolescents and the role of stress-related pathways in these relationships. Identification of modifiable risk factors during these earlier life stages could help prevent future mental and physical health burden later in life, resulting in an enormous benefit to individuals and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, tropical cyclones, such as hurricanes and tropical storms, have a devastating effect on society, yet a comprehensive assessment of their health impacts is still lacking. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on quantifying the hospitalization and mortality burden of tropical cyclones while also characterizing physical factors that drive differences in impacts on vulnerable communities. The results of this project are expected to greatly beneﬁt understanding of the health impacts of tropical cyclone exposure, and create actionable results that identify the most vulnerable communities, closely aligned with NIEHS's mission and Strategic Plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Impact The Research Colloquium for Junior Psychiatrist Investigators (Research Colloquium) is an innovative multi-component research training, mentoring and career development program that involves interactive pre- and post-colloquium webinars, a 2-day, immersive, mentoring and networking event, a 6-month booster session at the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology Annual Meeting, a 12-month booster session at the Society of Biological Psychiatry, and yearlong networking and mentoring through an online Research Colloquium community. The program helps address the documented lack of psychiatric researchers, especially among women and ethnic minorities, in this country, by providing research experience for early career psychiatrists, including senior residents, research fellows and junior faculty across age, ethnoracial, gender identity and sexual orientation groups, who meet with distinguished senior research mentors to receive advice on their planned research studies. The overarching goal is to encourage early career psychiatrist investigators, especially minoritized populations and women, to develop and maintain a research career path and includes pre- and post-colloquium activities such as webinars, interactive online Q&A sessions, and discussion boards to ensure longer-term mentoring and career guidance to the junior investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The histidine kinases and histidine phosphatases are a poorly understood family of enzymes that play critical roles in G-protein signaling, ion conduction, central metabolism and chromatin biology and have been implicated in diseases as diverse as cardiovascular disease and cancer. The main barrier to a better understanding of these enzymes is a lack of tools available to study them. Research in the Barrios lab is focused on developing the tools necessary to study the enzymes involved in histidine phosphorylation and dephosphorylation, including cell-compatible fluorogenic substrates and targeted inhibitors. In addition, we are investigating the context cues that facilitate histidine phosphorylation and the impact of histidine phosphorylation on protein structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Peripheral axon loss, poor sensation and pain are all components associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy and new treatment approaches to correct these complications are desperately needed. We will determine if ketones bodies have direct actions on sensory neurons to improve their metabolism, stimulate axon growth, improve sensation and reduce pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco remains the leading preventable cause of death in the U.S. and is also the leading preventable cause of death among people with substance use disorders. This innovative training program has a primary focus on tobacco with emerging areas of focus on cannabis and tobacco co-use and industry research that extends from tobacco to pharmaceutical opioids. We will prepare the next generation of leaders in substance use and addiction science with a combination of coursework and mentored research in a collaborative environment that has a proven record of integrating multiple disciplines to translate science to improve public health policy and clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of our work is to understand how mammalian cells integrate receptor signals and cell contacts to make decisions whether to move and proliferate. These decisions are critical both for cancer and tissue regeneration and understanding how cells make these decisions will predict synergistic signaling activities that can be targeted to treat cancer and restore tissue function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Endothelial cells regulate arterial contractility. Dysfunctional endothelial cell control of contractility is a hallmark of several cardiovascular diseases, including hypertension, but pathological mechanisms involved are poorly understood. We will investigate the novel hypothesis that rapid trafficking of small-conductance calcium-activated channels regulates arterial contractility, investigate signaling mechanisms involved and test the concept that vasodilation mediated through these pathways is dysfunctional during hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide a novel approach to mitigating aldehyde overload, a common pathological condition that currently has no clinical treatments. Small molecule intracellular metal catalysts (SIMCats) could offer therapeutic advantages over conventional aldehyde traps due to their distinct catalytic detoxification mechanism. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence-based treatments for Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) in young adults are lacking, and the neural mechanisms associated with effective treatments are poorly understood. The proposed study will develop and test an integrated AUD randomized controlled trial intervention, among young adults, to improve treatment efficacy and inform about the neural mechanisms of treatment. Further, findings will help advance the development of future interventions to improve alcohol abstinence and ultimately reduce the number of young adults who develop AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, use of radiological clips that can also serve as a calibration target for spectral-based quantitative ultrasound will be assessed for their ability to account for transmission and attenuation losses and thereby improving the accuracy of quantitative ultrasound to identify the early response of breast cancer patients to chemotherapy. Radiological clips are already an integral part of treatment course for patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy in breast cancer. We will evaluate multiple clip materials and physical sizes through phantom studies, studies in animal models of breast cancer and validate the process in a human study of locally advanced breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The treatment for glioma, the most common type of brain tumor, has not changed in over 20 years. Our laboratory has identified that drugs targeting a specific metabolic pathway preferentially kill brain tumor cells with a mutation in the gene IDH1, a very common alteration in this incurable disease. This proposal will study why these tumor cells become dependent on this specific metabolic pathway, potentially assisting in the development of targeted therapies to alleviate the burden of this deadly cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aberrant expression of PDE2A was found in the brain of AD patients and animal models accompanied by impaired cAMP/cGMP signaling and in vitro studies suggested a critical role of aberrant PDE2A signaling in mediating Aβ-induced mitochondrial dysfunction and neuronal dysfunction. In this application, we proposed to investigate the causal involvement of aberrant PDE2A2 signaling in mitochondrial/neuronal dysfunction and the pathogenesis of AD in vivo and explore the underlying mechanism which will likely pave the way for developing treatment targeting mitochondrial dysfunction in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This study proposes to use friendship data from a cohort of high school students in Southern California from an NIH-funded R01 to determine the social influence effects of perceived friend norms and friend e-cigarette use on individual e-cigarette use. The project will also evaluate the longitudinal relationship between friend influence and e-cigarette initiation and use a simulation model to determine how potential behavioral interventions would affect e-cigarette use outcomes in the network. The results of these analyses can be used to create a framework for a network-based intervention to change normative perceptions and ultimately decrease e-cigarette use among adolescents.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: A key to improving racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic inequities in preterm infant health outcomes is for the family to be engaged with the preterm infant during the hospitalization in the neonatal intensive care unit. However, there are many disproportionate barriers faced by marginalized families in order to visit with their infant. This research aims to understand these barriers in mixed methods study and evaluate the effects of the most salient of these, paid family leave, in order intervene to ensure families can engage in their preterm infant's care, and ultimately, improve preterm health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) afflicts over 1 million American adults, causing chronic joint inflammation and pain. Although several therapies exist, a deeper knowledge of this disease is required to improve the lives of patients living with this chronic illness. Here we will apply new knowledge of an immune cell type we identified in patient tissues to further understand the mechanisms of the disease and how to guide development of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative    Significant evidence indicates that environmental exposures, most notably crystalline silica inhalation and  virus infections, contribute to the pathogenesis of lupus and other systemic autoimmune. Here we propose  that silica, viruses, and genetic factors synergize by activating distinct innate immune pathways that together  lead to more effective break of tolerance, earlier disease onset, and enhanced severity. The mechanistic  basis of these synergistic effects will be investigated using well- characterized mouse models, including  relevant gene- deleted and transgenic strains.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because synaptic dysfunction is associated with many neurological disorders that lack effective therapeutic options. Moreover, understanding the signaling proteins that promote synaptic development will provide significant advances in our knowledge of how the nervous system is organized. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge about living systems and to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemia following acute brain injury has been identified as one of the leading causes of transitioning vulnerable penumbra to damaged tissue, but understanding specific mechanisms of injury has lagged far behind. Spreading depolarizations (SDs) have been identified as key contributors to injury progression through a many underexplored cellular mechanisms and thus pose as the best area for preclinical exploration. This proposal seeks to understand the relationship between excessive SD-mediated L-type Ca2+ channel activation, Zn2+ release and subsequent post-synaptic uptake, and initiation of downstream cellular injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia and affects as many as six million Americans, with incidence increasing with lifespan and healthcare costs astronomical. Because amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI) can often precede conversion to full AD, with accelerated and debilitating memory deficits, it is increasingly important to develop therapies that can restore memory function in aMCI subjects prior to conversion and grant a multipronged understanding of the neural basis for aMCI as a precursor to AD. We will combine structural and functional magnetic resonance imaging, scalp electroencephalography, genetic testing, and image-guided theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation to improve memory function in elderly individuals with aMCI and elucidate individual differences and functional changes underlying clinical improvements, aiding the development of individually tailored noninvasive therapies for restoring memory function and contributing to our knowledge of the functional bases of memory in the coherence and dynamic evolution of brain networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This NRSA F30 fellowship will provide an invaluable training opportunity for a future physician scientist as she develops into an emerging leader in the field of alcohol-related liver injury. The proposed studies will investigate alcohol and calorie-dense diet-mediated disruption of hepatic mitochondrial processes and lipid handling. The findings from these studies will provide correlative and mechanistic insight for future translational studies and therapeutic applications aiming to alleviate the combination of alcohol and metabolic-induced liver injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have uncovered novel non-IgE mechanisms of mast cell activation driven by environmental particulates that will be further investigated in this proposal. Specifically, we will examine redox-independent and - dependent roles of thioredoxin interacting protein (Txnip) in regulating non-IgE mast cell activation. Our findings will be further explored in patients with chronic idiopathic urticaria, a mast cell activation disorder that is largely driven by non-IgE mechanisms, to define a role for Txnip in mast cell activation by particulates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Lack of perceived control, particularly during stress, has been critically implicated in major depressive disorder (MDD) and anhedonic symptoms, especially among female adolescents; yet the neural underpinnings of perceived control disruptions in MDD remain poorly understood. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging with a novel “value of control task” in conjunction with a prospective design, this study will provide a comprehensive understanding of stress and perceived control related mechanisms in female adolescents with MDD and will examine stress-induced disruptions in perceived control as a predictor of “real world” expressions of maladaptive coping and anhedonia. This work is aligned with NIMH’s Strategic Objective 1 Strategy 1.1 (Describe the molecules, cells, and neural circuits associated with complex behaviors) and Strategic Objective 2 Strategy 2.2. (Identify useful biomarkers and behavioral indicators that predict change across the trajectory of illness) and may facilitate the identification of MDD biomarkers that could assist with earlier detection of adolescents vulnerable to MDD.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project narrative Owing to the scale-up of control interventions, malarial burden has significantly declined in Zimbabwe and other endemic countries in the past ten years. However, the decline has been heterogeneous and a new setback of reinvasion from malarious to former malaria-free areas, including highly populated cities, is emerging. The goal of the proposed project is to employ robust molecular and field approaches to ascertain the vector, parasite and host-related determinants of urban malaria in order to identify targets for control interventions to restore malaria-free status. The project will leverage on existing malaria surveillance collaboration with the Ministry of Health and Childcare and its partners and will incorporate evaluation of control interventions over time. It also lays groundwork for development of larger follow-up research gearing towards ultimate attainment of malaria elimination by the country which is a member of the malaria elimination-8 (E-8) block.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Pulmonary fibrosis is a devastating illness that involves progressive remodeling and scarring of lung tissue that can eventually lead to poor gas exchange. The incidence of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is increasing worldwide, including among Veterans, mortality rates are high, and the average life expectancy is 3 to 5 years after diagnosis. This proposed study will investigate a previously unrecognized mechanistic pathway that contributes to the development of pulmonary fibrosis and will identify potential targets for therapeutic intervention to reduce fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes sexually transmitted infections, and rising levels of antibiotic resistance in the bacteria as well as rising case rates have created an urgent need for infection prevention. Observational studies in humans and preclinical work in mice indicate that a vaccine approved for use in the US to prevent infections caused by the related bacteria, Group B Neisseria meningitidis (4C-MenB), may provide partial protection against N. gonorrhoeae infection. We propose a randomized controlled trial with a unique experimental human infection model to test the effectiveness of 4C-MenB in preventing N. gonorrhoeae infection in men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Our studies will establish an important role for the apelin receptor system in normal and pathological pregnancy. These studies will unveil the molecular mechanisms involved in the regulation of trophoblast function associated with normal pregnancy, provide insights into the pathology of the hypertensive pregnancy disorder preeclampsia, and contribute to our understanding of the adverse effects of downregulated apelin receptor system leading to abnormal uteroplacental development in preeclampsia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Telomere maintenance is essential for genome stability and the prevention of cancer and degenerative diseases. The proposed research will examine how environmental genotoxic and oxidative stress cause accelerated telomere shortening, and the pathways that preserve damaged telomeres. This project will reveal how various forms of telomeric DNA damage impact telomere function, cellular function and organism health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The final stage of lung development begins late in pregnancy and continues through the first decade of life. Infants born prematurely often require treatments, including oxygen and mechanical ventilation, that harm new blood vessels that drive postnatal lung development, resulting in the chronic lung disease of infancy, bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD). This proposal uses state-of-the art imaging, molecular, and computational tools to understand the role of pericytes, in promoting postnatal lung development, with the overall goal to discover new strategies to prevent and treat BPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This research project is aimed to explore a novel and phosphorylation-depenent mechanism for the regulation of metabotropic glutamate receptors and to define the role of metabotrpic glutamate receptors in the pathophysiology and symptomatology of a common mental illness (major depressive disorder). The information obtained through this project is valuable for advancing the knowledge on biology of glutamate receptors related to depression and for the development of new pharmacotherapies for preventing and treating depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE A major problem in the treatment disorders of motivation such as addiction is the probability of relapse, even after protracted remission periods, when at-risk populations are faced with drug-associated triggers. Clinical experience indicates that there are few effective approaches for use in crisis intervention, stabilization and harm reduction. Here we will explore the role of the endocannabinoid system as a potential pharmacological target with promising therapeutic value in a broad spectrum of conditions involving compromised motivational states. Through the experiments proposed herein, we will gain a better understanding of the neurobiological mechanisms triggering maladaptive cue-driven renewal of reward seeking in the treatment of motivational disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by Plasmodium parasites and the development of an effective malaria vaccine is key to shifting the fight against malaria towards elimination. This project will develop and evaluate the efficacy of a multi-modal vaccine against blood-stage parasites formulated with a novel human- compatible liposomal adjuvant, using a non-human primate model of human malaria. The rational inclusion of the two parasite components is expected to result in strain-transcending neutralizing antibodies induced by a structure based AMA1-RON2L vaccine that will synergize with a broad cellular response induced by the whole blood-stage antigens to maximise control of the blood-stage parasite and confer protection against P. falciparum blood-stage infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because a better understanding of the etiology of autism will lead to improved methods for prevention and treatment. This proposal focuses on both common and rare genetic variants because together they provide an integrated understanding of the genetic risk for autism. It also proposes to investigate risk for autism in people of Hispanic/Latin American ancestry, an under-represented population in prior studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To serve as a catalyst to generate knowledge and translate it into successful strategies to prevent, treat and cure HIV infection, we organized the Einstein/Rockefeller/CUNY-Center for AIDS Research (ERC-CFAR). The ERC- CFAR brings together a highly synergistic partnership of complementary resources by linking a strong basic and clinical research institution `treating a large patient base of people with HIV (Einstein), a globally pre-eminent basic science institution (Rockefeller), and a strong public health/implementation science institution (CUNY) to energize and mobilize our complementary basic, translational, clinical, epidemiologic, behavioral, and implementation research programs to attain our shared goal of Ending the HIV Epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pitch and harmonicity are both crucial factors in the perception of music, speech, and auditory scene analysis, but the question of how they are perceived and represented in the human auditory cortex remains mostly unknown. This project uses a combination of behavior, electrophysiology (EEG), and neuroimaging techniques (fMRI) to further our understanding of cortical representations and the temporal processing of pitch and harmonicity. This research will extend our understanding of pitch processing in normal-hearing individuals, which will help inform the development of pitch processing strategies in auditory prostheses, such as cochlear implants, that are currently unable to provide robust pitch information.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE Generally, adolescents living with HIV (ALHIV) have poor outcomes with higher rates of disengagement from care and higher mortality rates compared with other age groups especially during the transition period. Transition success may be maximized for ALHIV who are better prepared to negotiate care in adult clinic settings but majority of adolescents and young adults with HIV do not have the necessary skills to negotiate their own care by the time they are transitioned to adult care. This application proposes to develop a self- management intervention that is developmentally tailored for ALHIV to obtain the skills they need to successfully navigate adult HIV clinic following transition and optimize health outcomes for a key population in the global HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: This Collaborative Merit Award application (CMA) is a synergistic, multidisciplinary project focused on the mechanistic understanding of platinum resistance (PtR) as the foremost cause of death in ovarian cancer patients. The overall strategy is to integrate ideas, resources, and expertise in advanced technologies to identify and validate novel therapeutic targets and biomarker-driven treatments for ovarian cancer patients. This application (CMA1) will identify biomarkers and underlying molecular pathways of platinum resistance as well as test potential targeted therapies that prevent or overcome PtR. CMA1 is highly integrated with the other two applications and will serve as a resource for CMA2 and CMA3 to identify and validate biomarkers and molecular mechanisms of platinum resistance. The major contribution of CMA1 is to generate a comprehensive integrated mechanistic multi-omic database that will facilitate the development of biomarker-driven mechanism-based cancer therapies for extending survival and improving the quality of life of Veteran women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  High-risk human papillomaviruses (HPV) cause cervical, anogenital, and head and neck cancers. Despite the availability of preventive HPV vaccines, their poor uptake leaves most men and women at risk for these cancers, many of which remain common globally and others which are increasing domestically. Through direct mechanistic studies of viral and host protein partnerships, this project will uncover how cellular growth and differentiation are hijacked by HPV, and how cellular immortalization is temporally and longitudinally activated by HPV, all of which must occur for HPV-associated cancer development and progression.

PHR: The proposed research will combine the expertise from data privacy, biomedical informatics, machine learning, and cloud computing to develop data outsourcing and sharing technologies for AI-powered Parkinson’s Disease research. The outcome is expected to have a broader impact beyond PD research in removing a major privacy roadblock that restricts medical data accessibility and in advancing the theory and implementation of cloud-based medical studies with data privacy protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substantial genetic and clinical differences exist between European-American (EA) and African-American (AA) systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and our mechanistic understanding of 1) the SLE epigenome and 2) how it impacts the disease’s clinical differences along racial lines remains woefully lacking. Our laboratory, therefore, has joined with the Buenrostro laboratory at Harvard to utilize their sciATAC-seq (single cell indexing assay for transposase-accessible chromatin) method to assess cell-specific chromatin accessibility differences between SLE cases and controls, and between EA and AA SLE cases. Utilizing our cutting-edge approach, we believe our planned Aims will significantly contribute to a better understanding of how the epigenome process genetic information from genotype to phenotype in a cell-, disease- and racially-specific manner, thereby significantly aiding in the translation of genetic knowledge into actionable clinical knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this project is to identify the structure and provisions of Severe Emotional Disturbance (SED) 1915(c) HCBS waiver programs across the United States, the characteristics of children served in these programs and the extent to which they are at risk of psychiatric long-term care (LTC) placement, and estimate the effects of an SED waiver on behavioral health care service use and expenditures for children with SED. Because these policies aim to reduce the use of psychiatric LTC through the provision of community-based alternatives—but programs and environments vary considerably across states and over time—this study will explicitly examine variation in program structures and participants and will assess policy impacts on community-based and out-of-community service use and expenditures, while accounting for contextual variation. As this study relies on data drawn from state administrative documents and public healthcare claims, this grant also provides training in research design and statistical methods for utilizing policy and claims data to address key information needs for behavioral health policy decision-making that reduces avoidable use of psychiatric LTC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The studies proposed here will further elucidate subcellular mechanisms of single neuron computation. The results will provide detailed insights into postsynaptic mechanisms for input processing that allow for flexible toggling among different outputs in individual neurons. The findings from the study will not only contribute to our basic understanding of the computational capacity of the brain but will also aid in our understanding of subcellular dysfunctions in neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this study is to employ Bayesian inference to design subject-specific models of voice production for norm and structural vocal pathologies. The proposed models utilize high-speed videoendoscopy, electroglottography, and acoustic data for parameter inference and model validation. The vocal dynamics, glottal aerodynamics and their interactions are studied comprehensively using the computational models to better understand the normal and disordered function of voice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Wound healing is markedly impaired by diabetes, which is caused in part by alterations in the subpopulations of cells important for tissue repair. It is our fundamental hypothesis that restoration of those cellular populations can reverse these defects and correct wound healing and other diabetic complications. In this proposal, we will use emerging single cell techniques to identify the critical alterations in cellular populations induced by diabetes in mice and humans and use these insights to develop cell based strategies to restore these depleted populations to prevent diabetic complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research program on the Demography of Chronic Pain enhances U.S. public health by documenting population-level patterns and trends in chronic pain, identifying individual-level and contextual factors that could reduce the burden of pain and disparities therein, and clarifying how pain contributes to U.S. disability and mortality. We leverage large-scale, longitudinal data from the U.S. and from peer countries to conduct comparative, policy-relevant research. This project investigates pain both as a public health problem in its own right, and as a potential missing link in understanding recent adverse trends in U.S. health disparities, disability, and mortality.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it represents an innovative multi-level approach to identifying targets for effective interventions to improve the quality of care for older adults with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias and limited-English proficiency through improved palliative care. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Immunotherapy with immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) for advanced bladder cancer is only moderately effective, costly, inconveniently administrated through intravenous infusion and associated with significant immune-mediated toxicity secondary to delivery of ICIs to and activation of immune response against non-cancerous tissues. The goal of this project is to develop an oral, more effective, less toxic, more affordable immunotherapy medication that can also be used for photodynamic diagnosis and therapy of bladder cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cisplatin and other platinum-based chemotherapeutic drugs are still the mainstay treatment for many cancers. Clinical limitations, however, including cancer drug resistance, are a major health concern. The goal of this proposal is to assess the mechanism of how APOBEC3 deaminases activate BER and MMR to mediate cisplatin efficacy. Understanding the interplay between these pathways will help identify patients that will respond better to cisplatin chemotherapy as well as assist in the design of new treatment protocols in cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy is first line therapy for localized prostate cancer, however preservation of the surrounding nerve tissue continues to challenge surgeons and leaves up to 60% of patients with some form of incontinence and impotence post-surgery. Nerve visualization in the operating room is difficult and no clinically approved imaging methodology has been developed to aid in nerve identification and visualization. In the work proposed herein, we will develop a clinically relevant near infrared nerve-specific imaging strategy to be utilized with the FDA approved fluorescence-imaging channel in the da Vinci surgical robot enabling nerve-specific imaging during robotic assisted nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy for improved surgical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intestinal transplantation (ITx) is the only therapeutic option for patients with intestinal failure once parenteral nutrition fails, but its use is limited by high rates of rejection that necessitate increased levels of immunosuppression, predisposing patients to infections, malignancy, and graft-versus-host disease. Previous work has demonstrated that rejection is mitigated by higher ratios of graft-versus-host (GVH)-reactive donor T cells in the graft relative to host-versus-graft (HVG)-reactive recipient T cells, but the factors that help determine the GVH:HVG balance remain unknown. Based on evidence that dysbiosis is associated with various states of gut inflammation including infection, inflammatory bowel disease, GVHD, and rejection, this proposal aims to identify novel biomarkers and treatments for rejection by exploring the hypothesis that homeostasis between the gut microbiome and mucosal defenses plays an essential role in maintaining the balance of GVH:HVG-reactive T cells in the graft, thus regulating rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Laryngotracheal stenosis (obstructing scar in the larynx and trachea) occurs in patients after long-term breathing tube placement and can result in communication disability and high mortality rates due to the obstructed airway. This proposal will investigate the mechanism of how mTOR suppression works on the pathologic T-cell and fibroblast subsets that are critical to the development of iLTS. Finally, the proposal will test a novel drug eluting stent to deliver mTOR suppression directly to the site of disease in the larynx and trachea to target diseased T- cells and fibroblasts without side effects of systemic mTOR inhibition. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defining the Impact of Initial Influenza Exposure on Immunity in Infants Establishment of a maternal-infant cohort in Cincinnati and Mexico City to detect influenza infection and vaccination will provide the framework to improve our understanding of the immunological responses to the initial infant influenza exposure, be it infection or vaccine, and how that initial exposure imprints the infant’s response to subsequent exposures. The information gained from the Influenza IMPRINT Cohort and the planned analyses will provide the knowledge needed to develop an effective universal influenza vaccine. Our instructive maternal-infant cohort will investigate unique features of how individuals immunologically respond to natural infection compared with vaccination, and the potential impact of vertically transferred maternal immunity. Longitudinal evaluation of these individuals will establish how prior influenza exposure impacts susceptibility and the immune response to infection by genetically identical, similar or discordant influenza virus strains that draws a blueprint for more universal influenza vaccines strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States and worldwide and results in a tremendous healthcare burden. Identifying and characterizing novel therapeutic targets is critical due to few recent discoveries being translated into effective therapies. This proposal will investigate the role of a previously unstudied ligand/receptor system, TRAIL/DR5 in the heart, which has been identified in human studies as being a powerful predictor of heart failure risk and progression severity, in order to define its role and gain insight into a potential novel therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because everyone benefits from having effective antibiotics and reducing use of unnecessary antibiotics. In this project, we will test two implementation strategies for an antibiotic stewardship program to decrease overtreatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria, or harmless bladder colonization with bacteria, in hospitals and nursing homes across the United States. This project is relevant to AHRQ’s mission because improving antibiotic use makes health care safer, and it will increase knowledge about how to put evidence into clinical practice.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Emergency Department (ED) is a major access point for rural and underrepresented minority (URM) persons seeking mental health (MH) and co-occurring substance use disorder (SUD) treatment, but outcomes after such ED visits are greatly understudied. The overall research goal of this K08 is a detailed, state-based study measuring the effectiveness of New Mexico Medicaid’s Alternative Payment Model (APM) as an intervention in rural and URM communities and scaling these findings nationally through a Technical Expert Panel who will identify key policy and outcome measures for inclusion in Medicaid policy analysis. This work lays the foundation for multistate comparisons to prospectively test the impact of Medicaid policy interventions (e.g., APMs) on rural mental health outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving rural mental health equity through Medicaid policy evaluation - resubmission

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  THE BIOLOGY OF GENOMES Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, New York  May 9 – 13, 2023  May 7 - 11, 2024  May 6 – 10, 2025  May 5 – 9, 2026  May 11 – 15, 2027 Every species of animal or plant has a distinct set of genes encoded in DNA packaged into discrete chromosomes. The full complement of these genes constitutes the organism's genome. Furthermore the genome of each individual within a species varies slightly, thus providing the genetic basis of the many differences we see between individuals. The technology of DNA sequencing has allowed scientists to construct the shared genome sequence of humans and many species of plant and animal, providing powerful evidence for the evolutionary connections between species. Effort is now going into decoding the genetic differences between individuals within a species, particularly for individual humans and their susceptibility to disease. Many of these advances rely upon interactions between a diverse set of experts, ranging from engineers developing ever faster sequencing technologies, bioinformatics experts who handle the very large datasets generated by these machines, biologists who interpret the results in the context of known biology to shed new light on fundamental mechanisms, and medical experts who seek to apply this information to improved medical treatment and the development of novel therapeutic strategies. This annual conference is one of the major points of exchange for many scientists, editors and associated genome experts to share their latest findings, and provides rapid peer-to-peer communication and networking that is essential to drive the field forward. This Cold Spring Harbor meeting traditionally attracts a very wide and diverse international community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative The current immunomodulatory therapies of multiple sclerosis (MS) can only relieve the symptoms but are ineffective in curing the disease, so it is urgent for the field to find novel therapeutic approaches that can cure the disease, for instance by promoting remyelination. The central nervous system has great potential to regenerate oligodendrocytes and remyelinate in response to myelin damage, however the ability of remyelination is greatly diminished in the MS lesions. Here we aim to test the hypothesis that activating PPARβ/RXRα/Qki function will help remyelination in MS through two ways: 1) activating microglia’s function to clear myelin debris, consequently promoting oligodendrocyte regeneration, and 2) enhancing lipid generation of existing and newly generated oligodendrocytes.
