IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Delays and waits for needed health care result not only in lower patient satisfaction but adverse impacts on patient outcomes. While VHA has long struggled with access problems as a result of influxes of Veterans after wartime or in response to needs of new (e.g., traumatic brain injury) or aging cohorts (e.g., long term care), VHA's highly publicized access crisis in 2014 drew demands for immediate action. That action has taken the form of expansion of Veterans' access to community providers and policy and practice action within the VA. Improving how VHA manages access through more effective deployment of clinic personnel, resources, and processes to achieve timely access is a top priority. Oddly, the evidence base on effective access management strategies remains scant, requiring new approaches to accelerating how research can support VHA access improvement efforts. The proposed study aims to provide a national profile of how VHA has responded to the access crisis, and explore what drives or hinders successful efforts to improve access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The pace at which biological knowledge is published in the scientific literature far surpasses the ability of professional biocurators to collate and annotate such knowledge in a timely fashion. However, knowledgebases are a critical component of biological research whose utility depends on prompt entry of new data. Combining the dual benefits of text mining and community curation, the proposed ACKnowledge system, readily generalized, presents a novel approach to aiding curation by guiding authors to efficiently and accurately annotate their papers, thus quickly and reliably adding new information to knowledgebases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Integrins make up a large family of cell surface receptors, with at least one integrin found in every type of human cell. Changes in their overall shapes are important in establishing a link between the inside and outside of the cell. Therefore, defects in integrin structures are implicated in many diseases—including bleeding disorders, inflammation, and cancer—and thus are critical and proven drug targets. The platelet integrin, called αIIbβ3, is essential in platelet aggregation events. Dysregulated platelet aggregation is the trigger for abnormal thrombotic disorders such as heart attacks and strokes. There are currently three licensed αIIbβ3 drugs; however, these cause severe bleeding complications and are thus only used for a brief period of time (less than 72 hours). Using these clinical and preclinical drugs, our proposal aims to gain a new understanding of αIIbβ3 structure and function with the ultimate goal of positively impacting the broad integrin αIIbβ3 therapeutic space in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will generate extensive evidence on links between brain changes and behavior in adults with autism spectrum disorders between 40 and 70 years of age, for whom relevant data are extremely limited. Some specific focus will be on neuronal excitation:inhibition balance, which changes in aging. This systematic body of evidence will provide crucial information in the quest for predictors of long-term neurocognitive success or decline in ASD, thus serving as a first step to developing interventions to protect against such decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mood disorders including depression, bipolar, and post-traumatic stress disorder constitute the world's leading cause of disability and their burden is increasing. This proposal seeks to mitigate the burden of these related mood disorders by identifying patterns of brain structure and function indicative of a patient's likelihood of benefiting from various related interventions. This research has the potential to inform more personalized treatment strategies than are currently available and will likely further inform development of precision interventions targeting mood disorders.

PHR: 3D cell migration is of fundamental importance for both normal physiological processes such as in development, and disease progression such as cancer metastasis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer mortality rates are projected to more than double in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) in the next two decades. In order to address this looming public health crisis, we propose a training program that will maximize the rigor of cancer research in SSA by training researchers to develop strategic and operational capacity that will generate new knowledge about the determinants of cancer risk and outcomes, and improve effectiveness of strategies for reducing risk and improve outcomes. The overarching goals of this training program are to 1) Develop and disseminate best practices to enable the highest quality cancer research in Africa; 2) Teach fundamental skills to those who conduct research in Africa; and 3) Create a cadre of individuals who can lead and support cancer research in SSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to improving treatment options and lifespan of women with metastatic breast cancer by improving the understanding of the molecular co-evolution of the tumors and the immune system during tumor development and progression. Our expected outcomes include; 1) advancing our current understanding of resistance mechanisms; 2) determining how stress-induced HSP70 may regulate immunosuppression; and 3) testing the therapeutic utility of HSP70 inhibitor to improve effectiveness of current therapies in metastatic breast cancer. Our impact includes the identification of molecular targets that regulate critical steps in metastatic process and will lead to improved therapeutic approaches for the treatment of women with metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The NIMH identifies an urgent unmet need for science focused on improvement and development of interventions for individuals suffering from mental illness that are acceptable and easily disseminated to the service community and supported by policy makers. The UCSF Clinical Services Research Training Program trains junior investigators in the practices of clinical services research, relevant research methods, and professional skills. The program's success is reflected in the success of its graduates who have continued in clinical services research careers, many being leaders in the field, through academic/research positions, funded research programs and active dissemination of their research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple Myeloma is one of the most common cancers of blood cells; although the treatment has become more effective, multiple myeloma remains incurable. These cancer cells reside mainly in the bone marrow where they are supported by the normal bone marrow cells, particularly cells that form blood vessels. Our preliminary experiments implicated proteins called the EphB and ephrinB families in this interaction and our study is designed to determine if inhibiting the ability of these proteins to interact impairs the progression of this cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 80% of early stage head and neck tumors undergo surgery of curative intent at some point in their treatment course. Although the success of this oncologic surgery primarily depends on obtaining clear surgical margins, tumor positive margin rates remain at approximately 30%. Because poor survival directly correlates with positive margin rate in head and neck cancer, we propose a clinical trial using a systemically injected contrast agent to determine if optical imaging during surgery can improve detection of tumor-positive margins in real-time. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence and severity of periodontitis increase with age, causing tooth loss in over 50% of adults 65 or older. Fragility fractures and delayed healing of the craniofacial bone cause significant morbidity and mortality in our aging population, and is in part due to the depleted regenerative potential of the aging stem cell pool. Our proposal focuses on determining factors that contribute to aging and senescence of the craniofacial stem cells, with the long-term goal of developing therapeutics directed to rejuvenate stem cells to counteract bone aging and treating periodontitis in elderly patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Respiratory viral infection of the susceptible epithelium is associated with the onset and progression of asthma. The Seattle Center will focus on the identification of common and distinct mechanisms that drive persistent T2 and non-T2 inflammation through epithelial interactions with immune cells that are in close contact with the epithelium in the context of viral infection. The results will provide the basis for novel therapeutics with efficacy in individuals with persistent T2 inflammation and non-T2 predominant disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because our ability to diagnose and treat neurodevelopmental disorders and brain tumors is critically dependent on fundamental understanding of cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate neural stem cell self-renewal and differentiation in vivo. Research described in this proposal will uncover new and potentially evolutionarily conserved mechanisms governing these processes. If successful, it will have a broad impact on the understanding of human brain development and associated brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: EGFR mutant NSCLC initially has a high response rate (70%) to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs), however, resistance to these drugs is inevitable. This project will use preclinical mouse models and human biospecimens to understand the role of the HGF-MET-TWIST1 pathway in mediating resistance to EGFR TKIs and if targeting TWIST1 can overcome or prevent resistance. Results of this proposal could lead to a new therapeutic paradigm for treatment of lung cancer through targeting EMT transcription factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop a novel computational paradigm for comprehensively characterizing and interpreting the causal system and its variability in functional brain networks. The findings will be translated in clinical studies of patients with different severity of neurological disorders to guide therapeutic practices, and particularly, post- concussive vestibular impairment syndrome will be used as one illustrative example in this study. Upon conclusion, we will understand the information transfer in resting state brain networks as well as its role in differentiating the subtypes of vestibular impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Sensory experiences activate patterns of neurons throughout cortex and hippocampus that reactivate together during quiet waking, potentially facilitating memory consolidation. However, the circuit-level effects of online activation and offline reactivation on learning are not well understood, as previous studies of learning and reactivation have not tracked large-scale activity patterns across days, and could not assess local circuit changes in neuromodulation and associated synaptic signals underlying plasticity. The proposed studies will use chronic two-photon imaging of calcium activity, local neuromodulation and downstream molecular signaling in large numbers of cortical neurons across days to link offline reactivation of specific recent experiences with next-day changes in behavioral performance and in cortical network dynamics during learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adult cancer survivors (≥65 years, ≥1-year post-treatment) are an understudied yet uniquely high-risk group for untreated depression in need of novel mental health treatments and delivery strategies across cancer settings. Despite the rapidly growing number of older adult cancer survivors, no studies have evaluated the implementation of evidence-baseddepression treatment for older adults through cancersurvivorship clinics. The current proposal adopts an implementation science framework to evaluate the preliminary efficacy and implementation outcomes of social work delivered Behavioral Activation via telephone for older adult cancer survivors, with the ultimate goal of increasing engagement in evidence based depression treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Health and Retirement Study (HRS) is the premier data set worldwide for the study of aging in all its complexities. The RAND HRS Longitudinal File and its supplementary data files, that constitute the RAND HRS Data System, have been instrumental in facilitating and increasing the use of the HRS in the work of thousands of researchers in the U.S. and around the world. This project will substantially expand the content of the RAND HRS Data System to realize the full potential of the HRS and to facilitate rigorous multidisciplinary research on health and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project 2 Narrative Effective treatments for non-type 2 (T2) asthma are lacking for children and adults. Using bronchial airway epithelial cells from well characterized cohorts of children and adults with and without asthma we will conduct mechanistic experiments using organotypic models to improve understanding of the role of the airway epithelium in coordinating immune cells that drive airway inflammation and remodeling, and influence exacerbations, lung function, and inflammatory signatures in non-T2 asthma. Results from this Project will be highly impactful to the field with potential to identify novel therapeutic targets for non-T2 asthma to prevent exacerbations and lung function decline for children and adults with non-T2 asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed mechanistic trial will utilize mindfulness training to permit examination of questions about the causal role of emotion regulation strategies linked to the striving persistent behavioral style in driving mental health and health morbidities among BIPOC78. The proposed Project STRIVE (STudents RIsing aboVE) will identify BIPOC students who are academically resilient in the face of disadvantage and will offer a tailored mindfulness intervention targeting self-regulation processes as a putative mechanism to interrupt the links between the striving persistent behavioral style and negative health outcomes. We propose a multisite randomized trial to the effects of the STRIVE intervention on putative self-regulation mechanisms, health and mental health outcomes, and to examine the mechanistic model linking striving persistent behavioral style to health and mental health morbidities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The UCSD Training Program in Reproductive Sciences takes a multidisciplinary approach to prepare physician- scientists and reproductive biologists to become the future leaders in reproductive research. Postdoctoral scholars with Ph.D. and/or M.D. degrees are trained in the field of reproductive biology through advanced basic research experiences and/or engaging in clinical investigation of reproductive disorders. A cohesive, highly interactive group of faculty mentors from the Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology, and Reproductive Sciences and the Departments of Medicine and Pathology with complementary interests, co-authored publications, shared grants, and balanced clinical, translational, and basic science backgrounds, provides intensive research training and career development to foster the future careers of outstanding postdoctoral and clinical fellow trainees.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Reproductive Sciences

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Over the last five years the annual reductions in malaria illness and deaths in sub-Saharan Africa have stalled. The previous success of malaria control has been largely due to the scale-up in the distribution of long lasting insecticidal nets and it is thought that insecticide resistance is one of the causes of the slow down . The goal of this research project is to embed genomic surveillance approaches into ongoing vector control trials to accurately quantify the epidemiological impact of resistance and to provide the resources to mitigate its impact on malaria control programmes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This relevance of this proposal centers on illuminating the mechanisms by which a rare but highly-lethal type of metastatic prostate cancer – known as Androgen Receptor Pathway-Independent Prostate Cancers (APIPC) – is able to flourish and progress. The incidence of this form of the disease is increasing due to the widespread use of potent AR pathway inhibitors, and represents a significant challenge in terms of clinical management. Successful completion of this project will yield actionable targets and potential therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental disabilities affect 10% of all families in the United States. Researchers are urgently needed who are able to apply cutting-edge, interdisciplinary research methods to elucidate the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of these disorders so that new and more effective therapeutic interventions can be identified. This program strives to fill this need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Foreign-born Latinos in the United States are at risk for poor health outcomes, including poor outcomes for cancer. It is uncertain whether or not they receive fewer prevention services for cancer, and if so, which specific factors may be most responsible for the lower receipt of these services. This project will use a highly innovative electronic health record database that contains country of birth information and is linked to community information in order provide policy makers and healthcare providers better information about what cancer prevention services their patients or community members are most at risk for underutilizing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive training and Tai Chi exercise lifestyle interventions have shown success in improving cognitive, functional, and mood-related outcomes in both cognitively impaired and normal samples, however these interventions have not been considered in patients diagnosed earlier in life (“early-onset Alzheimer’s Disease”; EOAD). We propose to collect preliminary data to investigate the feasibility and effect of a combined lifestyle intervention on short-term and long-term cognition, functioning, and mood in amyloid-positive participants with EOAD from the Longitudinal Early-Onset Alzheimer’s Disease Study (LEADS) cohort. Achieving these aims will result in information on feasibility and initial efficacy of administering this lifestyle intervention to this under- served population, with successful improvement of cognition and psychosocial factors in EOAD having implications for patients and families, healthcare practice, policy, and other forms of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public health relevance: Individuals addicted to cocaine face great difficulty in suppressing their drive to consume cocaine, even long after their previous use of the drug. The proposed studies will focus on understanding those neural systems that underlie the suppression and inhibition of cocaine seeking. The findings of this work may have significant future benefit in the creation of better treatments that strengthen the ability to inhibit cocaine use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  HBV-associated diseases such as liver fibrosis, cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma lead to significantly decreased quality of life and even death. HBV infection is maintained by a persistent viral genome called cccDNA minichromosome, which cannot be eradicated or inactivated by currently approved drugs. This research project aims to elucidate the mechanism of epigenetic regulation of cccDNA transcription, which will potentially discover new antiviral targets for development of epigenetic therapy against chronic hepatitis B.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chemical modifications to histone proteins coordinate gene expression by helping to turn specific genes “on” or “off” in human cells. This project will elucidate how a subset of these modifications, called acylations, are regulated by metabolism and what impacts these acylations have on gene expression. By defining these specific cellular mechanisms, the project will reveal new therapeutic strategies to combat diseases associated with epigenetic and metabolic dysregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Stress can be a risk factor that shifts alcohol consumption from recreational to excessive, and evidence supports an association between post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and the development of an alcohol use disorder (AUD). We developed an animal model where repeated exposure to traumatic stress (a model of PTSD) significantly increased anxiety-related behavior and later alcohol drinking in male and female mice, with heterogeneity in the response as is seen in PTSD patients. We will use this model to determine sex differences in biological and molecular mechanisms that confer susceptibility for increased drinking following traumatic stress so that the information can guide the development of new interventions for the treatment of PTSD- induced AUD, which likely differ in males and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Chemoresistant prostate cancer (PCa) is lethal with no cure. This R01 project will develop a novel class of EED inhibitors that interrupt EED-EZH2 interaction and block noncanonical EZH2 survival signaling in chemoresistant PCa cells. We anticipate to identify several patentable, highly potent and efficacious EED inhibitors with optimized pharmacological profiles and drug-like properties, which can be promptly moved to the next stages of drug development. This project is original, innovative and has high impact on both translational research and patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Staphylococcus aureus (SA) and in particular methicillin resistant SA (MRSA) is a major human pathogen that causes a wide range of infections from skin infections to life threatening bloodstream infections with high mortality rate. Currently nearly as many people die in the US from SA as from AIDS. The efforts towards development of vaccines have been unsuccessful. The recent clinical study on Merck V710 vaccine for SA in patients undergoing cardiac surgeries led to increased mortality in people who were vaccinated and got infected after operation. Studies indicate that there is a detrimental immune response in some patients that leads to vaccine failure. The goal of this proposal is to delineate the underlying mechanisms of the deleterious and protective immune responses to SA vaccines. These studies will help us develop more effective vaccines in future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculosis remains a leading cause of death from infection because the causative agent, Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), is highly successful at moving in airborne micro-droplets from the damaged lungs of one coughing, talking or sneezing person to the healthy lungs of several others. To succeed in this journey, Mtb must survive drastic, rapid, sequential changes in the composition of the surrounding fluid; the concentrations of oxygen, carbon dioxide, water and hydrogen ions; and the ambient temperature. This Program Project brings new technologies and animal models to bear to characterize Mtb's transmission biology at genomic, metabolomic and lipidomic levels; to use the physics of respirable aerosols to guide the development and use of a mouse model for testing genetic hypotheses; and to improve on the historic guinea pig model of natural transmission through new molecular knowledge of how Mtb makes an infected host cough.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: The transcriptional co-activator YAP1 is the oncogenic component of the Hippo signaling cascade and contributes to the genesis and metastasis of a variety of cancers, by modulating a variety of oncogenic events including proliferation, epithelial-mesenchymal transition, angiogenesis and metastasis. Here we find that YAP1 is regulated by a novel set of signaling events. Our ongoing studies show that the tank binding kinase TBK1 binds to and phosphorylates YAP1; depletion of TBK1 significantly elevated YAP1 levels selectively in K- Ras mutant lung cancers, through arginine methylation mediated by CARM1. We hypothesize that these regulatory mechanisms facilitate the growth of K-Ras mutant lung cancers and can be targeted for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment advances in psychosis are limited by the use of phenomenology-defined diagnoses based on symptomatic outcomes, rather than by neurobiological constructs monitored by quantitative characteristics. The Bipolar-Schizophrenia Network for Intermediate Phenotypes (B-SNIP) uses biomarkers to define psychosis subgroups with the goal of testing the advantages of B-SNIP biomarkers for diagnostic and therapeutic decisions, consistent with principles in the NIMH Strategic Plan. We propose to test Biotype1 psychosis subgroup with clozapine, and predict a differential clinical response to clozapine compared with Biotype2, marked by normalization of IEA, cortical attractor network activity and an advantage over usual antipsychotic drugs, establishing low IEA in Biotype1 as a predictive biomarker for clozapine efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Surgeons need formalized, rigorous training programs to prepare them to conduct the type of research that is needed for a more effective and efficient healthcare delivery system. This T32 training program prepares surgeons for successful careers in research and in leading the learning healthcare systems of the future, with a focus on gastrointestinal conditions that are some of the most common reasons for surgery. With rigorous training in research methods, practical skills for leading research centers, statewide and national platforms for community-based research, and structured mentorship, these trainees will become independently funded scientists and leaders in high-impact surgical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We propose to form a research network of internationally-renowned methodological and substantive experts who are actively researching the benefits of new data collection methodologies for longitudinal studies of aging in response to recent societal developments. The proposed network will meet regularly to shape methodological innovations specifically for the measurement of aging populations and design studies that will produce evidence-based best practices for this type of longitudinal measurement. Via a coordinated international program of training, consulting, thematic working group meetings, and pilot research projects, we aim to set the agenda for methodological research on longitudinal studies of aging and protect NIA investments in population-representative longitudinal studies by maximizing their methodological quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on combining theoretically-guided behavioral intervention with neuromodulation to optimize treatment for acquired speech deficits subsequent to stroke, which pose a significant barrier to effective communication, and limit participation in professional, social, and family environments. While current treatments can promote some limited recovery, residual disability remains a problem, and understanding the mechanism of recovery will create the potential for significantly improved individualized outcomes. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent sexual minority males are at higher risk than other groups for HIV infection in the United States; yet, there are few interventions focused on HIV prevention in this group, including those involving pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) uptake. Importantly, parents are a main source of support for adolescents yet rarely included in research or interventions. Dr. Rusley will work with his mentor team to develop a family-based HIV prevention intervention that includes PrEP for adolescent sexual minority males, with the goal to decrease HIV transmission in this key population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic differences between individuals can influence gene expression levels across different tissues and cell types, and it is unknown if this tissue-specific regulation of gene expression affects risk of developing the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) during critical illness. In this proposal, we will apply an advanced computational framework to existing genetic data to predict the gene expression levels of lung tissue and immune cells in patients at high risk for developing ARDS. This research will advance practitioners’ ability to incorporate genetic information to bring more personalized care to critically ill patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative This proposal focuses on mechanisms of Hedgehog signaling through the tumor microenvironment in glioblastoma, an incurable cancer of the central nervous system and the most common primary malignant brain tumor. Our objective is to understand why pharmacologic inhibition of Hedgehog signaling unexpectedly accelerates invasion and tumorigenesis of glioblastoma cells. Using a novel human astrocyte organoid model of glioblastoma and patient derived xenografts, this work will provide fundamental insights into how the Hedgehog pathway functions in cancer, and establish the preclinical basis for new clinical trials in glioblastoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PAR-20-221: NIDA Avant-Garde Alex K. Shalek NARRATIVE People who inject drugs (PWID) with opioid use disorder (OUD) or polysubstance used disorder (PSUD) have a substantial risk for developing and incidence of HIV-1 and other infection. To develop effective prophylactics and therapeutics against HIV-1 and other infections for individuals with OUD or PSUD, we must first understand how opioids and the lived experiences of OUD/PSUD impact the immune system at a cellular and molecular level. The goal of our NIDA Avant-Garde DP1 proposal is to define, at unprecedented resolution, how OUD and PSUD influence immune function and responses to HIV-1 and other pathogens by developing and applying innovative single-cell and bulk profiling and perturbation tools, helping to inform the design of novel cure and prevention strategies for those with OUD or PSUD, as well as others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Michigan Center for Translational Cancer Proteogenomics (UM-CTCP) will perform advanced proteogenomics analyses a part of the Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium (CPTAC) initiative. Working in collaboration with other members of the CPTAC, UM-CTCP will apply its advanced computational infrastructure for comprehensive and global characterization of genomics, transcriptomics, and proteomics data, collected from several cohorts of human tumors using NCI-provided biospecimens. UM- CTCP will conduct integrative analyses of data across these different data types with a goal to identify potentially cancer-related molecular alterations and to elucidate how distinct changes at the protein level are related to abnormalities in cancer genomes. A second priority of UM-CTCP is to assist with the selection of cancer-specific protein candidates for subsequent functional studies and validation using targeted assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The US is facing a crisis of opioid overdoses and addiction. Current therapies consist largely of alternative opioids (i.e. maintenance with methadone or buprenorphine) and do not correct neurobiological factors underlying addiction, including the long-lasting changes in the neural plasticity thought to contribute to drug cravings that cause relapse, and perpetuate the illness. This proposal focuses on a recently identified pH- dependent signaling pathway at synapses in the nucleus accumbens that may be targeted to reverse the neurobiology underlying craving with non-opioid medications already used in humans for other illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alterations in emotion, empathy, and social behavior are early features of Alzheimer's disease that are often overlooked. A more sophisticated understanding of how neurodegeneration, neural network aberrations, and neuropathological changes relate to emotion physiology, behavior, and experience across the Alzheimer's disease spectrum will be critical for improving early diagnosis, broadening current conceptualizations of disease progression, and advancing biological models of affective symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 6.5 million people in the United States currently live with progressive neurodegenerative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, yet no disease-modifying treatments are available. The proposed research is aimed at understanding network and cell-level vulnerability to pathological protein progression with a focus on the impact that multiple pathologies have on disease progression. Understanding how dementia progresses is critical to assess therapeutic efficacy and improve disease prognosis and therefore relevant to the missions of the NIA and the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This project address the major challenge of improving the quality of vaccine-elicited responses against the neutralizing antibody targets on the virus pathogen by novel immunogen design. This study proposes to modify vaccine candidates derived from HIV-1 envelope glycoproteins for efficiently activating, selectively expanding, and precisely shepherding HIV-1 broadly neutralizing antibody (bNAb) germline precursor to achieve bNAb response elicitation and to develop new vaccination regimens to optimize the vaccination efficacy. The outcomes of this study will contribute to the development of a broadly effective HIV-1 vaccine as well as increase understanding of host/pathogen interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This research will refine and test an automated tool for measuring speech sound development in children. This tool will identify if a child has speech sounds that are not developing in a normal or typical way, will reveal which specific sounds are not developing typically, and will indicate which speech sounds make the largest contribution to speech intelligibility for children at different ages. This information can be used to develop speech therapies that maximize speech intelligibly. The research will benefit all children, but has special application to children with cerebral palsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation is hypothesized to contribute to the pathogenesis of major depressive disorder (MDD) but the precise inflammatory mechanisms and how these processes influence neural systems to generate depressive symptoms are still poorly understood. This project seeks to elucidate the neural circuitry underlying a maladaptive homeostatic response to inflammation in MDD by using a placebo-controlled lipopolysaccharide challenge that will cause a transient inflammatory response. The proposed research is highly pertinent to public health because it will identify brain targets relevant to inflammation-induced depression, which is a necessary step in the development of immune-based interventions for mood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastatic melanoma is one of the deadliest cancers, and although immunotherapy and targeted agents extend survival, some melanomas do not respond to the treatments or develop resistance; thus, the 5-year survival rate remains dismal. This proposal examines the mechanism by which ABL family proteins contribute to BRAF/MEK inhibitor resistance and includes a clinical trial to test the safety and initial efficacy of an ABL1/2 inhibitor in combination with BRAF/MEK inhibitors for treating refractory melanomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed basic science research project will reveal the neural circuit connectivity and behavioral function of chemically-identified brainstem neurons that signal to the limbic forebrain to increase threat-induced emotional responses, akin to symptoms of anxiety in humans. For this, a new transgenic rat model will be used to target two specific groups of hindbrain neurons that express glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP1) and project to the limbic forebrain. Given evidence that brainstem GLP1 neurons and limbic GLP1 receptors are similar in rats and humans, results from this basic science project have potential translational relevance for understanding the neurobiological bases of normal threat responses and pathological anxiety in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Preclinical studies in rodent models and in vitro show that subtle decreases in body and brain temperature increase tau protein pathology, which is a central cause of Alzheimer’s disease; however, it’s not yet known whether body and brain temperature influences tau pathology in human, or, whether the known decrease in body temperature with ageing could contribute to increasing tau pathology with older age. In our preliminary study, we showed for the first time that lower body temperature naturalistically measured over 2 days in cognitively normal older adults strongly predicted increased tau pathology measured with tau position emission tomography. In the current study, we propose to build on this preliminary work using similar methods in a larger study of one hundred older adults who are cognitively normal or have mild cognitive impairment; results have the potential to identify a novel pathway underlying tau pathology in Alzheimer’s Disease, and, because lower body temperature may be a modifiable risk factor, to support future clinical studies to prevent the progress of tau pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The main goal of this project is to develop an informatics approach for automated extraction of SUDEP risk markers from multimodal clinical data to enable individualized SUDEP risk assessment. Success of this study will enable systematic SUDEP risk assessment based on known and putative factors and communication of such risk factors to patients with epilepsy. Ultimately, this study can lead to evidence-based SUDEP risk assessment tools that help clinicians and patients manage potentially modifiable risks, leading to overall reduced SUDEP mortality and improved epilepsy patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fentanyl test strips (FTS) are increasingly being used by people who use drugs, including those who use drugs other than heroin, to detect the presence of fentanyl in the unregulated drug supply as a strategy to prevent unintentional fentanyl overdose. Recent work based in Philadelphia found alarmingly high rates of FTS positivity in non-heroin drugs, suggesting that people who use drugs are incorrectly using FTS, incorrectly interpreting results, the non-heroin drug supply is much more contaminated than prior estimates have suggested, or a combination of the three. This project will fill important evidence gaps by assessing the real- world accuracy of FTS use by people who use drugs and current presence of fentanyl in non-heroin drugs in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE There is very limited knowledge on the impact of environmental exposures during pregnancy and long-term maternal health. We will evaluate the associations of urinary phthalate and organophosphate flame retardant metabolite concentrations during three window of exposure (preconception, pregnancy and midlife) with cardiovascular and metabolic health in midlife. Results will inform clinical care for women from the reproductive years through midlife and cardiovascular guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative: The ability to endure bouts of starvation and infection is a primitive challenge in animals, and in order to combat these ancient stressors animals, from insects to humans, have developed highly integrated metabolic and innate immune stress responses. Unfortunately, over-nutrition associated with modern high-calorie diets and poor eating habits often leads to mis-regulation of these same primitive responses and the development of metabolic diseases. The goal of our research is to use the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, as a simple model system to uncover the origins of diet-metabolic-innate immune interactions in order to advance our knowledge of diet- mediated metabolic dysfunction in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The vertebrate gut contains millions of bacteria, called the microbiome, that can have wide-ranging effects on host biology; in fact, recent studies have shown that the gut microbiome can drastically affect development and function of the brain and the nervous system of the gut. However, the large numbers of bacterial species in the gut and complexity of the vertebrate nervous system means that in order to understand how the microbiome interacts with the nervous system we need to find simple, manipulable systems in which to study these phenomena. We propose to use the association between the Hawaiian bobtail squid and its glowing bacterial symbiont as a simple, accessible, and manipulable model system in which to study interactions between beneficial microbes and animal nervous systems, focusing on the role of neurotransmitters in relaying signals between bacteria and their hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the rise in the impact of cardiovascular disease on US and world health, it is critical to train the next generation of physician-scientists in translational cardiovascular research. Participation in mentored research provides valuable training and increases the likelihood that medical students will continue to pursue research as part of their careers. This multidisciplinary Stanford Cardiovascular Summer Research Training Program for Medical Students is designed to train a diverse cohort of medical students in basic, clinical, translational and population level cardiovascular science, to provide them with a strong foundation of medical ethics, and to foster their development into investigators dedicated to identifying innovative solutions and capable of translating research into clinical success to combat cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes Self-Management Education and Support (DSMES) is an evidence-based, small group educational program that helps people with diabetes better control blood sugar (improved hemoglobin A1c) and reduce diabetes-related complications and healthcare costs. DSMES is strikingly underutilized with fewer than 10% of eligible patients receiving this helpful service due to patient-, clinician-, and health system-level barriers that include low clinician awareness and lack of integrated referral processes between clinics and community- based DSMES programs. Our project tests a clinic level-intervention that implements an electronic clinic- community referral system and creates a practice facilitation collaborative to empower clinical teams to identify and address DSMES barriers with the goal of increasing DSMES utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optimal cancer and functional outcomes from surgical treatment of head and neck cancer requires the surgeon to have the ability to intraoperatively distinguish neoplastic disease from adjacent normal tissue. Our novel optical imaging FLIm technique, coupled to the da Vinci surgical system, captures and analyzes tissue autofluorescence to identify distinct tissue types and display this information onto the surgeon’s field of view during trans-oral- robotic surgery (TORS). This enables a more accurate and optimal cancer removal while preserving adjacent normal tissue and function. The successful validation of FLIm, with the sophisticated incorporation of head and neck cancer patient and radiology data to improve the tissue classifier, will allow for more cures with less long- term side effects and will be easily extended to other robotic and endoscopic procedures, thus advancing innovation well beyond TORS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The 5-year survival rate of liver cancer patients is as low as 9.9% in the United States and 6.2% in Europe. Nearly 2 billion people worldwide infected with hepatic viral diseases are at risk for developing liver cancer and dying owing to limited therapeutic options. While historically systemic chemotherapy has been the cornerstone to cancer treatment, inability to achieve uniform drug delivery to tumors, collateral toxicity to non- cancerous liver and systemic side-effects have limited progress in the development of novel therapies for liver cancer. We propose a transformative platform technology that uses a catheter based locoregional approach to deliver X-ray visible bioengineered biomaterial, i.e. next generation TACE, to induce a more efficient ischemic cell death within the tumor microvasculature that can be coupled with chemo- and immunotherapy. We believe that our approach will prevent progression of cancer providing time to bridge more patients to the curative liver transplantation and extend lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Craniofacial birth defects and acquired diseases affecting the craniofacial region through treatment modalities or accidents often cause significant functional, structural, and esthetic damage to the face, mouth, and cranium. Despite recent advances in treatment options, the lack of knowledge in molecular mechanisms controlling craniofacial development and regeneration remains a major obstacle in development of more sophisticated therapies or more effective prevention of these conditions. The goal of this NIDCR Dental Specialty and PhD Program is to educate a diverse and uniquely qualified workforce that will accelerate our possibilities to prevent and treat craniofacial diseases and disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elderly subjects, aged 65 years and over, show suboptimal responses to influenza vaccination, and are at increased risk of influenza-related morbidity and mortality. While T cell responses have been shown to provide better correlation than humoral responses with respect to immune protection against influenza in the elderly, existing vaccine/adjuvant combinations may not elicit these required functional T cell responses. In this proposal, we aim to demonstrate the effectiveness of influenza vaccination/challenge studies in aged mice with the oral adjuvant 7HP349 that has shown enhancement of both humoral and T cell responses with multiple infectious disease vaccines, and to activate an IND and manufacture cGMP 7HP349 Drug Product to support a future Phase I/IIa clinical study for the improvement of the effectiveness of influenza vaccination in elderly subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Success of the proposed project would lead to the development of a superior replacement for all general- purpose radiotherapy machines with advantages in dose conformity, automation, and throughput. The project will allow completing the system, achieving regulatory clearance, carrying out the first clinical installation and performing a clinical study for lung cancer patients. The final clinical system would revolutionize the field of radiation therapy by allowing precise tumor targeting to be achieved with a quick, flexible robotic system enabling high patient throughput.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Melanoma is the leading cause of skin cancer related death and its incidence continues to rise. Despite the approval of targeted therapies and immune checkpoint inhibitors to treat melanoma, effective treatment options for metastatic disease remain an unmet need. In this proposal, we aim to better understand the crosstalk between tumor cell signaling pathways and immune cells in order to provide the preclinical basis for new therapeutic strategies.
